questions.text: A neonatologist assess a baby 5 minutes after birth and assigns an APGAR score of 5, with a score of 1 in each of the components. Which of the following is the baby likely to have?
questions.solution:
This baby with an APGAR score of 1 in each component is likely to have a weak cry.

Other options:

Option A: HR > 100/min gives a score of 2.

Options B and C: If present, each is given a score of 0. 

The Apgar score is a systematic way of assessing the infant after birth at 1 and 5 minutes of life. It gives a maximum score of 10 which indicates the newborn is in the best possible condition.

Scores between 0-3 require immediate resuscitation. Changes in the Apgar scores denote the response of the infant to resuscitation. If the score at 5 minutes remains less than 7, the infant should be assessed again every 5 minutes for the next 20 minutes.

questions.text: A patient presents with cutaneous vasculitis, peripheral neuropathy, severe sinusitis, and asthma. Labs show peripheral eosinophilia and elevated ESR. ANCA is positive. Which of the following features is false about the type of ANCA that will most likely be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Shows a nuclear type of staining

questions.solution:
This patient with cutaneous vasculitis, peripheral neuropathy, severe sinusitis, asthma, and eosinophilia with positive ANCA is most likely to have eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Churg-Strauss syndrome). The type of ANCA positive here is perinuclear ANCA or pANCA, which is directed against myeloperoxidase and not proteinase-3. 

Types of ANCA: 

  • Perinuclear ANCA (pANCA)- They are directed against the myeloperoxidase enzyme and cause nuclear or perinuclear staining on immunofluorescence microscopy. They are associated with microscopic polyangiitis, Churg-Strauss syndrome and crescentic glomerulonephritis.
  • Cytoplasmic ANCA (cANCA)- They are directed against the proteinase-3 enzyme and cause granular cytoplasmic staining on immunofluorescence microscopy. They are associated with Wegener's granulomatosis.

Related Pearl: ANCA Antibodies

The antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) are the antibodies that are targeted against the specific proteins present in neutrophils and monocytes. They can be further classified as:

 

Cytoplasmic ANCA (cANCA)

 Perinuclear ANCA (pANCA)

Directed against

Proteinase 3 (PR3)

 Myeloperoxidase (MPO)

Predominantly positive in

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener granulomatosis)

Microscopic polyangiitis

Churg–Strauss syndrome 

Crescentic glomerulonephritis

Inflammatory Bowel Disease

Staining pattern

Granular cytoplasmic staining

Perinuclear or nuclear staining

questions.text: Which of the following is the causative organism of Haverhill fever?
questions.solution:
Haverhill fever or Erythema arthriticum epidemicum is a rat-bite fever caused by Streptobacillus moniliformis

Rat-bite fever (RBF) is characterized by fever, rash, and arthralgia which usually occurs days or weeks after a bite.

The two types of rat-bite fever are:

  • Streptobacillary RBF develops 2–10 days after a rat bite, associated with sudden onset of fever, headache and myalgia followed by petechial rash and arthritis. It is also called Haverhill fever or Erythema arthriticum epidemicum.
  • Spirillary RBF is similar to streptobacillary type, associated with fever and regional lymphadenopathy. It is also called Sodoku.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about herd immunity?

choices.text: It refers to group protection beyond what is afforded by the protection of immunized individuals
Vaccination allows the possibility of 100% herd immunity against a disease
It is affected by presence and distribution of alternative animal hosts
It doesn’t protect the individual in the case of tetanus

questions.solution:
It is not possible to achieve 100% herd immunity against a certain disease but studies have shown this is not necessary for disease control.

Herd structure is never constant. It is subject to constant variation because of new births, deaths and population mobility. An ongoing immunization programme will keep up the herd immunity at a very high level.

Related Pearl: Herd Immunity

  • Herd immunity is the level of protection of a community against a particular disease brought about by vaccination or immunization.
  • It refers to group protection beyond what is afforded by the protection of immunized individuals.
  • It is difficult to maintain the chain of infection if a large portion of the population is immune to a certain disease.
  • Elements which contribute to herd immunity are:
    • Occurrence of clinical and sub-clinical infection in the herd
    • Immunization of the herd
    • Herd structure
  • The herd structure not only includes the primary species but also the presence and distribution of alternative animal hosts, vectors and other environmental/social factors that are related to disease spread.
  • It is not possible or necessary to achieve 100% herd immunity in a population.
  • The proportion of immune individuals above which a disease may no longer spread is called herd immunity threshold.
  • This threshold depends upon the virulence of the disease, efficacy of the vaccine and contact parameter for the population.
  • Herd immunity is determined by serological surveys.
  • Herd immunity doesn’t offer protection against diseases like tetanus.

questions.text: A positive Jacquemier's sign during the first trimester of pregnancy denotes :

choices.text: Rhythmic uterine contraction on bimanual examination
Increased pulsation felt through the lateral fornices

questions.solution: A dusky hue of the vestibule and anterior vaginal wall visible at about 8th week of pregnancy is called Chadwick’s sign or Jacquemier’s sign. The discolouration is due to local vascular congestion.

questions.text: The first case of a communicable disease introduced into a population unit is called as _________
questions.solution:
A primary case is the first case of a communicable disease introduced into a population unit.

Other options:

  • An index case is the first case of the disease that comes to the notice of an investigator or physician.
  • A suspect case is a case that has all the clinical features of the disease but has not been diagnosed with it.
  • A secondary case is one that develops after contact with the primary case.

questions.text: Which of the following systems are referred to as the drainage system of coarse type and fine type respectively?
questions.solution:
The lymphatic system is regarded as the drainage system of coarse type and Venous system is regarded as the drainage system of fine type.

The lymphatic system helps remove larger particles such as proteins and particulate matter from the tissue fluid. Therefore, they are considered as the drainage system of coarse type.

On the other hand, the venous system is considered as the drainage system of fine type.

questions.text: Which of the following is a good prognostic factor in schizophrenia?
questions.solution:
The presence of mood disorders e.g. depression is a good prognostic factor in schizophrenia.

Young age of onset, focal neurological deficits, and family history of schizophrenia suggest poor prognosis in schizophrenia.

Good prognostic factors Poor prognostic factors
Acute onset Insidious onset
Late-onset Early-onset
Presence of stressor Absence of a stressor

Good premorbid social, sexual,

and work histories

Poor premorbid social, sexual,

and work histories
Presence of depression No depression
Positive symptoms Negative symptoms
Family history of mood disorder Family history of schizophrenia
Married Single
Catatonic schizophrenia

Hebephrenic schizophrenia

questions.text: A 25-year-old male prefers to be detached, does not mingle with people, and often remains alone. He does not experience pleasure and is rather preoccupied with himself and his own fantasy world. This personality type will show__________
questions.solution:
A young male who is a loner by choice and emotionally cold comes under schizoid personality. Individuals with schizoid personality have low novelty seeking.

Novelty seeking (NS) is a temperament trait in the Cloninger’s model of personality and refers to the tendency to be intensely exhilarated or excited in response to novel stimuli.

High novelty seeking:

  • Individuals high in novelty seeking are quick-tempered, curious, easily bored, impulsive, extravagant, and disorderly.
  • High novelty seeking is related to addiction, ADHD and impulsivity.
  • Cluster B personality disorders like borderline, histrionic, narcissistic and antisocial have high novelty seeking behavior.

Low novelty seeking:

  • Persons low in novelty seeking are slow tempered, uninquiring, stoical, reflective, frugal, reserved, tolerant of monotony, and orderly.
  • Individual with schizoid personality is a markedly detached person who stays alone in introspection and lives in his own world of fantasy. This is associated with having a cold attitude.

Other options:

  • Magical thinking – Schizotypal personality
  • Grandiosity - Narcissistic personality
  • Impulsivity – Borderline personality, Antisocial personality

Related Pearl: Personality Disorders

Key features of Personality disorders

Cluster A (Odd, Weird, Eccentric)
Paranoid
Suspicious, distrustful, hypervigilant
Schizoid
Prefers to be loner, detached, unemotional
Schizotypal
Eccentric & odd thoughts, perceptions & behavior, magical thinking and beliefs

Cluster B (Dramatic, Emotional and Erratic)
Antisocial
Disregard for and violation of rights of others, illegal activities
Borderline
Chaotic relationships, sensitivity to abandonment, labile mood, impulsivity, inner emptiness, self-harm
Histrionic
Dramatic, superficial, attention-seeking
Narcissistic
Grandiosity, lack of empathy

Cluster C (Anxious, Fearful, Introvert)
Avoidant
Avoidance due to fears of criticism and rejection
Dependent
Submissive, clingy, needs to be taken care of
Obsessive-compulsive/
Anankastic
 
Rigid, controlling, perfectionist

questions.text: What is the ideal minimum duration of treatment (ATT) for tubercular meningitis?
questions.solution:
The ideal minimum duration of anti-tuberculosis therapy(ATT) for tubercular meningitis is 9 months.

X-pert MTB/RIF assay may be used as an adjunct in the diagnosis of TB meningitis. Steroids can also be used in HIV negative patients with TB meningitis.

The Index TB guidelines are for extrapulmonary TB.

Note: The Duration of ATT in lymph node and abdominal TB is 6 months.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding operative vaginal delivery using ventouse:

choices.text: The cup is placed over the flexion point closer to the anterior fontanelle
The chignon persists for several weeks
Traction is applied between uterine contractions
A vacuum of 0.2 kg/cm2 is induced and is gradually raised upto 0.8 kg/cm2

questions.solution:
The ventouse extraction begins by slowly initiating a vacuum of 0.2 kg/cm2. This takes about 2 minutes. The pressure is then gradually increased to at the rate of 0.1 kg/cm2 per minute until the effective vacuum of 0.8 kg/cm2.

Ventouse is an instrument used in operative vaginal delivery by creating a vacuum between it and fetal scalp. The instrument consists of:

  • Suction cup
  • Vacuum generator
  • Traction tubing device

The suction cup is placed on the fetal head at a point near the occiput, called the flexion point, which is an imaginary point on the sagittal suture, located about  6 cm from the center of the anterior fontanel or about 3 cm in front of the posterior fontanel. Thus the flexion point is closer to the posterior fontanel.

 

Once the cup is placed over flexion point, the vacuum is generated and traction is applied.

Traction:

  • The traction is applied at a right angle to the cup and should be synchronous to the uterine contractions.
  • Between the uterine contractions, the traction is released
  • The traction is made using one hand along the axis of the birth canal, while the fingers of the other hand are placed against the cup to note the correct angle of traction, rotation, and advancement of the head.

Traction should be abandoned if:

  • There is no decent of the presenting part with each pull
  • Delivery is not imminent after three pulls.

Under any circumstances, the traction should not exceed for more than 30 minutes. Once the head is delivered, the vacuum is reduced by opening the screw-release valve and the cup is then detached.

An artificial caput succedaneum (chignon) is produced due to the sucking. It usually disappears within a few hours.

Related Pearl: Caput succedaneum and Cephalohematoma

Indicators Caput Succedaneum Cephalhematoma
Location Presenting part of the head The periosteum of skull bone and bone
Time of appearance  Immediately after birth Several hours after birth
Cause Prolonged labor, causing venous stasis and edema  Instrumental delivery, causes rupture of emissary veins in skull
Extent of movement Both hemispheres; crosses the suture line Individual bones; do not cross the suture lines
Period of absorption 2-4 days 2 weeks to 3 months
Treatment None

Supportive.

It can cause neonatal jaundice

questions.text: The gluteus maximus muscle is attached to:
questions.solution:
The gluteus maximus muscle is attached to the iliotibial tract of the fascia lata.

Origin:

  • Posterior aspect of dorsal ilium, posterior to posterior gluteal line
  • Posterior superior iliac spine
  • Posterior aspect of sacrum and coccyx
  • Sacrotuberous ligament.

Insertion - It is inserted mainly in fascia lata at the iliotibial band and also into the gluteal tuberosity on the posterior femoral surface.

Action:

  • Major extensor of hip joint
  • Lateral rotation of hip joint
  • Active in powerful abduction of thigh

Arterial Supply - Inferior and superior gluteal arteries and the first perforating branch of the profunda femoris artery.

Nerve Supply- Inferior gluteal nerve (L5, S1 and S2).

Note:

The fascia lata is a deep fascial investment of the whole thigh musculature.

The iliotibial tract is a longitudinal thickening of the fascia lata, which is strengthened posteriorly by fibres from the gluteus maximus.

questions.text: An elderly woman with strangulated femoral hernia has abdominal pain and fecal vomits. Small intestines were found to be perforated. The next day she underwent a release of hernia and resection of intestines with an end- to-end anastomosis. After that, she started developing signs of peritonitis and died 3 days later. Which of the following options is the most appropriate for line I (a) of the death certificate?
questions.solution:
Peritonitis is appropriate for line I (a) of the death certificate as it is the disease/condition directly leading to death.

In this patient:

  • I(a) - Disease directly leading to death: Peritonitis
  • I(b) - Antecedent cause: Perforation of small intestine
  • I(c) - Condition which gave rise to the antecedent cause: Strangulated femoral hernia

Terminal events like circulatory failure and respiratory failure, are modes of dying. They should not be written as the immediate cause of death in the death certificate because they are only signs of death and provide no useful information regarding the underlying disease process.

Refer the last line in the death certificate with an asterisk (*).

Related Pearl: WHO Format for International Death Certificate

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy who is a known case of asthma with normal lung function, now presented with a sudden asthmatic attack. What is the ideal treatment of choice for this type of brittle asthma?
questions.solution:
The given condition is type II brittle asthma and subcutaneous adrenaline is the ideal treatment of choice.

Brittle asthma can be classified as:

Type 1 Type 2

Wide variations with a persistent pattern of variability in lung function tests, despite maximal therapy.

Characterized by normal or near-normal lung function with sudden, unpredictable, severe attacks in the background of controlled asthma.
Oral steroids, infusion of bronchodilators and dietary exclusion of allergens may be helpful Difficult to manage as they respond only to subcutaneous epinephrine

questions.text: Biosynthesis of glycosaminoglycans involves attachment to core protein, chain elongation, and chain termination. The synthesis of these core proteins occurs in ________
questions.solution:
Biosynthesis of Glycosaminoglycans involves attachment to core Protein, chain Elongation, and chain Termination. The synthesis of these core proteins occurs in the Endoplasmic reticulum.

Synthesis of GAG:

  • Synthesis of the core proteins: Endoplasmic reticulum
  • Biosynthesis of glycosaminoglycan chains and their subsequent modifications: Golgi apparatus

Glycosaminoglycans or mucopolysaccharides are complex carbohydrates made up of amino sugars and uronic acids. They may be attached to a protein molecule to form a proteoglycan. Proteoglycans are components of the ground substance of connective tissue. Proteoglycans have a bottle brush appearance.

The biochemically important GAGs are as follows:

  • Hyaluronic acid
  • Chondroitin sulfate
  • Keratan sulfate
  • Heparin
  • Heparan sulfate
  • Dermatan sulfate

questions.text: Which of the following cranial nerve nuclei is not a part of the general somatic efferent (GSE) column?
questions.solution:
The trigeminal nerve nuclei is not a part of the general somatic efferent (GSE) column. It originates from the special visceral efferent (SVE) column.

The general somatic efferent (GSE) is the most ventral column in the basal plate. It innervates the extrinsic ocular muscles and muscles of the tongue. It is represented by the oculomotor (III), trochlear (IV), abducens (VI), and hypoglossal (XII)nuclei.

Related Pearl: Arrangement of cranial nerve nuclei in the brainstem

Functional Component Cranial nerves 

General Somatic Efferent (SE/GSE)

 3,4,6,12

Special Visceral Efferent (SVE/BrE)

5,7,9,10,11

General Visceral Efferent  (GVE)

 3,7,9,10

General Visceral Afferent (GVA)

 7,9,10

Special Visceral Afferent (BrA/SVA)

General Somatic Afferent (SA/GSA)

 5,7,9,10

Special Somatic Afferent (SSA)

 2,8

GVE represents the parasympathetic supply; so all cranial nerves having parasympathetic fibers, have the GVE component.

questions.text: Which of the following is a false statement regarding amniocentesis?

choices.text: Traditional  amniocentesis is performed at 16-20 weeks
Traditional amniocentesis is difficult to do compared to early amniocentesis
Early amniocentesis is performed at 11-14 weeks
Less fluid is drawn in early amniocentesis compared to traditional amniocentesis

questions.solution:
Early amniocentesis (done at 11-14 wks) is more challenging than traditional amniocentesis because the amnion fuses with adjacent chorion only by 16 weeks of gestation, making the sac puncture more difficult.

Amniocentesis is performed using aseptic technique, under direct sonographic guidance, using a 20–22 gauge spinal needle.

The needle is directed into a clear pocket of amniotic fluid while avoiding the fetus and umbilical cord. Sonography is used to observe the uterine puncture site for bleeding and fetal cardiac motion is documented at the end of the procedure.

Approximately 20 to 30 mL of fluid is collected for fetal karyotyping and chromosomal microarray analysis.

Amniocentesis

Study material

Amniotic fluid with amniocytes

Time

16-20 weeks

Early amniocentesis

11-14 weeks

(associated with increased fetal loss, foot deformities)

(less fluid is drawn - approximately 1 ml for each week of gestation)

Indications

a) Diagnostic

Sex-linked disorders/Karyotyping/Inborn errors of metabolism/Neural tube defects

b) Therapeutic

Abortion induction, decompression of uterus in acute hydramnios, amnioinfusion in oligohydramnios
Complication

Chorioamnionitis

Premature Rupture Of Membranes (PROM)

Fetal trauma/loss

Fetomaternal haemorrhage

questions.text: You are about to administer neostigmine to a patient for reversal of neuromuscular blockade. Your senior asks you to add atropine to it. This is because atropine _______.

choices.text: Facilitates earlier recovery from neuromuscular blockade

questions.solution:
Atropine, a tertiary amine, is an anticholinergic drug that is used along with anticholinesterases like neostigmine in order to minimize the muscarinic adverse effects of anticholinesterases. It has no effect on the reversal of neuromuscular blockade produced by the nicotinic effect of anticholinesterases.

Atropine counteracts the cardiovascular effects of anticholinesterases like bradycardia and other bradyarrhythmias.

Glycopyrrolate, a quaternary amine, is another anticholinergic that can be used with anticholinesterases. It has a slower onset than atropine but does not cause central effects as it does not cross the blood-brain barrier, unlike atropine.

questions.text: Given below is the image showing an X-ray finding of a bone tumor. Which of the following is the true statement regarding this condition?

choices.text: Metaphysis of distal femur is a common location
Diaphysis of humerus is the most common location

questions.solution:
The given image shows a lateral radiograph of the tibia demonstrating the lamellated periosteal reaction in the diaphysis suggestive of Ewing’s sarcoma. The true statement regarding this condition is that it is a highly radiosensitive tumor.

Ewing sarcoma is the 2nd most common bone sarcoma in children. The majority of the patients affected are usually <20 years of age. It has a slight male predominance. The majority of Ewing sarcomas have a balanced translocation between the EWSR1 gene on chromosome 22 and the FLI1 gene on chromosome 11. 

It commonly involves the diaphysis of the long bones like the femur, tibia, fibula, humerus, and flat bones of the pelvis.

Patients present with painful enlarging mass, fever, and anemia. The affected area is usually tender, swollen, and warm. Laboratory findings may show an elevated WBC count and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR). 

A histopathological examination of Ewing sarcoma shows sheets of uniform, round blue cells arranged in Homer-Wright rosettes (shown in the image given below). Immunohistochemistry is usually positive for synaptophysin and mic-2.

Fluorescent in situ hybridisation (FISH) demonstrates a positive EWSR1 gene rearrangement, characteristic of Ewing sarcoma. In the image given below, the fused region denoted by yellow corresponds to a normal intact gene, while a split signal pattern showing separate red and green signals is indicative of EWSR1 gene rearrangement.

Radiological examination of Ewing sarcoma shows a destructive lesion in the diaphysis of long bones. Deposition of periosteal reaction in layers gives an onion-peel appearance. 

Since Ewing's sarcoma is a highly radio-sensitive tumor. It is treated with combined radiotherapy and chemotherapy.

Related Pearl: Radiosensitive and Radioresistant Tumors

Highly radiosensitive tumors :

  • Lymphoma
  • Seminoma
  • Myeloma
  • Ewing’s sarcoma
  • Wilms tumor

 Highly radioresistant tumors :

  • Melanoma
  • Osteosarcoma
  • Pancreatic carcinoma
  • Hepatic carcinoma
  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • glioblastoma

questions.text: A woman experiences hot flushes and sweating often and has stopped to menstruate for the last one year. She suspects that she has attained menopause. It would be considered to be a premature menopause if her age is less than_____.
questions.solution:
It would be considered to be a premature menopause if her age is less than 40 years.

Menopause is the permanent cessation of ovarian function, thereby leading to permanent amenorrhea. It usually occurs between 45–50 years, but the average age of menopause is 47 years old and is confirmed after 12 months of amenorrhea.

Clinical features of menopause:

  • Hot flushes, which are transient heat sensations occurring in the face and neck and lasting for 2–5 minutes, followed by sweating
  • Insomnia, headache
  • Dyspareunia
  • Irritability, depression, tiredness
  • Lack of concentration and lack of memory 

Menopause sets in when the follicle number falls below 1000. If this occurs before 40 years of age, it is termed premature menopause, while attaining it after 55 years is delayed menopause. 

The age at which menopause is attained is not related to age at menarche, race, the number of pregnancies, socioeconomic status, or oral contraceptive pills usage. However, it is directly influenced by smoking and genetic disposition. Perimenopause is the period 3–4 years preceding menopause and is followed by 1 year of amenorrhea.

questions.text: The great cerebral vein (of Galen) is formed by joining ________
questions.solution:
The great cerebral vein (of Galen) is a short median vessel, formed by the joining of the internal cerebral veins. It then curves sharply up around the splenium of the corpus callosum and opens into the anterior end of the straight sinus.

Related Pearl: Dural Venous Sinuses

Dural venous sinus Drains into
Unpaired sinuses
Superior sagittal sinus Confluence of sinuses or continues as right transverse sinus
Inferior sagittal sinus joins the great cerebral vein to form the straight sinus
 Straight sinus forms the left transverse sinus
Occipital sinus Confluence of sinuses
Paired sinuses
Superior petrosal sinus transverse sinus
Inferior petrosal sinus Internal jugular vein
Transverse sinus continue as sigmoid sinus
Sigmoid sinus continuous with the internal jugular vein
Cavernous sinus Superior and inferior petrosal sinuses

questions.text: In a 20-year-old female who is suffering from chronic urticaria, you notice that the following three phenomenons occur in a sequential manner on stroking her skin. i) Redness in the line of stroke, ii) edema, and iii) Spread of redness around the line of stoke. These events are also associated with severe itching. What is this pattern of dermographism?
questions.solution:
The sequential occurrence of these events in a patient with urticaria, associated with itching is suggestive of symptomatic dermographism.

Dermographism is commonly elicited in chronic urticaria patients.

  • Simple dermographism is defined as the triple response of local erythema due to capillary vasodilatation, followed by edema and a surrounding flare due to axon reflex‐induced dilatation of arterioles after stroking the skin.
  • However, in <5%, it is accompanied by severe itching (symptomatic dermographism or factitious urticaria).
  • Patients complain of wealing and itching at sites of trauma, friction with clothing or scratching the skin. The itching is usually disproportionately severe compared with wealing and is often most severe at night. 
  • The eliciting stimulus determines the shape of the weals, but they are often linear from scratching or stroking.

Other forms of dermographism include

  • Red dermographism - repeated rubbing is necessary to induce small punctate weals.
  • Cholinergic dermographism - seen in some patients with cholinergic urticaria. Here, the demographic response consists of an erythematous line studded with punctate weals.
  • Delayed dermographism - after normal fading of the triple response, a weal returns in the same site, but is usually tender and persists for about 48 hours.

questions.text: As an intern during ICU posting, you see a patient on controlled ventilation using the instrument seen in the image below. The circuit is a modification of which breathing system?
questions.solution:
The device shown in the given image is the Bain circuit, which is a coaxial version of Mapleson class D.

The Mapleson systems A-F are breathing systems with certain features similar to those of the circle system:

  • Use of fresh gas flow
  • Supply of gas from a reservoir to meet inspiratory requirements
  • Elimination of CO2

However, they differ from the circle system by having bidirectional gas flow and lacking an absorber.

Components of Mapleson systems include: 

  • Connection point to a facemask or endotracheal tube
  • Reservoir tubing
  • Fresh gas inflow tubing
  • Expiratory pop-off valve or port

The Mapleson D, E, and F systems (or the T-piece group) are commonly used. Here, fresh gas enters near the patient, and excess gas is removed at the other end of the circuit.

The Bain circuit, a coaxial modification of the Mapleson D system, incorporates an inner fresh gas tube within an outer corrugated hose. Fresh gas enters near the reservoir bag and exits into the circuit at the patient’s end. Exhaled gases pass down the corrugated hose around the central tubing and are removed through the pop-off valve near the reservoir bag.

The advantage of this system is that the fresh gas acquires heat from the warmer exhaled gases through concurrent heat exchange. The disadvantage is kinking of the inner fresh gas tubing, resulting in inadequate gas flow and hypercapnia. To prevent this, the outer corrugated tube should be transparent to allow periodic inspection of the inner tube.

The image below shows the Bain circuit:

Related Pearl: Mapleson Classification

Mapleson circuit   Other name  Fresh gas flow rate
Spontaneous ventilation  Controlled ventilation
A Magills 1 minute ventilation (MV) i.e. 80 ml/kg/min Very high and difficult to predict
B - 2-3× (MV) 2-2.5 × (MV)
C Water’s to and fro 2-3 × (MV) 2-2.5 × (MV)
D Bain circuit 2-3 × (MV) 1-2 × (MV)
E Ayre’s t-piece 2-3 × (MV) 3 × (MV)
F Jackson rees modification 2-3 × (MV) 2 × (MV)

 

Note:

The efficiency of Mapleson circuits in spontaneous ventilation is  A > DFE > CB (A Dog Can Bite - Usually a spontaneous event)

The efficiency of Mapleson circuits in controlled ventilation is DFE > BC > A (Dead Babies can't assist - controlled)



Related Pearl: Identification of Mapleson's circuits

Magill;

B Near patient Near patient Present Present Obsolete
C Near patient Near patient Present Absent Obsolete; Still used in emergency resuscitation (AMBU bag)
D Near patient Away from patient Present Present Bain (co-axial)
E Near patient Absent Absent Present Ayre's T piece
F Near patient Absent Present Present Jackson Rees Modification for pediatric patients

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presented with fever, pain, and refusal to use his right lower limb. He has a history of a recent ear infection. His WBC count was 22,000/ cumm with neutrophil predominance. ESR and CRP were elevated. The MRI demonstrated inflammatory changes in the bone marrow of the proximal tibia. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute hematogenous osteomyelitis and the next best step of management would be to start empirical antibiotic therapy.

Acute osteomyelitis is an infection of the bone that usually occurs in children. The most common organism responsible is Staphylococcus aureus. 

Children with acute osteomyelitis present with pain, malaise, fever, and refusal to use the affected limb. There may often be a history of recent infection. On examination, the child is ill, with tachycardia, with fever. There is tenderness near the affected joint, with redness, swelling, warmth, and edema.

Clinical diagnosis is confirmed by aspirating pus or fluid from the abscess, soft tissues, or the adjacent joint. Investigations reveal elevated WBC count, ESR, and CRP. Blood cultures should be done if a fever >38 °C is detected.

MRI is helpful when the diagnosis is doubtful or when there is a suspected infection of the axial skeleton. It is sensitive even in the early phases of bone infections and detects bone marrow inflammation.

If osteomyelitis is suspected clinically, blood and fluid samples should be taken for laboratory investigations and treatment should be started immediately. There is no need to wait for confirmation of the diagnosis to start treatment. The main aspects of treatment include:

  • Antibiotics- initially empirical, then specific
  • Surgical drainage
  • Limb splinting and rest
  • Management of pain and dehydration

Children between 6 months and 6 years should be started on iv flucloxacillin and cefotaxime or cefuroxime. If antibiotics are started within the first 48 hours, drainage is not always needed. Surgical drainage is indicated when:

  • The patient does not respond to antibiotics
  • Signs such as swelling, edema, and fluctuation are present
  • Pus is aspirated

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl presented to OPD  with multiple pigmented papular lesions on her face, neck, and forearm and corneal injection following exposure to the sun. Which DNA repair mechanism is defective in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture and the history are suggestive of xeroderma pigmentosum. The DNA repair mechanism that is defective in this condition is nucleotide excision repair (NER). The given image shows hyperkeratotic lesions with some induration suspicious of actinic keratosis and early squamous cell carcinoma. Also, numerous hyper-pigmented lentigos and xerosis are seen on the entire front of the face.

 Xeroderma Pigmentosum (XP) is a rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder characterized by defective DNA repair which leads to clinical and cellular hypersensitivity to ultraviolet radiation and other carcinogenic agents.

Skin changes begin in infancy or early childhood, mainly in sun-exposed areas. The skin lesions include erythema, scaling, bullae, freckles, telangiectasia, keratoses, basal and squamous cell carcinomas, and malignant melanomas. Eye manifestations include photophobia, blepharitis, keratitis, corneal opacities, eyelid tumors, and possible blindness. Neurologic abnormalities occur rarely in the form of cognitive deterioration and sensorineural deafness.

UV radiation leads to pyrimidine dimerization in DNA strands, preventing further replication by DNA polymerase. The nucleotide excision repair mechanism corrects the dimer formation in DNA. In XP, there is an inability to repair DNA pyrimidine dimers caused by UV exposure, and hence the accumulation of mutations that cause cancers.

questions.text: Identify the type of MRI image.
questions.solution:
The given MRI is a T1-weighted image as the CSF is dark/hypointense, white matter is white, and grey matter is dark.

Many pulse sequence techniques are used in MRI, but the most classic ones are T1- and T2-weighted imaging.

In T1 images, CSF is dark/hypointense, white matter is white, and grey matter is dark.

In T2 images, CSF is bright/hyperintense, white matter is dark, and grey matter is white. (water is white on T2, so is CSF)

The following images are T1 and T2 images:

 

Fluid-attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR) is an inversion recovery technique that nulls fluid from T2. So, CSF is dark, white matter is dark, and grey matter is white. 

The following shows FLAIR image:

Short-tau inversion recovery (STIR) is an inversion-recovery technique that nulls fat. So, fat is black.

questions.text: A lactating mother is worried that her medication might cause some problems for her baby because of breastfeeding. What advice would you give to that mother?

choices.text: Medications to be taken immediately after nursing and 1 hour before next feeding
Medications to be taken 30 - 60 min after nursing and 3-4 hours before next feeding
Medications can be taken at fixed times in a day irrespective of breastfeeding

questions.solution:
If the lactating mother should take medications and are deemed safe, the dosing optimally should be 30-60 minutes after nursing and at least 3-4 hours before the next feeding.

A minimum interval of 3-4 hours ensures the infants are not exposed to the peak maternal plasma concentration that may translate to higher levels secreted into milk.

Most drugs administered are detected in breast milk but most of them are excreted in very small quantities that do not cause any effect in the infants. However, intake of cytotoxic agents and immunomodulatory agents are contraindications for breastfeeding.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient is brought with 2nd degree burns involving the anterior aspect of both his lower limbs and the perineal region. According to the rule of 9, what is the BSA involved in this patient?
questions.solution:
19% of the body surface area (BSA) is involved in this patient. The anterior part of each lower limb, according to Wallace’s rule of 9, would be 9% each, and the perineum is considered to be 1% of the total BSA.

Rule of nines (Wallace): It divides the body into segments that are approximately 9% or multiples of 9%, with the perineum forming the remaining 1%. Because of the proportionately larger heads and smaller legs of infants and children, this method must be modified in a pediatric burn injury.

Note: Although Wallace’s rule of nines is more commonly used, the Lund and Browder chart is the most accurate in measuring the percentage of BSA affected in children and overall.

Related Pearl: Burns – Formulae for Fluid Calculation(Updated according to ATLS 10th edition 2018 guidelines)

Parkland’s formula gives the total fluid requirement for 24hours. Half of this volume is infused in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is infused in the next 16 hours.

This formula is recommended for those who have sustained large deep partial-thickness or full-thickness burns that cover more than 20% of the TBSA in adults and more than 10% in children. 

Formulas provide a starting target rate; Subsequently, the amount of fluid provided should be adjusted based on urine output.

Category of burn Age Amount of Ringer’s Lactate given for 24 hours (ml) Target urine output (ml/kg/hour)
2nd/3rd-degree burns Adults  2 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 0.5
<14 years 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1
< 1 year or <30kgs 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA + 5% dextrose on a maintenance rate 1
4th-degree burns / Electrical burns All ages 4 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1-1.5 (until urine clears)

Dextrose maintenance:

  • 100 ml/ kg in 24 hours for 10 kg
  • 50 ml/kg for next 10 kg
  • 20 ml/kg for every kg after 20 kg

Evan’s formula is used for normal saline.

For the first 24 hours:

  • Amount of NS administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • Amount of colloid administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • 5% Dextrose administered= 2000 ml

After 24 hours, the amount of NS and colloid administered is half. 2000 ml of dextrose is maintained.

Muir and Barclay’s formula for colloids:

  • 1 portion of colloid = (weight in kgs x % TBSA)/2
  • 6 portions of colloid are administered over 36 hours

questions.text: A washerman presents with itchy, annular scaly plaques in the groin. He is prescribed with an antifungal that acts by interfering with mitosis. Identify the drug.
questions.solution:
Itchy annular plaques in the groin are suggestive of tinea cruris and the drug most likely given was griseofulvin which acts by interfering with fungal mitosis. 

Microtubule function is necessary for the formation of the mitotic spindle during cell division. Griseofulvin inhibits microtubule function and thereby disrupts mitotic spindle formation and inhibits cell division.

Tinea cruris is a dermatophytosis involving the groin and is also known as jock itch or dhobi's itch.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of Antifungal drugs

questions.text: A 55-year-old man had died and his body was burnt after the final rituals. There were no significant clinical ailments in the past. His son doubted that his demise could have been due to poisoning by his business enemies. If so, which of the following agents could be traced now?
questions.solution:
It is possible to detect poisoning by arsenic even when the body has been burnt for a long time.

Arsenic is volatile but much of the arsenic in bones is converted into arsenates, which are non-volatile. 

In suspected cases of poisoning by arsenic, all the available ashes and burnt bones should be preserved for chemical analysis.

questions.text: A young male patient presents with progressive dyspnea and weakness. He gives a history of fever, myalgia, and sore throat one week ago.  To further evaluate him as per Dallas criteria, which of the following tests need to be performed?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of infective myocarditis. The Dallas criteria used for the diagnosis of myocarditis is based on endomyocardial biopsy. It is used to define the disease.

Active myocarditis is defined as an inflammatory infiltrate of the myocardium with necrosis and/or degeneration of adjacent myocytes not typical of the ischemic damage associated with coronary artery disease.

Borderline myocarditis is the term used when the inflammatory infiltrate is too sparse or myocyte injury is not demonstrated.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is diagnosed to have uterine fibroids. She would not be advised uterine artery embolization procedure as a viable option unless she has a _______________
questions.solution:
The intramural type of fibroid is not a contraindication for this procedure.

A calcified fibroid does not shrink with the procedure. The submucous and subserous types of fibroids are often pedunculated and can fall off after the procedure resulting in intrauterine and peritoneal infections respectively.

Hence, the calcified, submucous, and subserous types of fibroids are contraindications for this procedure. 

Related Pearl: Contraindications to uterine artery embolization

Absolute contraindications:

  • GnRH agonist use
  • Asymptomatic fibroids
  • Pregnancy
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease
  • Uterine malignancy
  • Calcified fibroid

Relative contraindications:

  • Patient desirous of future pregnancy: UAE causes poor uterine perfusion and pelvic adhesions, decreasing fertility. 
  • Postmenopausal women: Fibroids regress naturally, after menopause. Fibroid enlargement post-menopause raises the suspicion of malignancy.
  • Subserosal or submucosal fibroids: Pedunculated subtypes may detach intraperitoneally or within the uterine cavity. This may lead to sterile peritonitis or intrauterine infection.
  • Size or number of fibroids: Large fibroids or a greater number of fibroids can cause large amounts of necrosis following UAE. This may lead to post-op pain or infection. 
  • Contraindications to radiologic contrast agents.

questions.text: During the Covid-19 pandemic, an experimental drug called remdesivir was used for the first time in the corona virus-infected patient. This is considered ___________ phase of clinical trial.
questions.solution:
Most of the new drugs will be administered for the first time in patients with the target disease in phase 2 of clinical trials.

Phase II of clinical trials

  • It involves a small group of patients (50-500).
  • Most of the new drugs will be administered for the first time in patients with the target disease.
  • The study is designed to obtain "Proof of concept"(Potential of the drug to treat the disease) and dose-ranging study (provides input for choosing the most appropriate dose for phase III studies).

Note:
Phase III studies are also known as pivotal studies as they establish treatment benefits.

Randomized and controlled trial; may be blinded

questions.text: A child with recurrent UTIs is suspected to have a congenital renal anomaly. The following picture is seen on IV urography. Based on these findings, which of the following would you suspect?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a right-sided fishhook or S-shaped appearance of the ureter, where the right ureter hooks behind the inferior vena cava (IVC), as seen in the retrocaval ureter. 

Circumcaval or retrocaval ureter is a developmental anomaly of the inferior vena cava (IVC). It is due to abnormal development of the right supracardinal system. A persistent right posterior cardinal vein ends up passing in front of the ureter. The anomaly always occurs on the right side, as this is the side of the normal IVC.

Other options:

Option B: Vesicoureteric reflux (VUR) is a condition with a retrograde urinary flow from the bladder to the ureter and kidney. It is usually congenital. VUR can cause urinary stasis and lead to urinary tract infection (UTI). It also predisposes to pyelonephritis, which can lead to renal scarring due to parenchymal inflammation. This is known as reflux nephropathy. A micturating cystogram is used to confirm the VUR. 

Note: Bilateral fishhook or J-shaped or hockey stick ureters describe the course of the distal ureter in patients with significant benign prostatic hypertrophy (BPH).

Related Pearl: IVU signs and associated conditions

Medullary sponge kidney 

  • Bouquet of flowers/ paintbrush appearance
  • It refers to the cystic dilatation of the distal collecting tubules

Duplex kidney

  • Drooping lily sign
  • It refers to the inferolateral displacement of the lower pole due to an obstructed upper pole in a duplicated collecting system

Horseshoe kidney

  • Handshake sign - due to the position of the lower poles closer to the spine, and the lower calyces closer to each other
  • Flower vase sign - due to medially rotated calyces

Retroperitoneal fibrosis

  • Maiden waist deformity 
  • It refers to the medially drawn ureters caused by fibrosis at the lumbosacral junction

Retrocaval ureter 

  • Fish hook / Reverse J deformity 
  • Right ureter hooks behind the IVC as it passes posterior to it

Ureterocele

  • Cobra/ Adder head appearance
  • It refers to the dilation of the distal ureter

Transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter

  • Goblet sign
  • It is due to the focal dilation of the ureter by an intraluminal mass

questions.text: Calculate the alveolar ventilation in a young man if the respiratory rate is 10/min and tidal volume is 600ml.
questions.solution:
Alveolar ventilation = RR X (VT –V D)

In the given case,

  • Respiratory rate (RR)= 10/min
  • Tidal volume (VT) = 600 mL
  • Dead space volume (VD) = 150 mL in a young man

Thus, Alveolar ventilation = 10 X (600-150) = 4500 mL/min = 4.5 L/min

questions.text: A male patient presents with complaints of jaundice, loss of appetite, and weight loss for the past several months. After a full laboratory workup, a liver biopsy was performed which appeared as shown in the given image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given histopathological image shows ground-glass hepatocytes which are a hallmark of chronic hepatitis B infection. 

These ground-glass hepatocytes are liver parenchymal cells that have an eosinophilic, granular, and glassy appearance on light microscopy. This appearance is due to the accumulation of HBsAg (hepatitis B surface antigen) in the smooth endoplasmic reticulum.

Liver biopsy findings in viral hepatitis:

Virus Liver Biopsy Findings
Hepatitis A Hepatocyte swelling, monocyte infiltration, Councilman bodies
Hepatitis B  Ground glass appearance 
Hepatitis C  Lymphoid aggregates with a focal area of macrovesicular steatosis 
Hepatitis D Similar to HBV 
Hepatitis E Patchy necrosis

questions.text: Infrequent blinking seen in Graves ophthalmopathy is known as _________
questions.solution:
Infrequent blinking seen in Graves ophthalmopathy is known as Stellwags sign.

Graves ophthalmopathy: Most frequently affected extra ocular muscle in Grave's ophthalmopathy is Inferior Rectus.

Classification: Acronym ‘NOSPECS’:

  • Class 0 : No signs and symptoms
  • Class 1 : Only signs, no symptoms. Signs are limited to lid retraction with or without lid lag and mild proptosis
  • Class 2 : Soft tissue involvement with signs of class 1 and symptoms including lacrimation, photophobia, lid or conjunctival swelling
  • Class 3 : Proptosis is well established
  • Class 4 : Extraocular muscle involvement (limitation of movements and diplopia)
  • Class 5 : Corneal involvement (exposure keratitis)
  • Class 6 : Sight loss due to optic nerve involvement with disc pallor or papilloedema

EARLY Graves : class 1 and 2

Late Graves : class 3 to 6

Related Pearl: Signs in Grave’s ophthalmopathy

questions.text: A 42-year-old male patient presents with fatigue and breathlessness for the past 2 years. In has gradually been worsening. On examination, a holosystolic murmur is heard and echo suggests chronic severe mitral regurgitation, likely to be of a secondary cause. Which of the following is a likely to be that secondary cause?
questions.solution:
Mitral regurgitation(MR) maybe acute or chronic. Causes of chronic MR are further divided into primary (affecting leaflets and chordae) and secondary.

Primary causes are: Myxomatous (MVP, Barlow’s, forme fruste), Rheumatic fever, IE (healed), Congenital (cleft, AV canal) and Radiation. 

Secondary causes are: Ischemic cardiomyopathy, Dilated cardiomyopathy, HOCM (with SAM), and Chronic AF with LA enlargement and annular dilatation.

questions.text: Which of the following structure is not a part of the oropharynx?
questions.solution:
Fossa of Rossenmuller is a part of the nasopharynx (not oropharynx).

questions.text: With respect to a disinfectant, what does the phenol coefficient indicate?
questions.solution:
Phenol coefficient indicates the efficacy of a disinfectant as compared to phenol.

Phenol coefficient = The dilution of test disinfectant which kills microorganisms in a given time ÷ The dilution of phenol which kills the microorganism in the same time under identical conditions. 

The Rideal-Walker coefficient helps in determining the phenol co-efficient (PC) which indicates the power of a disinfectant. A PC value of more than 1 indicates that it is more effective than phenol. The higher the number, the greater its effectiveness in comparison to phenol and vice versa. It is only of historical value.

 Other methods for testing of disinfectants:

  • Chick Martin test: Tests the activity in the presence of organic matter, so it simulates natural conditions.
  • Kelsey Sykes (capacity) test: Tests the activity on repeated use of a disinfectant. 
  • Kelsey and Maurer test: Determines whether the chosen disinfectant is effective in actual hospital practice.

Joseph Lister first introduced phenol (carbolic acid) as an antiseptic to sterilize surgical instruments and  clean wounds. Lister's work led to a reduction in postoperative infections and made surgery safer for patients, distinguishing him as the 'Father of Modern Surgery' and 'Father of Antiseptic Surgery'.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-glaucoma agents has no effect on aqueous outflow?
questions.solution:
Timolol is a non-selective beta-blocker. Beta-blockers reduce intra-ocular pressure primarily by reducing aqueous humor production. Another hypothesis states that by reducing ocular blood flow, there may be a decrease in ultrafiltration responsible for aqueous production. 

Netarsudil is a rho-kinase inhibitor that acts by increasing trabecular outflow.

Brimonidine is an alpha-agonist that has a small effect on increasing both uveoscleral and trabecular outflow. 

Latanoprost is a prostaglandin PGF2-alpha analog that primarily acts by releasing matrix metalloproteinases, thereby increasing trabecular and uveoscleral outflow.

Related Pearl: Antiglaucoma drugs: Mechanism of lowering intraocular pressure (IOP) at a glance

Drugs that increase trabecular outflow

  • Miotics (e.g., pilocarpine)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Bimatoprost
  • Rho-kinase inhibitor (Netarsudil)

Drugs that increase uveoscleral outflow

  • Prostaglandins (latanoprost)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Brimonidine
  • Apraclonidine

Drugs that decrease aqueous production

  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide, dorzolamide)
  • Alpha receptor stimulators in ciliary process (e.g., epinephrine, dipivefrine, clonidine, brimonidine, apraclonidine)
  • Beta-blockers

Hyperosmotic agents - (e.g., glycerol, mannitol, urea)

questions.text: Which of the following is not the content of the triangle marked as E in the given image?
questions.solution:
The triangle marked as "E" in the above image represents muscular triangle and mylohyoid muscle is not the content of muscular triangle.

Boundaries of muscular triangle:

  • Anteriorly by the median line of the neck from the hyoid bone to the sternum
  • Inferoposteriorly by the anterior margin of sternocleidomastoid
  • Posterosuperiorly by the superior belly of omohyoid

The triangle contains omohyoid, sternohyoid,sternothyroid, and thyrohyoid muscles.

Other triangles marked in the above image:

  • A – Carotid triangle
  • B – Occipital triangle 
  • C – Subclavian triangle
  • D – Digastric triangle

Related Pearl: Triangles of the Neck

questions.text: A 55-year-old man was diagnosed with bladder cancer and an ureterosigmoidostomy  procedure is done for internal urinary diversion. Which of the metabolic abnormality is seen in this patient?

choices.text: Metabolic Alkalosis with compensatory respiratory acidosis

questions.solution:
Ureterosigmoidostomy procedure causes normal anion gap metabolic acidosis.

A ureterosigmoidostomy is a surgical procedure where the ureters which carry urine are diverted into the sigmoid colon. Here bicarbonate loss is accompanied by a gain of chloride; thus the anion gap remains unchanged.

questions.text: The dose-response curve shown in the following image is seen in ________.
questions.solution:
The dose-response curve shown in the following image is seen in vitamins.

Vitamins show a U-shaped dose-response curve. At a low dose, adverse effects are observed because there is a deficiency of these nutrients to maintain homeostasis. As the dose increases, homeostasis is achieved, and the bottom of the U-shaped dose-response curve is reached. As the dose increases to surpass the amount required to maintain homeostasis, overdose toxicity can ensue. Thus, adverse effects are seen at both low and high doses.

Hockey stick-shaped dose-response curve for toxicants that are also metabolic by-products depicted in the image given below.

Inverted U-shaped dose-response curve (image below) for ligands that downregulate their receptors.

questions.text: A young male patient who returned from Africa 12 months ago presents with complaints of excessive itching and rashes present all over his body. The life cycle of the parasite he was infected with is shown in the image. What is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The above image depicts the life cycle of Onchocerca volvulus, which is transmitted by the vector, black fly. Ivermectin is the drug of choice for onchocerciasis caused by Oncocerca volvulus in adults and children aged more than 5 years. 

Onchocerciasis may present with subcutaneous nodules or onchocercoma. It is a firm non-tender nodule arising from bony sites like the coccyx and sacrum. It is commonly associated with pruritus and rashes. Patients may also have loose skin with hypo or hyperpigmentation and a leopard skin appearance.

Ivermectin is also a drug of choice for human strongyloidiasis. It is used for chemoprophylaxis of lymphatic filariasis caused by W. bancrofti and B. malayi. It is as effective as diethylcarbamazine in treating lymphatic filariasis. It can also be used in strongyloidiasis, ascariasis and enterobiasis.

Ivermectin activates glutamate-gated Cl channels and GABA-gated channels, which causes muscular paralysis in nematodes. Cestodes and trematodes are not sensitive to ivermectin as they lack receptors for binding.

It is associated with Mazzotti reaction (fever, pruritic rash, lymphadenopathy) as a side effect when given for filariasis due to immune system activation by the deadly parasite. This reaction is also seen with the use of diethylcarbamazine.

Related Pearl: Indications of Ivermectin

  • Onchocerciasis
  • Chemoprophylaxis of filariasis
  • Strongyloidiasis
  • Gnathostomiasis
  • Scabies
  • Head lice

questions.text: The neurotransmitter released by the Renshaw cell is?
questions.solution:
The neurotransmitter released by the Renshaw cell is Glycine.

Renshaw cell inhibition is an example of negative feedback inhibition. The axon of a spinal motor neuron gives a recurrent collateral that synapses on an inhibitory interneuron that terminates on the cell body of the same and other motor neurons. This inhibitory interneuron is called a Renshaw cell and its neurotransmitter is glycine.

The Renshaw cell releases glycine to reduce the activity of the motor neuron.

questions.text: What is the engaging diameter in a face presentation with complete extension of the head?
questions.solution:
The engaging diameter in face presentation with a fully extended head is submento-bregmatic diameter which measures 9.5 cm.

Suboccipito-frontal 10 cm Incomplete flexion Vertex
Occipitofrontal 11.5 cm Marked deflexion Vertex
Mento-vertical 14 cm Partial extension Brow
Submento-vertical 11.5 cm Incomplete extension Face

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida has come with labor pain. On examination, she has effective uterine contractions with cervical dilation of 4 cm. In view of pain, she has requested the obstetrician for a painless, safe labor. If the anesthetist plans to give epidural for the same, which of the following would be preferred?
questions.solution:
A combination of a local anesthetic agent, ropivacaine with an opioid, sufentanil would be preferred.

The doses of local anesthetics can be reduced by the combination of local anesthetics with opioids like fentanyl or sufentanil. The lesser concentration of local anesthetic used leads to greater preservation of motor function and makes ambulation of the patient possible (walking or mobile epidural). Moreover, by reducing the concentration of the drugs, adverse effects like hypotension and drug toxicity are minimized.

Concentrations used for epidural:

Drug Concentrations
  Without opioid With opioid
Bupivacaine 0.25% 0.0625-0.125%
Ropivacaine 0.2% 0.0625-0.2%

The dose of opioid used:

  • Fentanyl : 2–3 mcg/mL 
  • Sufentanil: 0.3–0.5 mcg/mL

 

A combination of 1.5% lidocaine with 1: 200,000 epinephrine can be used as a test dose before giving the epidural drug mixture.

Epidural opioids, like morphine, can produce satisfactory labor analgesia only at relatively larger doses (>7.5 mg), which can cause respiratory depression. Hence it is not preferred.

When compared with ropivacaine + sufentanil, bupivacaine used alone is less preferred.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is typically associated with accelerations before and after a deceleration?
questions.solution:
Variable type deceleration is associated with umbilical cord compression. It has an acceleration at the beginning and also at the end.

These accelerations are described as the shoulders of the deceleration.

The following image shows the variable type deceleration:

  • Onset, nadir and recovery occur after the onset, peak and recovery of contraction
  • Abrupt fall in the heart rate     
  • Onset of a deceleration varies with each contraction
Time taken to reach the nadir of deceleration > 30seconds > 30seconds < 30 seconds
Special feature   Nil    Nil Associated with shoulders of acceleration at the beginning and end of a deceleration component
Cause Fetal head compression Fetal hypoxia due to maternal hypotension, placental dysfunction and excessive uterine activity Umbilical cord compression

questions.text: Abrasions are noted on the body of a person who was found dead at his home. Which of the following indicates that these might be produced after death?
questions.solution:
Abrasions present over bony prominences indicate that they might be produced after death. Antemortem abrasions may be located anywhere. 

Difference between antemortem and postmortem wounds:

Trait Antemortem wounds   Postmortem wounds
Site Anywhere on the body Usually over bony prominences  
Colour Bright reddish brown Yellowish, translucent, Parchment like 
Exudation More Less 
Microscopic Intravital reaction and congestion seen

questions.text: A 37-year-old man presented with a history of progressive hearing loss over a year, followed by an episode of sudden onset vertigo. He noticed an improvement in hearing after the vertiginous episode. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis would be Lermoyez syndrome. 

It is a variant of Ménière’s wherein the symptoms appear in reverse order. The patient presents with a progressive hearing loss followed by an attack of vertigo which causes improvement in hearing.

Lemierre’s syndrome is a condition characterized by infectious thrombophlebitis of the internal jugular vein and bacteremia caused by primarily anaerobic organisms, following a recent oropharyngeal infection. 

Leriche syndrome, commonly referred to as an aortoiliac occlusive disease, is due to thrombotic occlusion of the abdominal aorta just above the site of its bifurcation.

Leigh syndrome (subacute necrotizing encephalomyelopathy) is a rare genetic neurometabolic disorder characterized by degeneration of the CNS.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient underwent liposuction under local anesthesia. A few hours after the procedure, he presented with complaints of lassitude, shortness of breath, and slate grey cyanosis. The patient is started on 100 % oxygen, but the pulse oximeter still shows a saturation of 85%. Which of the following local anesthetic agents can most likely be attributed to his symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with refractory hypoxemia (no change in saturation even on oxygen supplementation) points to a diagnosis of methemoglobinemia. The local anesthetic agent which can be attributed to his symptoms is prilocaine.

Prilocaine is metabolized to o-toluidine in the liver, which converts hemoglobin (Fe 2+) to methemoglobin (Fe 3+), hence producing methemoglobinemia. Therefore, the use of prilocaine is limited to dental procedures.

Methemoglobinemia is characterized by cyanosis which does not respond to oxygen administration. On examination, slate grey/ brownish pseudocyanosis can be seen.

Interestingly, pulse oximetry in methemoglobinemia shows a plateau of 80% to 85% irrespective of the arterial oxygen saturation and the methemoglobin levels. Co-oximeters which can differentiate methemoglobin from carboxyhemoglobin, oxyhemoglobin, and deoxyhemoglobin are thus preferred. Treatment of methemoglobinemia includes reduction of methemoglobin to hemoglobin by intravenous methylene blue (1–2 mg/kg).

Note: Benzocaine used in topical local anesthetic sprays can also cause methemoglobinemia.

Related Pearl: High Yield Points in Local Anaesthetics

Cocaine: 

  • Naturally occurring
  • Vasoconstrictor
  • 1st local anesthetic

Chloroprocaine: Intradural injections are contraindicated and may cause paraplegia

Prilocaine: 

  • Safest
  • Causes maximum methemoglobinemia
  • Suitable for Bier’s IV block
  • EMLA is a eutectic mixture of LA containing 2.5% lidocaine & 2.5% prilocaine

Bupivacaine

  • Long-acting
  • Most cardiotoxic
  • Contraindicated in regional IV anesthesia
  • Toxicity is treated with amiodarone, bretylium(for VT), vasopressors (for circulatory collapse), isoproterenol and benzodiazepines (sedative)

Procaine

  • LA of choice in malignant hyperthermia
  • 1st synthetic LA
  • Metabolized to PABA, which have been associated with rare anaphylactic reactions

questions.text: A patient with a history of chest pain has elevated troponin I and Lactate Dehydrogenase (LDH)  but normal Creatine Kinase Myocardial Band (CK-MB). Approximately, how many days ago did he have the myocardial infarction?
questions.solution:
This patient, who has elevated troponin I and LDH but normal CK-MB had an MI approximately 6 days back.  

CPK-MB starts to rise by 4-6 hours and returns to baseline by 2-3 days. So Option A can be ruled out because before 2-3 days, CK-MB will also be elevated. By 10-12 days, troponin I returns to baseline. Thus, option B can be ruled out. By 10 days, LDH also return to baseline. Hence, Option D can be ruled out. Hence, the most appropriate answer is 6 days.

Troponin I and Troponin T are specific markers of myocardial infarction and they rise rapidly incase of an acute infarct. They rise to a diagnostic level at 12 to 16 hours after an infarct and peak 24 to 32 hours after the event. Following reperfusion the levels may still be higher. 

Creatine kinase Myocardial band (CK MB) - Although the levels of CK MB rise 4 to 8 hours after an infacrt it is not specific to the diseae as their levels are raised in other conditions such as muscular disorder or trauma including intramuscular injections. 

Myoglobulin rises within 2 hours of onset of symptoms and remains for 7 to 12 hours. 

Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) - LDH is leaked following cell death in a myocardial tissue and is a sensitive marker of the disease and the onset is 72 hours after the infarction but lasts till 10 days. 

Related Pearl: Cardiac Biomarkers

  Time to initial elevation Mean time to peak elevation Time to return to normal range
Myoglobin 1- 4 h 12 h 24 h
CK-MB 4-8 h 24 h 48-72 h
cTnI 3-12 h 24 h 7-10 d
cTnT 3-12 h 12h – 2d 7-10 d 

CK-MB: Creatine kinase-MB; CTnI: Cardiac-specific troponin I; CTnT: Cardiac-specific troponin T

questions.text: An 8-year-old child was brought to the hospital with sudden onset abdominal pain and vomiting.  During clinical examination, tenderness was present near the right iliac fossa, and McBurney's sign positive. Which of the following investigation is preferred in this child for diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of acute appendicitis. The investigation preferred in this child for diagnosis is USG.

A CT scan is the most effective and accurate imaging modality for appendicitis, but in pediatric and pregnant patients, USG is preferred to avoid the risk of radiation exposure.

Acute appendicitis begins as periumbilical pain, which is a visceral pain followed by anorexia and nausea; then, the pain shifts to the right lower quadrant due to peritoneal irritation.

Clinical features:

  • The classical features of acute appendicitis begin with poorly localized colicky abdominal pain.
  • This is due to midgut visceral discomfort in response to appendiceal inflammation and obstruction.
  • The pain is frequently first noticed in the periumbilical region.
  • The patient often gives a history of similar discomfort that settled spontaneously. Family history is also useful as up to one-third of children with appendicitis have a first-degree relative with a similar history.

The Alvarado Scoring System is the clinical scoring system used in the diagnosis of appendicitis.

Related Pearl: Alvarado Scoring System

Findings

Points

Migratory right iliac fossa pain

1

Anorexia

1

Nausea / vomiting

1

Tenderness in right iiliac fossa

2

Rebound tenderness right iliac fossa

1

Elevated temperature ≥ 37.3°C

1

Leukocytosis ≥ 10⨯109 cells/L

2

Shift to the left of neutrophils

1

 

A score of 4-5 or below rules out the diagnosis of acute appendicitis in children, and in adults, a score of 8-9 or higher rules in the diagnosis.

If the score is 4-6, an an adjunctive CT scan would be recommended to confirm the diagnosis.

If the score is 7 or higher, surgery is recommended.

questions.text: You are a cardiologist with a very busy OPD. You have four patients with atrial fibrillation. Assuming no other comorbidities exist, except what is given, for which of these patients, are anticoagulants definitely recommended?

choices.text: A 78 year old man with diabetes
A 45 year old man with hyperthyroidism
A 55 year old man with hypertension
A 48 year old man with claudication

questions.solution:
Patients with atrial fibrilation are scored according to the CHADS2 or CHA2DS2-VASc scoring, to assess the risk of stroke. Among the four patient we have, only the 78 year old man with diabetes, had a CHADS2 score or >2 and hence, anticoagulants are definately recommended in him. 

Treatment based on CHA2DS2 (Congestive heart failure, Hypertension, Age>75, Diabetes, Stroke) scoring is as follows: 

CHADS2 score Antithrombotics
0 Aspirin or no antithrombotics
1 Aspirin or oral anticoagulant
2 or more Oral anticoagulant

Note :

A newer scoring system used to assess the risk of stroke in patients with non-valvular AF is the CHA2DS2-VASc scoring.

Other Options:

Option B: CHA2DS2 score is 0.

Option C: CHA2DS2 score is 1.

Option D: CHA2DS2-VASc score is 1. CHA2DS2 Score is 0 because it does not take peripheral vascular disease into account.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not correct regarding the Schultze method of placental separation?

choices.text: The separation begins at the centre of the placenta.
The fetal surface of the placenta appears first at the vulva.
The maternal surface of the placenta appears first at the vulva.
There is a formation of retroplacental clot.

questions.solution:
The below image A shows the Schultze method of placental separation. In this method, the fetal surface of the placenta appears first at the vulva.

Placental separation occurs during the third stage of labor. There are two mechanisms by which placental separation may occur:

A. Central separation of the placenta, known as Schultze method

B. Marginal separation of the placenta, known as Mathews-Duncan method.

Schultze method:

The process of separation begins at the center of the placenta (fetal surface). Consequently, this central part descends first and becomes visible at the vulva. During this phase, blood gathers in a membranous sac located behind the placenta, resulting in the creation of a retroplacental clot. Bleeding does not happen until the placenta is fully expelled

Mathews-Duncan method:

Placental separation begins at the periphery of the placenta, leading to the maternal surface becoming visible first. Blood gathers between the membranes and the uterine wall and is discharged through the vagina. Unlike the previous method, there is no development of a retroplacental clot, resulting in significant bleeding during this type of placental separation. However, it is less frequent compared to the Schultze method.

questions.text: A schizophrenic patient was started on an antipsychotic drug that decreased his hallucinations significantly. 3 days after starting the medication, he developed torticollis and orofaciolingual movements. This effect is due to which of the following actions?
questions.solution:
The patient is suffering from acute dystonia. Acute dystonia is seen due to the D2 blocking effect of the antipsychotic.

Acute dystonia is an extrapyramidal side effect of antipsychotics that occurs within 1-5 days of intake.It is characterized by spasms of the muscles of the tongue, face, neck and back.

Amongst extrapyramidal symptoms of antipsychotics, acute muscular dystonia is the earliest appearing symptom and akathisia is the most common one.

Other options:

Option A: Alpha blockade results in hypotension and sedation.
Option B: H1 blockade results in an antiemetic effect and causes sedation
Option C: Antimuscarinic effect result in dry mouth, dilated pupils, and urinary retention.

Related Pearl: Extrapyramidal side effects of antipsychotic drugs

questions.text: A Hepatologist decided to perform a percutaneous transhepatic cholangiogram in a patient. Which of the following needle is used for this procedure?
questions.solution:
The Chiba needle is used for percutaneous transhepatic cholangiogram(PTC). The other needle used for this procedure is the Okuda needle.

This is an invasive technique in which the bile ducts are cannulated percutaneously using the Chiba or Okuda needle. Under radiological control (either ultrasound or CT) a bile duct is cannulated. Successful entry is confirmed by contrast injection or aspiration of bile.  Multiple images can be taken demonstrating areas of strictures or obstruction.

In general, if a malignant stricture at the level of the confluence of the right and left hepatic ducts or higher is suspected in a jaundiced patient, a PTC is preferred to ERCP(Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography) because successful drainage is more likely.

Other options:

Option B: Huber needle is used for accessing the port for subsequent addition of fluid to the band system percutaneously after gastric banding in bariatric surgery.

Option C: Jamshidi needle is used for bone biopsy of bone tumours. 

Option D: Menghini needle is used in liver biopsy.

questions.text: What are prevalence studies also known as?
questions.solution:
Cross-sectional studies help in obtaining the prevalence of a disease. Hence, they are also known as prevalence studies.

Cross-sectional study is a type of observational study where a cross-section of a population is examined once at one point in time. It is more useful in studying chronic diseases than acute ones. They do not provide information on the natural history of disease or incidence and also do not establish the time sequence.

questions.text: A 6-month-old baby was brought to the clinic with a history of failure to thrive. Further examination shows generalized hypotonia and hepatomegaly. Chest X-ray image shows massive cardiomegaly. Microscopy of a muscle biopsy is shown in the given image. Which of the following is the treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical symptoms of hypotonia, hepatomegaly, and cardiomegaly, along with muscle biopsy showing vacuoles are suggestive of Pompe's disease. 

Pompe's disease (type II glycogen storage disorder) occurs due to a mutation in alpha-1,4-glucosidase (also known as acid maltase), a lysosomal enzyme. A defect in this enzyme leads to the accumulation of glycogen in the lysosomes of peripheral, voluntary muscles and progresses to involve the cardiac muscle and diaphragm. Clinical features include hypotonia (floppy baby syndrome), cardiomyopathy, hepatomegaly, and failure to thrive. Myozyme 

The treatment for Pompe disease is recombinant enzyme alglucosidase alfa (Myozyme), which can prevent worsening or reverse cardiac and skeletal abnormalities.

questions.text: A study on mood stabilizers shows that a new drug X works faster to stabilize mood than the standard drug Y. The results are statistically significant. The study is carried out 100 different times and shows such significant differences 95 times. What is the likelihood of a type II error?
questions.solution:
The likelihood of a type II error here is 5%.

A type II error is the probability of rejecting the alternate hypothesis when it is true. It is also known as a beta error.

In this case, it is the chance of saying the experimental drug does not work better than the standard drug, while it actually does. This happened in 5/100 studies, hence the likelihood of a type II error (beta) is 5%.

Note: Power = 1- beta. Here, the power of the study is 95%.

Related Pearl: Concepts in Hypothesis Testing

Probability value (p value)

  • A probability value is the probability of an outcome given the hypothesis.
  • It is not the probability of the hypothesis given the outcome, although the probability of the given hypothesis is not ignored.
  • If the probability of an outcome is sufficiently low, we have evidence that the hypothesis is false.
  • It is also called the p value.

The Null Hypothesis and Alternative Hypothesis

  • The hypothesis that an apparent effect or outcome is only due to chance is a null hypothesis.
  • In other words, a null hypothesis is one where there is no difference between the specified sample and population and any observed difference is due to chance or some other error.
  • A null hypothesis is represented by H0.
  • If the null hypothesis is rejected as false, then there is an alternative or experimental hypothesis (HA), which is logically accepted.

Criterion or Significance Level (α)

  • If the probability value of an outcome is sufficiently low, then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • This point below which we would define the probability value as being low enough to reject the null hypothesis is called the criterion or significance level or α (alpha) level.
  • When the null hypothesis is rejected, the effect or outcome is said to be statistically significant.
  • By convention (but not always), the level of α is 0.05, i.e., if the probability value of an outcome is less than or equal to 0.05 (p value ≤ 0.05), then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • If it is greater than 0.05, then the null hypothesis is accepted.
  • Although by convention the level of α is 0.05, it can be lower but cannot be any higher.

Type I Error

  • The interpretation of p value ≤ 0.05 is that an investigator can be 95% sure that the result was not obtained by chance.
  • It also means that there is a 5% probability that the result was obtained by chance.
  • From this, we can deduce that the null hypothesis might indeed be true even though we rejected it.
  • This is a type I error. In other words, when an alternative hypothesis is accepted even when it is false and the null hypothesis is true, it is a type I error or false positive error.
  • It is also called an alpha (α) error as it is related to the criterion α.
  • The lower the α level, the lower the rate of a type I error being made.
  • Thus, it can be said that α is the maximum tolerable probability that a type I error is being made and that the p value is the probability that a significant difference is declared when there is none.

Type II Error

  • The error that is made by rejecting an alternative hypothesis when it is true or failing to reject a null hypothesis when it is false is called a type II error.
  • It is also called a false negative error and more commonly, as a beta (β) error.
  • If the null hypothesis is false, then the probability of a type II error is β.
  • The power of a statistical test is indicated by 1–β.

Power of a Test

  • The power of a test is the ability of a statistical test to avoid a type II error, which depends on its ability to detect a false null hypothesis.
  • It is equal to 1–β, which is the probability that a false null hypothesis will be rejected.
  • By convention, a test is required to have a power of 0.8 (or a β of 0.2) to be acceptable. This is to say that a study that has less than 80% chance of detecting a false null hypothesis is unacceptable.
  • Type I errors are easily reduced by reducing the criterion α.
  • A test's power will increase in the following conditions:
    • If α increases, but this will increase the chance of a type I error.
    • If the difference between the sample mean and hypothesized mean increases. This is also called effect size.
    • If sampling error decreases.
    • If the sample size (n) increases.
