questions.text: The hysterosalpingography of a patient with chronic pelvic inflammatory disease shows bilateral fallopian tube blockage. Which of the following organisms has the highest propensity to cause this tube block?
questions.solution:
Chlamydia trachomatis has the highest propensity to cause bilateral fallopian tube blockage.

Chlamydia infection remains asymptomatic in the endocervix and produces minimal symptoms, and therefore the infection goes unnoticed and untreated, but the damage it causes to the fallopian tube is five times higher than Neisseria gonorrhoea.

Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) is usually a polymicrobial infection. The most common causes of PID are Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae. 

Other organisms causing PID are Mycoplasma, E.coli, and anaerobes. PID commonly spreads as ascending infection along with sperms. Genital tuberculosis mostly has a hematogenous spread.

On ultrasound, a tubo-ovarian abscess may be seen which appears as a complex cystic adnexal or cul-de-sac mass with thick irregular walls and septations.

Related Pearl: Organisms Responsible for Pelvic Inflammatory Disease

Sexually transmitted: Gonococcus, Chlamydia, Mycoplasma, Trichomonas 
Aerobes: Staphylococci , Streptococci ,E. coli
Anaerobes: Bacteroides fragilis, Peptococcus, Clostridium, Actinomyces (IUD)
Others: Tubercular salpingitis
 

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male came with complaints of acute abdominal pain. He was diagnosed with appendicitis. He also had a previous history of similar presentation, so laparoscopic appendectomy was done. Among the given options, which condition is associated with risk-reduction in the post-appendectomy status of the patient?
questions.solution:
Appendectomy is protective in Ulcerative Colitis and also recurrence of disease after colectomy is uncommon.

There is a protective effect of the previous appendectomy with confirmed appendicitis (risk reduction of 13–26%), particularly at a young age.

However, appendectomy is not protective in the other options.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man comes with the following findings. He says that he cut himself while shaving 3 months back. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of a shaving cut and the image showing a large area of scar tissue are suggestive of a keloid.

A keloid refers to excess accumulation of collagen at the scar site with growth of the scar tissue beyond the boundaries of the original wound. It does not regress.

Option A: Exuberant granulation or proud flesh refers to the protrusion of excessive amounts of granulation tissue above the level of the surrounding skin. This blocks re-epithelialization. 

Option B: The accumulation of excessive amounts of collagen may give rise to a raised scar known as a hypertrophic scar. However, it remains within the boundaries of the original scar.

Option D: Pyogenic granuloma is a benign, vascular tumor.

questions.text: A 2-year-old malnourished child presents with loose stools. The child has symmetrical edema, weight/height <70% of expected and height/age < 85% of expected. Management of this child involves ___________

choices.text: Continue aggressive hydration even after dehydration resolves for the next 2 hours
Use low sodium ORS for rehydration 5ml/kg every 30 min for first 2 hours
Give 5ml/kg of ringer lactate IV if unconscious

questions.solution:
The above child has severe malnutrition. Management should involve the use of low sodium ORS for rehydration 5 ml/kg every 30 min for first 2 hours.

WHO Classification:

Parameter  Moderate malnutrition Severe malnutrition
Symmetrical edema No Yes
Weight/height (wasting) -2 to -3 S.D(70 to 79% of expected) < -3 S.D (<70%)
Height/age(stunting) -2 to -3 S.D(85 to 89%) < -3 S.D (<85%)

Treatment:

  • Do not give IV fluids unless the child is in shock.
  • Give ReSoMal (low-sodium rehydration solution for malnutrition) 5 mL/kg every 30 min for the first 2 hours orally or NG tube.
  • Then give 5-10 mL/kg in alternate hours for up to 10 hour. The amount depends on stool loss and eagerness to drink. Feed-in the other alternate hour.
  • Give ReSoMal after each watery stool as a prevention strategy.

Treatment of hypoglycaemia in malnutrition:

  • If conscious: 10% glucose (50 mL), or a feed or 1 teaspoon sugar under the tongue-whichever is the quickest.
  • If unconscious: Immediately give sterile 10% glucose (5 mL/kg) by IV.

Related Pearl: Comparison between low-osmolar oral rehydration solution and ReSoMal

Composition Low-osmolar ORS (mmol/L) ReSoMal (mmol/L)
Glucose  75 125
Sodium  75  45
Potassium  20  40
Chloride  65  70
Citrate  10  7
Magnesium  ---  3
Zinc  --- 0.3
Copper  --- 0.045
Osmolarity (mOsmol/L) 245 300

questions.text: A first-year medical student during his practical exam was given with 1st rib and asked to name the small projection seen on the medial (inner) border of the 1st rib, which is present between two grooves. Which of the following structure passes through the groove related anteriorly to the tubercle?
questions.solution:
The scalene tubercle is a feature of the 1st rib present as a small projection on the medial (inner) border of the 1st rib and the subclavian vein is present anterior to this tubercle.

Structures passing through the grooves related to the scalene tubercle are

  • Anterior groove - Subclavian vein.
  • Posterior groove - Subclavian artery and lower trunk of brachial plexus. (Option B and C)

Scalenus anterior is attached to the scalene tubercle.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male, who is a known case of CKD and T2DM, felt dizzy and uncomfortable after undergoing hemodialysis. On examination, his BP was found to be 90/70 mmHg. As a physician, if you are suspecting a constituent of a dialysate, what could it be?
questions.solution:
Acetate once used as a buffer in the dialysate is the most common cause of dialysis-induced hypotension because of its vasodilatory and cardio-depressive effects.

Hypotension is the most common acute complication of hemodialysis, particularly among patients with diabetes mellitus.

Acute complications of Hemodialysis :

  • Hypotension
  • Dialysis disequilibrium syndrome
  • Anaphylaxis
  • High output cardiac failure if AV fistula or graft is used for access.
  • Muscle cramps.                                                                                   

Note: Dialysis-associated hypotension has become less common these days due to the use of bicarbonate.

questions.text: Satellitism in H. influenza demonstrates the dependence of:
questions.solution:
Satellitism in H.influenza demonstrates the dependence of Factor V.

This phenomenon is seen when S. aureus is streaked across a plate of blood agar on which H. influenzae has been inoculated. After overnight incubation, the colonies of H. influenzae will be large and well developed alongside the streak of Staphylococcus and smaller, farther away from the streak.

This is due to the release of factor V by lysis of RBCs mediated by S. aureus and factor V is required for the growth of H. influenza.

Factor V is a co-enzyme, nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD), or NAD phosphate (NADP) which acts as a hydrogen acceptor in the metabolism of the cell. It is heat-labile, being destroyed at 120°C in a few minutes. It is present in red blood cells and in many other animal and plant cells.

Factor X is hemin or other porphyrins required for the synthesis of cytochrome and other heme enzymes such as catalase and peroxidase involved in aerobic respiration. It is heat stable.

questions.text: Otoendoscopy of a patient revealed cholesteatoma limited to the protympanum. Which of the following sites is being referred to here?

choices.text: The developmental predecessor of the middle ear
The anterior part of middle ear
The part of the middle ear foremost in conduction of sound
The part of middle ear around the eustachian tube

questions.solution:
The part of the middle ear around the eustachian tube is referred to as the protympanum.

The middle ear is divided into 3 main parts:

  • Epitympanum/attic- above the level of pars tensa, medial to pars flaccida, and scutum.
  • Mesotympanum- opposite the pars tensa
  • Hypotympanum- below the level of TM

questions.text: Which of the following extrapyramidal side-effects of anti-psychotic drugs occur after months or even years of treatment?
questions.solution:
Tardive dyskinesia is a late extrapyramidal feature that usually occurs after months or years of antipsychotic treatment.

It is characterized by stereotyped, repetitive, painless, involuntary, quick choreiform (tic-like) movements of the face, eyelids, mouth, tongue, extremities, or trunk.  It results from an increase in the nigrostriatal dopaminergic activity. Therefore, dopaminergic drugs like levodopa and anticholinergics will increase severity.

Related Pearl: Extrapyramidal side effects of antipsychotic drugs

Spasm of muscles of tongue, face, neck, back
Diphenhydramine or benztropine

questions.text: A farmer developed multiple ulcerative nodules along the lymphatics following a rose thorn prick a week ago. Microscopic finding of the skin biopsy is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows an asteroid body which is characteristically seen in a case of sporotrichosis.

Asteroid bodies are formed due to the deposition of the immune complexes around the yeast cell. It consists of a central rounded or oval basophilic, cigar-shaped yeast cell surrounded peripherally by eosinophilic radiations. Formation of such structures is called the Splendore-Hoeppli phenomenon.

Note: Asteroid bodies are also seen in sarcoidosis. Those are irregular, star-shaped inclusions seen in multinucleate giant cells.

questions.text: A diabetic patient with chronic kidney disease has been undergoing hemodialysis for the past 4 years. Deposition of which of the following is likely in this condition?
questions.solution:
Patients on long-term hemodialysis for renal failure can develop amyloidosis as a result of the deposition of β2-microglobulin.

This protein is present in high concentrations in the serum of persons with renal disease. The protein is retained in the circulation because it cannot be filtered through the dialysis membranes.

It gets deposited in the synovium, joints, and tendon sheaths. When this deposition takes place in the carpal ligament of the wrist, it leads to the development of carpal tunnel syndrome.

With new dialysis filters, the incidence of this complication has decreased substantially.

questions.text: Which of the following is involved in locking of knee?

choices.text: Lateral rotation of the femur on tibia during extension
Medial rotation of the femur on tibia during flexion
Lateral rotation of the femur on tibia during flexion
Medial rotation of the femur on tibia during extension

questions.solution:
Locking of knee is medial rotation of femur on tibia during the later stages of extension.

When standing, the knee joint is locked into position to reduce the amount of muscle work needed to maintain the standing position. The muscle responsible for locking is vastus medialis.

The image given below shows the locking of knee joint on standing.

Unlocking of the knee joint is the lateral rotation of femur on tibia during the beginning of flexion. This is brought by the action of popliteus muscle.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy living near the sea mistakenly consumes pufferfish and complains of vomiting, diarrhoea, abdominal pain with ascending paralysis, and eventually dies with respiratory failure. The toxin in this poisoning acts mainly on which of the following channels?
questions.solution:
Puffer fish poisoning is caused by the toxin tetrodotoxin. This toxin acts mainly on the sodium channnels.

This toxin is also used to study the flow of ions across the various other individual channels by blocking sodium channels. For instance, the sodium channels are blocked by tetrodotoxin when it is applied to the outside of the cell membrane where the sodium activation gates are located.

questions.text: PRPP synthetase is an example of:
questions.solution:
PRPP synthetase is a ligase.

Synthetases are ATP-dependent enzymes catalyzing biosynthetic reactions that belong to the class ligases. Ligases catalyze joining together of two molecules with the hydrolysis of ATP.  Examples are PRPP synthetase, argininosuccinate synthetase, glutamine synthetase, Acetyl -CoA carboxylase, etc.

Synthases are ATP-independent enzymes catalyzing biosynthetic reactions. They belong to class other than ligases. Examples are ALA synthase and glycogen synthase. Lyases cleave bond without adding water. Examples are aldolase, fumarase, HMG-CoA lyase, argininosuccinate.

Transferases catalyze the transfer of functional groups from one substrate to another.

Hydrolases Catalyze hydrolytic cleavage of C-C, C-O, C-N, and other covalent bonds.

Related Pearl: Enzyme classification

There are seven groups of enzymes according to IUBMB.

E.C. NO. Enzyme class Type of reaction catalyzed with examples
1 Oxidoreductases

Catalyze redox reactions

  • Dehydrogenase
  • Oxygenase
  • Oxidase
  • Catalase
  • Peroxidase
2 Transferases

Catalyze the transfer of functional groups from one substrate to another.

  • Kinases
  • Transaminases
  • Transmethylases
3 Hydrolases

Catalyze hydrolytic cleavage of C-C, C-O, C-N, and other covalent bonds.

  • Lipase
  • Arginase
  • Pepsin
  • Esterase
4 Lyases

Catalyze the cleavage of C-C, C-O, C-N, and other covalent bonds by atom elimination, thereby generating double bonds.

  • Aldolase
  • Fumarase
  • HMG-CoA lyase
  • Arginosuccinase
5 Isomerases

Catalyze structural changes within a molecule.

  • Phosphohexoisomerase
  • Mutase
  • Racemase
6 Ligases

Catalyze the joining together of two molecules in reactions.

  • Acetyl CoA carboxylase
  • PRPP synthetase
  • Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase
  • Glutamine synthetase
7 Translocases Catalyze the movement of molecules or ions across membranes.

questions.text: You are sending pharmaceutical waste from the hospital for inertization. What percentages of cement and lime are added for this method of biomedical waste treatment?
questions.solution:
The percentages of cement and lime used for inertization are 15% and 15% respectively.

Inertization is the process of mixing biomedical waste with non-toxic substances to reduce the toxicity of the waste and reduce the contamination of groundwater. It is most commonly used for incineration ash with high metal content. The typical composition of the inertization mixture is:

  • 65% - pharmaceutical waste
  • 15% - cement
  • 15% - lime
  • 5% - water

A homogeneous mass is formed and cubes or pellets are produced on-site and then transported to suitable storage sites.

questions.text: In a pregnant woman, on performing Leopold's 1st grip, you are able to palpate a freely mobile, hard and globular mass. Which of the following fetal parts is the denominator in this case?
questions.solution:
If a freely mobile, hard and globular mass is found on the 1st Leopold's grip, the fetus is in a longitudinal lie, in podalic/ breech presentation, and hence will have sacrum as the denominator.

The fetal denominator refers to the bony fixed point of reference on the presenting part with respect to different quadrants of the pelvis. The denominators for various presentations are as follows:

Presentation Denominator
Breech Sacrum
Vertex Occiput
Face Mentum (chin)
Brow Frontal eminence
Shoulder Acromion

 Note: The question refers to a breech pregnancy hence the part felt on the 1st Leopold's grip would be a smooth, hard globular mass indicative of head. The image provided is that of a fetus in a normal longitudinal lie, vertex presentation.

Fetal pole, lie, presenting part, engagement, and attitude of fetal head are assessed by Leopold's maneuvers:

Leopold grip Also known as Importance
First Fundal grip To know which fetal pole occupies the uterine fundus.
Second Lateral/ Umbilical grip To know the fetal back and extremities 
Third Pawlick grip

To know the presenting fetal part in respect to the true pelvis
Fourth Pelvic grip

To determine the degree of descent.

If the head has already descended into the pelvis, the anterior shoulder or the space created by neck may be differentiated readily from the head

 

Interpretation of various fetal parts felt in Leopold's grips:

  • Large, soft, nodular mass - indicates breech 
  • Hard, round, mobile mass - indicates head  
  • Uniform curved hard resistance- indicates back
  • Small, irregular, mobile parts- indicate fetal extremities 

Definitions of various terminologies used for the fetus in utero:

  • Lie: Relationship of the long axis of the fetus to the long axis of the maternal spine.
  • Presentation: Part of the fetus occupying the lower pole of the pelvis.
  • Presenting part: Part of the presentation which overlies the internal os.
  • Attitude: The relation of the different parts of the fetus to one another.
  • Position: Relation of the denominator to the different quadrants of the pelvis.

questions.text: A patient with suspected tuberculosis gives a sputum sample for smear. What is the minimum number of acid-fast bacilli that should be present in 1 mL of sputum for them to be demonstrable under the microscope?
questions.solution:
At least 10,000 acid-fast bacilli should be present per milliliter of sputum for them to be readily demonstrable in direct smears.

Slide reporting as per RNTCP guidelines: 

No. of AFB

No. of oil immersion fields examined

 Report
0 100 0
1-9 100 Scanty
10-99 100 1+
1-10 1 2+
>10 1 3+

 

Related Pearl: Diagnostic algorithm for Pulmonary TB – National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP) 2020 Guidelines

Any case of presumptive pulmonary TB should undergo sputum examination + chest X-ray + CB-NAAT

  • If sputum and chest X-ray normal: rule out TB and refer
  • If sputum is positive and CB NAAT is positive: microbiologically confirmed case of TB

The following protocol is used for CB-NAAT testing:

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Type of TB Case Intensive Phase Continuation Phase
New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) 2 months H R Z E 4 months H R E

Classification based on drug resistance. 

The cases are classified as:

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

Standard DR TB regimen

Regimen class Drugs Comments
H mono-resistant/ poly-drug resistant TB regimen Lfx R E Z for 6 months

6 months long

Oral drugs only
BPaLM regime (New MDR regime by WHO) Bdq Pa Lzd Mfx for 6 months

6 months long
9- 11 months shorter oral bedaquiline regime (Shorter MDR)

Intensive Phase:

Lfx Bdq(6 months) Cfz Z Hh E Eto for 4-6 months

Continuation phase:

Lfx Cfz Z E for 5 months

9-11 months long totally

Injectables used in Intensive phase.
Longer MDR TB regimen Bdq(6 months or longer) Lfx Lzd Cfz Cs 

18-20 months long

Oral drugs only

This regimen is used for XDR TB patients for 20 months.

 

Criteria for patients to receive standard Drug Resistant TB regimen:

Standard Drug Resistant TB regimen Inclusion criteria Exclusion criteria
H mono-resistant/poly-drug resistant TB regimen Isoniazid resistant TB with rifampicin sensitive No specific criteria
BPaLM regimen (New MDR TB regimen by WHO)
  1. MDR/RR-TB or pre-XDR-TB ( MDR/RR-TB and resistance to fluoroquinolones). 
  2. Those with confirmed pulmonary TB and all forms of extrapulmonary TB (except for TB involving CNS, osteoarticular, and miliary TB).
  3. Patients >14 years of age.
 Pregnant and lactating women
9- 11 months shorter MDR TB regimen Patient with rifampicin resistant pulmonary or extra pulmonary TB Non drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • Pregnancy
  • Any extra pulmonary disease in PLHIV
  • Disseminated meningeal or central nervous system TB
  • Intolerance to any drug in the shorter MDR TB regimen
Drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • If DST/DRT result for FQ or SLI is resistant (XDR TB)
  • Presence of InhA mutation
  • Resistant to Z 
Longer MDR TB regimen Patients in whom shorter MDR TB regimen cannot be considered due to any reason None

Legend

SLI: Second Line Injectable

PLHIV: People Living with HIV

questions.text: The table shows the examination findings of various psychiatric emergencies presenting with fever and altered sensorium.  Which of the following may be seen in neuroleptic malignant syndrome?
questions.solution:
Option A is seen in Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS). 

Neuroleptic malignant syndrome refers to a syndrome of muscle rigidity, hyperthermia, and hypertension in psychotic patients treated with antipsychotics like phenothiazines. Dopamine antagonism is believed to be the probable mechanism 

Treatment includes stopping offending antipsychotic immediately, supportive care, dantrolene, and bromocriptine.

Other options in the above table represents:

Option B- Serotonin syndrome.

Option C- Anticholinergic syndrome.

Option D- Malignant hyperthermia.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist?
questions.solution:
Metyrapone is not a mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist.

It is a selective inhibitor of 11β-hydroxylase and thereby reduces cortisol and corticosterone synthesis.

Options A and B - Spironolactone and eplerenone are aldosterone antagonist that is used in hypertension and chronic CHF for reversing the effects of aldosterone

Option C - Drospirenone is a 4th generation progestin used as an oral contraceptive having mineralocorticoid antagonist action

questions.text: A poultry worker was admitted to ICU with severe pneumonia. Bronchoalveolar lavage was done; it showed Levinthal Cole Lillie bodies.  Which of the following is the causative organism for the above condition?
questions.solution:
Pneumonia in a poultry worker with Levinthal-Cole-Lillie bodies on bronchoalveolar lavage specimens is suggestive of psittacosis.

Levinthal-Cole-Lillie bodies are inclusion bodies of Chlamydia psittaci seen in infected cells including alveolar macrophages from patients suffering from psittacosis. C. psittaci can be transmitted to humans by direct contact with infected birds or by inhalation of aerosols from avian feather dust. Psittacosis presents with fever, chills, muscular aches and pains, severe headache, hepatosplenomegaly and gastrointestinal symptoms. Severe pneumonia may develop. It is treated with tetracycline. 

Related Pearl: Inclusion bodies seen in various conditions/diseases

questions.text: A 30-year-old female comes to the PHC with the contraceptive pill strip shown in the image below. She has forgotten the instructions given on how to start taking the pills and asks your help on the same. She is on Day 1 of her menstrual cycle. What is the dose of each pill and how frequently would you instruct her to take it initially for effective contraception?
questions.solution:
The contraceptive pill which the woman has is Chhaya which has 30 mg of centchroman. Centchroman is a synthetic nonsteroidal contraceptive started on the first day of menses and taken twice weekly for 12 weeks and weekly thereafter.

To begin the use of Chhaya, the woman is advised to take the first pill on the first day of the period and the second pill three days later. This pattern of days is repeated throughout the first 3 months. Starting from the fourth month, the pill is to be taken once a week on the first pill day and should be continued on the weekly schedule regardless of her menstrual cycle.

Effects:

It does not prevent ovulation but prevents implantation through endometrial changes.

It exhibits a strong antiestrogenic and a weak oestrogenic action peripherally at the receptor level

The return of fertility occurs soon after stoppage of the drug (within 6 months)

Centchroman is not teratogenic or carcinogenic, exerts no pharmacological effect on other organs. The drug can also be used as a postcoital pill, given in 60 mg dose within 24 h of coitus (two tablets repeated 12 h later with a failure rate of 1%). 

Side effects include Gain in weight, some delay in the return of fertility (up to 6 months). It does not protect against HIV and STD. Prolonged use can result in hyperplasia and atypical endometrium.

Contraindications

PCOD, hepatic dysfunction, cervical dysplasia, allergy to the drug.

Update: Saheli is renamed as Chhaya and is now available in two packages: ASHA supply (for home distribution) and free supply (for distribution at health facilities).

questions.text: The snake shown in the image is found in the ocean. Its venom is most likely to be:
questions.solution:
The snake in the given image is a sea snake, and its venom is myotoxic. 

The venom of sea snakes is myotoxic. Myotoxin causes severe muscle necrosis via a non-enzymatic mechanism.

Related Pearl: Identification of Poisonous Snakes

  • Anticoagulant effect: widespread bleeding

  • Krait

  • Local reaction:
    • Mild
  • Neurotoxicity leads to muscle paralysis

Hydrophidae (sea snakes) are now considered a subfamily of Elapidae

questions.text: A 12-year-old child while playing challenges his younger brother to keep on inspiring until he says to stop. Due to intact Hering-Breuer reflex activation, the younger child could not inspire continuously for a longer time. This reflex will not be activated until his tidal volume reaches:
questions.solution:
Hering-Breuer reflex probably is not activated until the tidal volume increases to more than three times normal (>≈1.5 liters per breath). Therefore, this reflex appears to be mainly a protective mechanism for preventing excess lung inflation

In the Hering-Breuer inflation reflex, prolonged inspiration inhibits further inspiration. Hyperinflation of the lungs stimulates slowly adapting pulmonary stretch receptors and the impulses travel in the vagus nerve via large myelinated fibers. This signal inhibits the inspiratory ramp signals of the dorsal respiratory group of neurons (DRG), thus, inspiration is quickly inhibited and expiration follows. It cuts down the inspiration time, and prevents overinflation of the lungs.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of death in children with untreated Hirschprung's disease?
questions.solution:
Enterocolitis is the most common cause of death in children with untreated Hirschsprung's disease.

Hirschsprung disease or congenital aganglionic colon is characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the myenteric (Auerbach) plexus and submucosal (Meissner) plexus of the distal intestinal segment. This is because of the premature arrest of normal migration of neural crest cells from the cecum to the rectum.

Hirschsprung disease is classified into:

  • Short-segment - limited to the rectosigmoid segment
  • Long-segment - proximal extension beyond the rectosigmoid segment

It may be familial or associated with Down syndrome. The following gene mutations can be seen,

  • Mutations in chromosome 10 (loss-of-function mutations in the receptor tyrosine kinase RET) or chromosome 13
  • glial cell line-derived neurotrophic factor (GDNF) mutations

It is more common in males. Most infants present with abdominal distension and bilious vomiting with failure to pass meconium within the first 24 hours of life. Enterocolitis is a potentially fatal complication.

Hirschsprung's-associated enterocolitis is characterized by abdominal distension, tenderness, diarrhea alternating with periods of obstipation, hematochezia, and systemic toxicity (fever, failure to thrive, and lethargy). Infants are often dehydrated and show leukocytosis with an increase in circulating band forms on hematologic evaluation.

Its treatment includes rehydration, systemic antibiotics, rectal irrigations, colonic decompression, and definitive surgery.

The investigations for Hirschsprung’s disease are as follows:

Water-soluble contrast enema is the initial investigation. It shows a narrow distal aganglionic segment, a conical transition zone, and the dilated proximal bowel. It helps in excluding other causes of distal intestinal obstruction, such as colonic atresia, meconium ileus, and meconium plug syndrome. It is both diagnostic and therapeutic for the latter.

A contrast enema image in Hirschsprung's disease is shown below,

Rectal biopsy is the gold standard investigation. It shows the following:

  • Absent ganglia
  • Hypertrophied nerve trunks
  • Positive immunostaining for acetylcholinesterase
  • Calretinin immunostain­ing (superior to acetylcholinesterase staining)

Anorectal manometry shows the failure of the relaxation of the internal anal sphincter. It can be performed in older children, but it is relatively inaccurate and rarely used.

 Definitive surgeries for Hirschsprung disease are as follows:

  • Swenson
  • Duhamel
  • Soave

questions.text: A patient presents to the dermatology clinic complaining that a birthmark that was asymptomatic has now become pruritic with the following appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows an eczematous ring surrounding a melanocytic naevus (birthmark), suggestive of halo dermatitis. 

It is also known as Meyerson nevus. Histology shows a benign naevus surrounded by a dermal lymphocytic and eosinophilic infiltrate, with acanthosis, spongiosis, and parakeratosis.

The condition usually resolves spontaneously within few months without involution of the nevus.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient came to the hospital with complaints of paroxysmal vertigo, drop attack, during arm exercise. This is due to_______.

choices.text: Occlusion in the 1st part of subclavian artery
Occlusion in the 2nd part of subclavian artery
Occlusion in the 3rd part of subclavian artery

questions.solution: Subclavian steal syndrome occurs if there is an occlusion in the 1st part of the subclavian artery. Arm exercise causes syncope because of reversed flow in the vertebral artery leading to cerebral ischemia. It can be treated by angioplasty or surgery.

questions.text: Which of the following has the least total cross-sectional area?
questions.solution:
Aorta has the least total cross-sectional area (4.5 cm2) and capillaries have the maximum cross-sectional area (4500 cm2).

In the circulatory system, the highest velocity of blood flow is in the aorta. The velocity of blood flow is inversely proportional to the vascular cross-sectional area.

v= velocity
F= blood flow through the vessel
A=vascular cross-sectional area.

Thus, under resting conditions, the velocity is highest in aorta and least in capillaries.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about a partial mole?

choices.text: Initial beta hCG levels <1 lakh mIU/ml

questions.solution:
p57KIP2 immunostaining is positive in a partial mole.

Gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD) refers to a spectrum of interrelated but histologically distinct tumors originating from the placenta.

Trophoblastic tumors

Related Pearl: Complete vs. Partial Mole

Hydatidiform mole is a benign abnormal condition of the placenta characterized by partial degenerative or proliferative changes of the chorionic villi. Though benign, it has malignant potential. It is commonly seen in pregnancies of extreme reproductive age groups - teenage and women above 35 years of age. A previous history of molar pregnancy is also a strong risk factor for recurrence of this condition.

Molar pregnancy is of 2 types - complete mole and partial mole.

questions.text: A 45-year-old, chronic alcoholic male developed dyspnoea, fever, and hypotension after being administered 2 units of fresh frozen plasma. Oxygen saturation of 88% and bilateral lung infiltrates were seen in the chest x-ray. He was diagnosed to have a Transfusion Related Acute Lung Injury (TRALI). What is the duration within which TRALI occurs after a transfusion?
questions.solution:
Transfusion-related acute lung injury(TRALI) occurs during or within 6 hours of transfusion.

TRALI is a sudden onset of respiratory failure resulting from the transfusion of donor fresh frozen plasma and platelets that contain high-titer of anti-HLA antibodies. These antibodies bind recipient leukocytes and aggregate in the pulmonary vasculature, releasing mediators that increase capillary permeability. 

The pathogenesis involves a two-hit hypothesis:

  • Priming event - increased sequestration and sensitization of neutrophils in the microvasculature of the lung
  • Second hit - the aggravating factor (most commonly MHC class II  antibodies) present in the transfused blood product activates the primed neutrophils

TRALI is a severe fatal complication of blood transfusion. The implicated donors are frequently multiparous women. Recipients with a history of pre-existing lung diseases, smoking, chronic alcohol use, mechanical ventilation and cancer surgeries are at increased risk of developing TRALI. 

The recipient develops symptoms of hypotension, fever, hypoxia and signs of noncardiogenic pulmonary edema, including bilateral interstitial infiltrates visible on the chest X-ray.

Treatment is supportive, and patients usually recover without sequelae. The incidence of TRALI has been reduced by choosing males and nulliparous women as donors.

Related Pearl: Blood Transfusion Reactions

(Most common complication of blood transfusion)

Typically caused by IgG antibodies to foreign protein antigens and are associated with laboratory features of hemolysis.

Non-immune mediated transfusion reactions are as follows:

  • Transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO)
  • Hypothermia
  • Electrolyte abnormality- hyperkalemia, hypocalcemia
  • Iron overload
  • Transient hypotension
  • Immunomodulation
  • Blood-borne infections

questions.text: Deep sulcus sign on a supine chest radiograph is seen in:
questions.solution:
A deep sulcus sign on a supine chest radiograph is seen in pneumothorax.

The costophrenic angle is abnormally deepened when the pleural air collects laterally, producing the deep sulcus sign. 

AP view plain chest x-ray showing pneumothorax. There is an increase of transradiancy at the left lung base and the costophrenic sulcus laterally is more pronounced (‘deep sulcus sign’-yellow arrow).

Pneumothorax refers to the presence of gas (air) in the pleural space. When this collection of gas is constantly enlarging with resulting compression of mediastinal structures it can be life-threatening and is known as a tension pneumothorax. The best X-ray view to diagnose pneumothorax is a PA view in full expiration.

Types of pneumothorax:

  • Primary spontaneous: No underlying lung disease
  • Secondary spontaneous: Underlying lung disease is present
  • Iatrogenic/traumatic  

Chest radiograph in spontaneous pneumothorax demonstrates:  

  • The visible visceral pleural edge is seen as a very thin, sharp white line
  • No lung markings are seen peripheral to this line
  • The peripheral space is radiolucent compared to the adjacent lung.
  • The lung may completely collapse.
  • The mediastinum should not shift away from the pneumothorax unless a tension pneumothorax is present.
  • Subcutaneous emphysema and pneumomediastinum may also be present.
  • The deep sulcus sign on a supine chest radiograph is an indication of a pneumothorax. In a supine film (common in the ICU), it may be the only indication of pneumothorax because air collects anteriorly and basally within the nondependent portions of the pleural space, as opposed to the apex when the patient is upright.

questions.text: In the given image, the structure marked as "C" develops from which of the following?
questions.solution:
The structure marked as C in the given image is the medulla oblongata, which develops from myelencephalon. It is a part of the rhombencephalon.

The rhombencephalon is subdivided into a cranial part—the metencephalon—and a caudal part—the myelencephalon.

  • The metencephalon forms the pons and cerebellum(marked as B and D respectively)
  • The myelencephalon forms the medulla oblongata.

Mesencephalon forms midbrain which is marked as "A" in the above image.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient was brought to the casualty after a road traffic accident and eFAST was performed on him. Which among the following statements is true regarding eFAST?

choices.text: It detects free fluid in the abdomen or pericardium
It helps in assessment of retroperitoneum

questions.solution:
eFAST/extended FAST helps in detecting free fluid in the abdomen and pericardium. 

Focused assessment with sonography for trauma (FAST) aims to identify intra-abdominal free fluid (assumed to be hemoperitoneum in the context of trauma) allowing for an immediate transfer for surgery or for CT imaging and further workup.

The standard order of evaluation is:

  • Pericardial (subxiphoid)
  • Right flank (perihepatic view or Morison's pouch)
  • Left flank (perisplenic view)
  • Pelvic (retrovesical views)

eFAST (Extended FAST) is used to assess pleural (pneumothorax and hemothorax evaluation), pericardial region, right flank, left flank, and pelvic region. It is accurate in detecting >100 ml of free blood. Hollow viscus injury and solid organ injury are difficult to diagnose. It is also unreliable in excluding injury in penetrating trauma. It is unreliable for the assessment of the retroperitoneum.

questions.text: Pregnancy is a pro-coagulant state. Which of the following is not true about hematological changes in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Clotting factor XIII decreases during pregnancy.

Pregnancy is a hypercoagulable state. Haematological changes in pregnancy include:

  • All clotting factors are increased (except factor 11,13).
  • Clotting time and bleeding time are unaffected.
  • Anticoagulants Protein C, Protein S and antithrombin decrease during pregnancy.
  • The most common cause of decreased platelet count in pregnancy is benign gestational thrombocytopenia (may be due to hemodilution and increased platelet consumption and women are asymptomatic).

questions.text: A 40-year-old man was started on an anticancer drug for the germ cell tumor of the testes. After 2 months he started developing the following skin lesions. Identify the anticancer drug:
questions.solution:
The given scenario is of a germ cell tumor of the testes and the image shows flagellate dermatitis. So, the anticancer drug is bleomycin.

Flagellate dermatitis is bands of pruritic, linear, and erythema maculae over the trunk and extremities. It can be associated with conditions such as dermatomyositis. It can also be seen as an adverse effect a few hours to 6 months after the administration of drugs like bleomycin, and peplomycin.

The rash of flagellate dermatitis heals with persistent flagellate hyperpigmentation. These lesions readily respond to topical corticosteroids, but usually, disappear after the stoppage of the drug. 

Bleomycin is DNA cleaving anticancer antibiotic that causes oxidative damage to nucleotides, resulting in single- and double-stranded breaks in DNA. It is used as a component in the treatment regimens of testicular cancer and Hodgkin's lymphoma.

Bleomycin has a little myelosuppression effect. The major adverse events include dose-dependent pulmonary toxicity (irreversible pulmonary fibrosis) and flagellate dermatitis.

Other options: 

Option A: Oxaliplatin is an antineoplastic drug used in the treatment of colorectal cancer. The adverse events include peripheral neuropathy, leukemia, and pulmonary fibrosis. 

Option C: Dacarbazine is a methylating agent used in the treatment of Hodgkin's lymphoma, malignant melanoma, and sarcomas. The adverse effects include myelosuppression, hepatotoxicity, flu-like syndrome, and alopecia.

Option D: Doxorubicin is an anthracycline antineoplastic drug used in the treatment of malignant lymphomas, Ewing sarcoma, soft-tissue sarcomas, and breast carcinoma. The major adverse effects include myelosuppression, cardiomyopathy, alopecia, and stomatitis.

questions.text: The alternative pale and dark laminations seen in the given image are typically seen in ________
questions.solution:
The given alternative pale and dark laminations are typically seen in Thrombi.

They are called lines of Zahn, which are pale platelet and fibrin deposits alternating with darker red cell–rich layers.

They signify that a thrombus has formed in flowing blood; their presence can, therefore, distinguish antemortem clots from the nonlaminated postmortem clots.

questions.text: All of the following diseases are transmitted by the vector shown in the image except:
questions.solution:
Scrub typhus is not caused by the vector shown in the image (tick).

The vector shown is a hard tick and transmits tick typhus, viral encephalitis (e.g., Russian spring-summer encephalitis), viral fevers (e.g., Colorado tick fever), viral hemorrhagic fevers (e.g. KFD in India), tularemia, tick paralysis, and babesiosis.

The following image shows a soft tick.

Scrub typhus is transmitted by trombiculid mite which is as shown below.

Related Pearl: Ticks

  • The two types of ticks are hard ticks and soft ticks.
  • The general morphology of ticks includes an oval-shaped body, four pairs of legs, and no antennae.
  Hard tick Soft tick
Scutum A chitinous shield that covers the entire back in males. Females have a small portion in the front. Absent.
Head Situated at the anterior end. Lies on the underside of the body (ventrally). Not visible from above.
Eggs Several hundreds or thousands laid at once Laid in batches of 20 – 100 over a long period
Nymphal stages One Five
Habits Cannot withstand starvation; feed night and day. Can withstand starvation for more than a year.
Vectors for Tick typhus, viral encephalitis, viral fevers, tularemia, Kyasanur forest disease, babesiosis, tick paralysis. Ixodes type transmits Lyme disease. Soft tick is a reservoir for Q fever and a vector for relapsing fever.
Life span Short Longer
Habits Always found on their hosts. They hide in cracks and crevices during the day and come out to feed during the night.
  • Insecticidal control of ticks includes DDT, chlordane, dieldrin, lindane, malathion, and toxaphene. Environmental control and protection of workers must also be done to prevent disease transmission from ticks.

questions.text: Which of the following is the sensitive indicator of environmental iodine deficiency?
questions.solution:
Neonatal hypothyroidism is a sensitive indicator of environmental iodine deficiency and can also be an effective indicator for monitoring the impact of a programme.

Urinary excretion of iodine is used for surveillance and epidemiological studies for classifying countries according to the level of iodine deficiency by the WHO and is an effective indicator of the programme against iodine deficiency.

questions.solution:
According to Caldwell and Moloy's classification of the pelvis, convergent sidewalls are associated with the android pelvis.

The female pelvis can be divided into 4 types based on the pelvic inlet's shape as follows:

  • Gynecoid

questions.text: A young male sprint runner sustained a large wound over the right thigh while practicing.  The doctor decided to cover the wound with a graft obtained from the left thigh by using the instrument shown below. What type of graft is being placed on the wound?
questions.solution:
The image above shows  Humby's knife with an Eschmann blade that is used to obtain the Thiersch graft. The graft is a type of partial-thickness/split-thickness skin graft. 

Grafts are tissues that are transferred without their blood supply and will revascularize after being engrafted to a new site.

The different types of grafts are:

  • Thiersch grafts/split-thickness skin grafts consist of the epidermis and a portion of the dermis. The donor area is commonly the thigh, and Humby's knife is used to take the graft. The process is shown below:
  • Full-thickness skin grafts, otherwise known as Wolfe grafts include the epidermis and entire dermis, with portions of the sweat glands, sebaceous glands, and hair follicles. Wolfe grafts have high durability and the least amount of secondary contraction. It is used in reconstructing superficial hand and facial wounds. 
  • Composite grafts are grafts that contain tissues besides skin. It can include subcutaneous fat, cartilage, small amounts of muscle, etc. It is indicated in small areas requiring specialized tissues such as nasal reconstruction.

Related Pearl: Skin Grafting : Phases of Graft Uptake

Skin graft uptake occurs in three phases:

  1. Imbibition (Plasmatic circulation): During the first 48 hours, the graft is nourished with plasma exudate from the host bed capillaries.
  2. Inosculation: Cut vessels from the host bed line up with the cut ends of the vessels of the graft to form anastomoses.
  3. Neovascularization: Blood vessels grow from the recipient bed into the graft.

Sensations return to the graft over time, with reinnervation beginning at approximately 4 to 5 weeks and being completed by 12 to 24 months. Pain returns first, followed by light touch and temperature returning later.

Note: Some books give that the 3 phases are imbibition, revascularisation (inosculation+neovascularisation) and organisation (fibrin layer holds the graft in place and this is replaced with fibroblasts by day 7).

questions.text: Which of the following passes through the structure marked A?
questions.solution:
The structure marked A is the aortic hiatus of the diaphragm. Among the given options, the hemi-azygous vein passes through the aortic hiatus of the diaphragm.

The diaphragm is a domed musculofibrous sheet that separates the thoracic and abdominopelvic cavities.

The image given below shows the inferior view of the diaphragm.

The important openings in the diaphragm and structures that pass through them are given in the table below:

Opening/aperture Structures passing through them 
Aortic hiatus
  • Aorta
  • Thoracic duct
  • Lymphatic trunks from the lower posterior thoracic wall
  • Azygos and hemi-azygos veins
Oesophageal hiatus  
  • Esophagus
  • Vagal trunks
  • Gastric nerves
  • Esophageal branches of the left gastric vessels
  • Lymphatic vessels
Caval opening
  • Inferior vena cava
  • Right phrenic nerve
Lesser apertures Greater and lesser splanchnic nerves

The diaphragm is supplied by the phrenic nerve whose root values are C3, C4, and C5. The phrenic nerve is responsible for the referred pain. Diaphragmatic pain is frequently felt at the tip of the shoulder due to the common root of origin of the phrenic nerve and the nerves supplying the shoulder.

Referred pain usually occurs when there is inflammation of the diaphragmatic pleura, e.g. in basal pneumonia, pleural effusions, or with irritation of the peritoneal pleura, as with a subphrenic abscess.

Note: The left phrenic nerve descends anterior to the pericardial sac of the left ventricle and terminates at the central tendon of the diaphragm. The left phrenic nerve innervates the left diaphragmatic dome, and the right phrenic nerve innervates the right diaphragmatic dome, with the majority of nerve branching occurring on the inferior aspect of the diaphragm.

The hemizygous vein may sometimes pass through the left crus of the diaphragm.

questions.text: What is the gross motor milestone that would have attained by a normal child who is capable of holding the block as given in the image?
questions.solution:
The milestone shown in the image is mature pincer grasp, which is seen at the age of 12 months. The child walks but falls at this age.

Developmental progression of the grasp:

  • At 6 months, the infant reaches and holds a larger object in a crude manner using the ulnar aspect of his hand (Ulnar palmar grasp). At 8-9 months, the object is grasped by the radial side of the palm (radial palmar grasp).
  • At 9 months, the immature pincer grasp develops. The object is secured between the adducted thumb and the extended index finger.
  • At 12 months, the mature pincer grasp develops. The object is secured between the opposed thumb and the tip of the index finger.

Other options:

  • Walks without support, Creeps upstairs: 15 months
  • Runs: 18 months

Hopping on 1 foot

questions.text: A 14-year-old male patient presented with painful swelling below the knee joint. On examination, there is localized tenderness over the tibial tuberosity. The X-ray image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The X-ray image shows a traction injury of the tibial tuberosity, at the site where the patellar tendon is inserted, which is characteristic of Osgood-Schlatter Disease, also known as apophysitis of the tibial tuberosity.

The condition is usually seen in young adolescents and may not be associated with any injury.

The presenting feature is a painful lump below the knee joint. On examination, the lump is tender and its situation over the tibial tuberosity is diagnostic of the disease.

Other options:

Option a: Jumper’s knee, also known as patellar tendinitis is an inflammation of the proximal patellar tendon, which occurs due to overuse injury and is usually seen in athletes.

Option c: Sinding-Larsen-Johansson Syndrome is seen where there is a partial rupture or avulsion of the distal patellar tendon, where it inserts into the patella, leading to traction tendonitis and calcification in the patellar ligament.

Option d: Osteochondritis Dissecans is a condition characterized by demarcation or separation and necrosis of a part of articular cartilage and bone. The condition is often associated with intra-articular loose bodies.

Related Pearl: Diseases and Usual Joints affected

Disease Joint
Gout MTP of great toe
Pseudogout Knee

Ankylosing spondylitis Sacro-iliac joint

Paget's disease
 Pelvis > Femur >Skull >Tibia
Osteochondritis dissecans Knee >Elbow
(Most common cause of loose bodies in young)
Actinomycosis Mandible

Acute osteomyelitis Lower end of femur(Metaphysis)
Brodie's abscess Upper end of tibia

questions.text:
A 50-year-old male with a history of myocardial infarction two months back has been planned for elective cholecystectomy because of cholelithiasis. During his preoperative evaluation, he has an ejection fraction of 40%. The following image shows an assessment of his airway. He would be classified as_________

ASA PS- American Society of Anesthesiologists’ Physical Status
questions.solution:
This patient, who is about to undergo an elective cholecystectomy can be classified as ASA PS 4 with an airway assessment grade 3 as per Mallampati classification.

He has a recent history of MI two months back and severe reduction in ejection fraction (40%), which together puts the patient under Physical Status 4 as per American Society of Anaesthesiologist classification of patients.

In the given image of airway assessment, only the base of the uvula, soft palate, and the hard palate can be seen. Hence, grade 3 as per the modified Mallampati classification given by Samsoon and Young.

Related Pearl: American Society of Anesthesiologists’ Physical Status Classification of Patients

American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status (ASA-PS) classification is used to define relative risk before conscious sedation and surgical anaesthesia and strongly correlates to perioperative risk.

ASA-PS Classification:

Class Definition Examples, including, but not limited to:
I A normal healthy patient Healthy, non-smoking, no or minimal alcohol use
II A patient with mild systemic disease Current smoker, well-controlled DM and HTN
III A patient with severe systemic disease Poorly controlled DM or HTN, history (>3 months) of MI, CVA, TIA, or CAD or stents.
IV A patient with severe systemic disease that is a constant threat to life Recent (< 3 months) MI, CVA, TIA, or CAD/stents
V A moribund patient who is not expected to survive without the operation Ruptured abdominal, thoracic aneurysm, massive trauma, intracranial bleed with mass effect
VI A declared brain-dead patient whose organs are being removed for donor purposes  

Related Pearl: Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification

Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification is used to predict the ease of endotracheal intubation.

• Class I: The entire palatal arch, including the bilateral faucial pillars, is visible down to the bases of the pillars.
• Class II: The upper part of the faucial pillars and most of the uvula are visible.
• Class III: Only the soft and hard palates are visible.
• Class IV: Only the hard palate is visible.

Initially, the Mallampatti scoring system (1985) had only 3 classes. This was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class 4. Later class 0 was also added.

questions.text: An endoscopic biopsy of the stomach was done in a patient with a history of peptic ulcer.  The histopathology of the biopsy is stained with a special stain and shown in the image. What is the special stain used and the type of gastritis caused by it?

choices.text: Warthin starry silver stain and type A gastritis
Warthin starry silver stain and type B gastritis
Masson Fontana stain and type A gastritis
Masson Fontana stain and type B gastritis

questions.solution:
The histopathology of the biopsy is stained with a Warthin starry silver stain and shows Helicobacter pylori.  Type B gastritis is associated with Helicobacter pylori infection. It affects the antrum.

Type B gastritis

  • Type B gastritis is associated with H. pylori.
  • It commonly affects the antrum.
  • Intestinal metaplasia is associated with chronic pan-gastritis with atrophy.
  • Intestinal metaplasia with dysplasia has malignant potential.

Type A gastritis: Remember the 4A's associated with type A gastritis:

  • Autoimmune condition: Has circulating antibodies to parietal cells
  • Atrophy of parietal cell mass
  • Achlorhydria: causes chronic hypergastrinemia and microadenomas of enterochromaffin-like (ECL) cells
  • Anemia: leads to pernicious anemia, due to malabsorption of Vit B12 (as the intrinsic factor is also produced by parietal cells)

questions.text: A 45-year-old man diagnosed with hyperlipoproteinemia due to deficiency of lipoprotein lipase was following strict restriction of fat intake in his diet. While enjoying the get-together party with his childhood friends, he accidentally consumes fatty meal. Which of the following lipoproteins will be elevated in this case?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, After a fatty meal, chylomicrons are elevated in lipoprotein lipase deficiency.

Chylomicrons transport dietary lipids from the intestine to the peripheral tissues. They are synthesized in the intestine by assembling apo B-48 with lipids (mainly triacylglycerols).

This is called a nascent chylomicron which upon receiving apo C-II and apo E from HDL is remodeled into mature chylomicron.

Apo C-II activates lipoprotein lipase present on the endothelium. Lipoprotein lipase hydrolyzes the triacylglycerols into fatty acids and glycerol which are either used for storage or energy.

Clinical correlate: Patients with lipoprotein lipase or apo C-II deficiency (type I hyperlipoproteinemia) hence show increased levels of chylomicrons in the plasma, after a fatty meal.

Related Pearl: Familial Dyslipidemias

Type Increased levels  Manifestation
1. Hyperchylomicronemia(type I hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons, VLDL, TG  Pancreatitis, hepatosplenomegaly, and xanthomas
2. Familial hypercholesterolemia(type II hyperlipoproteinemia) LDL and cholesterol Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
3. Dysbetalipoproteinemia(type III hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons and VLDL Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
4. Hypertriglyceridemia(type IV hyperlipoproteinemia) VLDL and TG Pancreatitis

questions.text: A 30-year-old male has been tested positive for SARS-COV-2. His household contacts are screened for the same, despite the absence of symptoms. What is the level of prevention employed here?
questions.solution:
Screening is a type of secondary prevention.

It is done to detect the disease in its early stages. Secondary prevention includes early disease detection, and its target is healthy-appearing individuals with subclinical forms of the disease. This is defined as the action which halts the progress of the disease at its incipient stage before it becomes clinically apparent and prevents complications. Screening tests and early diagnosis are the specific intervention used in the secondary level of prevention and they help to arrest the disease process.

Related Pearl: Lead Time in Screening

Lead time is the period between the first possible time of detection and the usual time of diagnosis.

Lead time is the advantage gained by screening. It helps in the early diagnosis and treatment of disease. Early treatment reduces the severity by reversing the disease process.

Soften the impact of long-term disease and disability, minimize suffering

questions.text: A 40-year-old male came to the hospital with complaints of severe dyspepsia and was advised to get upper gastrointestinal endoscopy done. During endoscopy, there was a protruded polypoid mass from the stomach, and biopsy from the same is suggestive of adenocarcinoma. What Borrmann's classification does this belong to?
questions.solution:
Gastric cancer having a macroscopic appearance of protruded polypoid type is classified under Type I in the Borrmann’s classification system.

Type II, Type III, and Type IV are depressed type in Borrmann’s classification of gastric cancer.

 

Related Pearl: Borrmann’s classification of stomach cancer

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought with abdominal swelling. On examination, a mass is palpable in the right upper quadrant.  Laboratory evaluation shows serum alpha-fetoprotein level of 1,50,000 ng/mL. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and elevated serum alpha-fetoprotein level are suggestive of hepatoblastoma.

Hepatoblastoma is the most common malignant liver tumor of early childhood, usually < 3 years. Serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is the most important clinical marker for hepatoblastoma. It remains the key clinical marker of malignant change, response to the treatment, and relapse.

Histological section of hepatoblastoma showing proliferating hepatoblasts consisting of round epithelial type cells is given below.

questions.text: A 28-year-old obese female with a history of irregular cycles is under evaluation for primary infertility. Labs reveal elevated levels of free testosterone. Her pelvic ultrasound findings are as given in the image given below. The measured ovarian volume is 12 cm³. Which of the following is used as the first-line treatment for ovulation induction in this patient?
questions.solution:
Letrozole is used as first-line therapy for ovulation induction in this patient with PCOS.

Ultrasound showing multiple cysts and an increased ovarian volume (>10cm³) in an obese female with irregular cycles and primary infertility,  strongly suggests that the cause of her primary infertility is PCOS (polycystic ovarian syndrome). Letrozole would be the preferred agent here.

Aromatase inhibitors like letrozole should be considered as first-line therapy for ovulation induction because of the increased live birth rate (27.5%) compared with clomiphene citrate (10.1%).

If prescribing letrozole, the starting dosage is 2.5 mg/day for 5 days typically starting on day 3, 4, or 5 after a spontaneous menses or progestin-induced bleed. If ovulation does not occur, the dosage can be increased to 5 mg/day for 5 days with a maximum dosage of 7.5 mg/day. 

Other options:

Clomiphene citrate has traditionally been the first-line treatment agent for anovulatory women, including those with PCOS. Dexamethasone as adjunctive therapy with clomiphene citrate has been shown to increase ovulation and pregnancy rates in clomiphene citrate-resistant women with PCOS

Gonadotropins are frequently used to induce ovulation in women with PCOS for whom clomiphene citrate treatment has failed.

Laparoscopic ovarian drilling is primarily recommended as second-line therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of Asperger's syndrome?

choices.text: More common in boys than girls
Diagnosis is usually after 3 years of age

questions.solution:
Patients with Asperger's syndrome have no delay in language development.

Asperger's syndrome is an autistic spectrum disorder characterized by a wide range of impairments in social communication and restricted and repetitive behaviors.

Features of Asperger's disorder include:

  • Impairment in social interaction and development:
    • markedly abnormal nonverbal communicative gestures
    • failure to develop peer relationships at the expected level
  • Restricted interests and patterns of behavior
  • No significant delay in language, clinically significant cognitive delay, or adaptive impairment
  • Intellectual disability is not seen, IQ is normal.
  • Delayed clinical diagnosis, often at age 11 or even later

Related Pearl: Autism Spectrum Disorder

questions.text: The type of taste evoked by monosodium glutamate is sensed via which type of receptor?
questions.solution:
The type of taste evoked by monosodium glutamate is Umami. Umami tastes are sensed by the activation of G-protein coupled receptors.

Taste Receptors: Humans have five established basic tastes: sweet, salt, sour, bitter, and umami. The taste receptors for these five basic tastes are of two major types:

  • Ligand-gated channels (ionotropic receptors): Salt and sour taste are mediated through epithelial sodium channels (ENaC)
    • Na+ movement through ENaC →salt taste
    • H+ movement through ENaC → sour taste
  • G-Protein Coupled Receptors (metabotropic receptors): Sweet, bitter, and umami are sensed via GPCRs
    • T1R2, T1R3 families→ sweet taste
    • T2R family → bitter taste
    • Metabotropic glutamate receptor (mGluR4) or T1R1, T1R3 families → Umami

L-glutamate was identified as having a unique taste, that cannot be categorized as bitter, sweet, salty, and sour. Therefore, it was called umami, with the Japanese word "umai" meaning "delicious". Ribonucleotides such as inosine 5′-monophosphate (IMP) and guanosine-5'-monophosphate (GMP), elicit umami taste on their own. It wasn't until the identification of G protein-coupled receptors specific for glutamate taste, that umami was completely accepted as a unique taste.

Related Pearl: Taste sensations and their mediators

Taste Sensations Mediated by
Salt Na+ movement in ENaC
Sweet G-protein coupled receptors (GPCRs) T1R family
Umami Glutamate receptor family (mGluR4) and G-protein coulped receptors (GPCRs) T1R family
Bitter G-protein coupled receptors (GPCRs) T2R family
Sour H+ movement through ENaC

questions.text: In which model of health education does internalization occur?
questions.solution:
Internalization belongs to the motivation model.

There are three models of health education:

  • Medical model: transfer of proven medical information into education. It does not bridge the gap between knowledge and behavior.
  • Motivation model: creates awareness of health needs and problems. Awareness leads to motivation which includes stages of interest, evaluation, and decision-making. It is followed by acceptance of the new idea which becomes part of his existing values, known as internalization.
  • Social intervention model: focuses on changing the social environment which subsequently shapes the behavior of individual and the community.

questions.text: Which among the following structures forms the level one support according to DeLancey's levels of support of genital organs?
questions.solution:
The uterosacral ligament forms the level one support  according to DeLancey's levels of support of genital organs.
