questions.text: Which among the following is an intravenous iron preparation?
questions.solution:
Ferrous sucrose or iron sucrose is an IV preparation of parenteral iron.

  • Iron sucrose is the most commonly used preparation for IV infusion
  • Safe with fewer adverse events – adverse effects are virtually unknown
  • Does not require a test dose

Other options:

Option A. Ferrous ascorbate – Oral preparation

Option B. Iron sorbitol – IM preparation

Option D. Iron polymaltose – IM preparation

Other preparations of iron :

  • Iron dextran - Both IM and IV
  • Ferric carboxymaltose - IV

questions.text: How would you describe the lesion seen in the image?
questions.solution:
The lesion in the given image can be described as poikiloderma, as it has the following features

  • Skin atrophy
  • Hypo- and hyperpigmentation
  • Telangiectasia

The following clinical conditions have been included under poikiloderma syndromes

  • Dyskeratosis congenita
  • Rothmund-Thomson syndrome
  • Poikiloderma with neutropenia, Clericuzio type
  • Acrokeratotic poikiloderma of Weary

Related Pearl: Glossary of important skin lesions

Glossary of Important Skin Lesions

Lesion

Description

Alopecia

Absence of hair from a normally hairy area

Aphtha

A small ulcer of the mucosa

Atrophy

Loss of tissue from one or more of the epidermis, dermis or subcutaneous tissues

Burrow

A small tunnel in the skin that houses a parasite, such as the scabies acarus

Callus

A localized hyperplasia of the stratum corneum

Cellulitis

An inflammation of cellular tissue, particularly purulent inflammation of the deep dermis and subcutaneous tissue

Comedo

A plug of keratin and sebum in a dilated pilosebaceous orifice

Crusts (scabs)

Crusts consist of dried serum and other exudates

Cyst

Any closed cavity or sac (normal or abnormal) with an epithelial, endothelial or membranous lining and containing fluid or semi‐solid material

Ecchymosis

A macular area of hemorrhage more than 1 cm (bruise) in diameter

Erosion

A loss of epidermis, which heals without scarring. It commonly follows a blister.

Erythema

Redness of the skin produced by vascular congestion or increased perfusion

Excoriation

Loss of skin substance, specifically produced by scratching

Exfoliation

The splitting off of the epidermal keratin in scales or sheets

Fibrosis

The formation of excessive fibrous tissue

Fissure

Any linear gap or slit in the skin surface

Fistula

An abnormal passage from a deep structure, such as a hollow viscus, to the skin surface or between two structures

Gangrene

Death of tissue, usually due to loss of blood supply

Guttate lesions

Small round or oval lesions distributed as a ‘shower’ of droplets. Usually applied to a form of psoriasis

Hematoma

A localized tumor‐like collection of blood

Keratoderma

A horny thickening of the skin

Lichenification

Thickening of the epidermis (and to some extent also of the dermis) in response to prolonged rubbing

Macule

A flat circumscribed, non‐palpable lesion that differs in color from the surrounding skin. It can be of any color or shape. A macule is <1 cm in diameter, larger lesions are a patch.

Maculopapular

Rash consisting of both macules and papules

Milium

A tiny white cyst containing lamellated keratin

Nodule*

A solid palpable lesion in the dermis or subcutis, which can be observed as an elevation or can be palpated. It is >0.5 cm in diameter.

Papule

An elevated solid lesion that is <1 cm in diameter.

Petechia

A punctate hemorrhagic spot, approximately 1–2 mm in diameter.

Plaque

An elevated circumscribed lesion >1 cm diameter; its surface is usually flat. Plaques may form from coalesced papules.

Poikiloderma

The association of cutaneous pigmentation, and telangiectasia.

Pustule

A circumscribed lesion that contains purulent material. 

Pyoderma

Any purulent skin disease

Scale

Scale is a flat plate or flake-like lesion desquamated of stratum corneum.

Scar

Replacement by fibrous tissue of another tissue that has been destroyed by injury or disease

An atrophic scar is thin and wrinkled.

A hypertrophic scar is elevated, with excessive growth of fibrous tissue.

Sclerosis

Diffuse or circumscribed induration of the subcutaneous tissues. It may also involve the dermis, when the overlying epidermis may be atrophic. It is characteristically seen in scleroderma.

Sinus

A cavity or track with a blind ending

Target lesions

These are <3 cm in diameter and have three or more zones, usually a central area of dusky erythema or purpura, a middle paler zone of edema, and an outer ring of erythema with a well‐defined edge.

Tumor

Literally a swelling; the term is used to imply enlargement of the tissues by normal or pathological material, or cells that form a mass. 

Ulcer (of skin)

A loss of dermis and epidermis, often with loss of the underlying tissues
Vesicles and Bullae

 A vesicle is a circumscribed elevation <1 cm in diameter that contains fluid

Bullae are >1 cm in diameter
Wheal  A transient elevation of the skin due to dermal and hypodermal, often pale centrally with an erythematous rim; it is the characteristic lesion of urticaria.

 *While Rook's textbook of Dermatology,9th edition mention nodule as >0.5 cm. Some authors define nodules as >1 cm.

questions.text: What is the main use of the instrument seen in the image?

choices.text: Reduction of the fracture of nasal septum
Reduction of the fracture of nasal bone
Punching out bone in DCR procedure

questions.solution:
The instrument seen in the image is Walsham forceps. It is is mainly used to reduce nasal bone fracture.

Asch forceps is mainly used to reduce fracture of the nasal septum.

questions.text: Which of the following is the first paranasal sinus to start developing in the body?
questions.solution:
The maxillary sinus is the first sinus to start developing in our body.

 The frontal sinus develops until early adulthood.

The sphenoid sinus is the last sinus to develop.

The ethmoid sinuses are present at birth and will attain their adult size by the early teens.

questions.text: A 29-year-old G2P1 comes to the physician at 36 weeks of gestation. At 28 weeks, she was diagnosed with gestational diabetes. She was unable to maintain her blood sugar levels with a diabetic diet and was planned to start on insulin. Which of the following is not true regarding the management of this patient?

choices.text: Insulin is the drug of choice for gestational diabetes mellitus
Insulin is started when  post prandial 2 hour blood glucose > 120 mg/dl
Insulin must be continued after the delivery
Insulin does not cross the placenta

questions.solution:
A patient of gestational diabetes mellitus is at an increased risk for developing overt diabetes and should undergo a glucose tolerance test at 6 weeks postpartum to determine further management (like insulin requirement).

Fifty percent of women with gestational diabetes develop overt diabetes within 20 years. Hence, they are recommended to undergo screening & revaluation between 4-12 weeks postpartum.

To start oral hypoglycemic or subcutaneous insulin directly would be incorrect as they may not have diabetes.

Insulin is the drug of choice for the treatment of gestational diabetes mellitus. It does not cross the placenta and tight glycemic control can typically be achieved.

Insulin therapy is started if :

  • fasting levels persistently exceed 95 mg/ dL in women with gestational diabetes
  • women with 1-hour postprandial levels that persistently exceed 140 mg/dL or
  • women with 2-hour postprandial levels > 120 mg/dL.

The starting dose is typically 0.7 to 1 units/kg/d and is given in divided doses. A combination of intermediate-acting and short -acting insulin may be used.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is alirocumab approved for use?

choices.text: Cystic fibrosis patients >12 years of age

questions.solution:
Alirocumab is a PCSK9 inhibitor that is approved for use in familial hypercholesterolemia.

PCSK9 inhibitors are a new class of lipid-lowering medications that are administered as monthly or bimonthly subcutaneous injections. PCSK9 is a binding protein that is expressed in hepatocytes and on secretion, binds to the LDL receptors, and promotes their degradation. By blocking PCSK9, these drugs increase the availability of LDL receptors leading to better removal of LDL cholesterol from circulation. Another approved PCSK-9 inhibitor is evolocumab.

Other options: 

Option B: Fremanezumab and galcanezumab are anti-CGRP monoclonal antibodies approved by the FDA in 2018 for the preventive treatment of migraine in adults.

Option C: Tezacaftor/Ivacaftor is FDA approved for cystic fibrosis patients >12 years of age. It facilitates the opening of chloride channels.

Option D: Plecanatide is FDA-approved for the treatment of chronic idiopathic constipation. It activates guanylate cyclase-C on endothelial cells in the GI tract and thus draws water into the lumen, leading to stool softening.

questions.text:
A diabetic woman who did not respond well to metformin therapy was started on dapagliflozin. Which of the following is not true about this drug?

SGLT2 - Sodium-glucose cotransporter - 2

choices.text: It increases risk of urinary tract infections
It acts by inhibiting SGLT-2 transporter on distal convoluted tubule
It increases the risk of fractures

questions.solution:
Dapagliflozin acts by inhibiting the SGLT2 transporter present on the proximal segment of the renal tubule. SGLT2 transporter is present on the proximal segment of the renal tubule and not in the distal convoluted tubule.

The SGLT2 transporter present in the proximal segment of the renal tubule is responsible for the reabsorption of 80-90% of filtered glucose. Dapagliflozin acts by inhibiting this transporter resulting in glycosuria and decreasing the blood glucose level. This drug is effective orally. This drug also results in weight loss.

Dapagliflozin has been approved by the FDA for the treatment of heart failure in both diabetic and non-diabetic patients.

The common side effects of dapagliflozin include urinary tract infections, genital mycotic infections due to the high glucose content of the urine, and also increased risk of fractures.

Other SGLT2 inhibitors include empagliflozin, canagliflozin, and ertugliflozin.

Empagliflozin has been found to decrease the risk of mortality from cardiovascular causes in diabetic patients.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient was brought to the emergency department with complaints of severe headache, vomiting, and progressive weakness of the right upper and lower limb weakness. A CT image of the patient is shown. Which of the following drugs is best suited to reduce morbidity in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the patient presenting with complaints of headache, vomiting, and paralysis and the CT image showing blood in the cistern is suggestive of subarachnoid haemorrhage (SAH) where nimodipine is best suited to reduce morbidity.

Subarachnoid hemorrhage is the hemorrhage in the subarachnoid space between the arachnoid and pia mater, mixed with CSF.

After head trauma, it is mostly caused as a result of the rupture of a saccular aneurysm. Other causes include bleeding from a vascular malformation such as arteriovenous malformation or dural arteriovenous fistula and an intracerebral hemorrhage extending into the subarachnoid space.

Some SAHs may be limited to the perimesencephalic cisterns and is arterial in origin but there could be a venous or capillary source. Manifesting features are due to raised intracranial pressure.

Nimodipine is indicated to relieve a neurological deficit occurring secondary to cerebral vasospasm following subarachnoid haemorrhage. It is a member of the dihydropyridine group of calcium channel blockers and causes vasodilation in cerebral blood vessels. It is lipid-soluble and has a high affinity for cerebral blood vessels and appears to reduce morbidity after subarachnoid haemorrhage.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with mood lability, sadness, and tearfulness 5 days after delivery. She has no thoughts of harming the baby. There is no history of previous mood disorders. There is no family history of mood disorders. What is the preferred treatment for her?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of postpartum blues and the preferred treatment is supportive therapy.

Mild depressive symptoms after a few days of delivery which resolve spontaneously are characteristic of postpartum blues.

During this period the patient may experience mood lability, sadness, dysphoria, subjective confusion, and tearfulness. These feelings have been ascribed to rapid changes in women's hormonal levels, the stress of childbirth, and the awareness of the increased responsibility that motherhood brings. This usually resolves spontaneously. 

If the symptoms persist longer than two weeks, evaluation is indicated for postpartum depression.

Related Pearl: Postpartum mood disorders

Disorders and features Incidence and timeline Harmful thoughts Treatment

Postpartum blues:

Depressed affect, tearfulness and fatigue

30-75%

Starts 2-3 days after delivery. Resolves within 10 days.

 No thoughts of harming the baby Support and follow up

Postpartum depression:

Depressed affect, anxiety, and poor concentration

10-15%

Starts within 4 weeks from delivery (DSM 5) or 6 weeks (ICD 11) and persists for ≥ 2 weeks. 

 Thoughts of harming the baby often present CBT and SSRIs 

Postpartum psychosis:

Mood-congruent delusions, hallucinations

0.1-0.2%

Onset within 4 weeks postpartum (DSM 5) or 6 weeks (ICD 11)

 Thoughts of harming the baby or self Hospitalization, atypical antipsychotics and ECT for refractory cases

Note: Zuranolone is the first-ever oral drug to be FDA-approved specifically for the treatment of postpartum depression. It is a neuroactive steroid that enhances the action of GABA in the brain and regulates mood.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is caused by trinucleotide-repeat mutations in the coding region of the gene?
questions.solution:
Huntington's disease (HD) is caused by trinucleotide-repeat mutations (CAG) in the coding region of the gene.

HD is an autosomal dominant condition occurring due to the degeneration of striatal neurons. Patients typically present with progressive chorea, that is, jerky, hyperkinetic, dystonic movements involving all parts of the body, and dementia. They may also develop bradykinesia and rigidity. A direct relationship exists between the degree of striatal degeneration and the severity of clinical symptoms.

The caudate nucleus and putamen are atrophied, and the lateral and third ventricles are dilated. The frontal lobe is also frequently atrophied. On microscopy, loss of striatal neurons is most marked in the caudate nucleus. Intranuclear inclusions of the defective protein huntingtin can be seen in striatal and cerebral cortex neurons.

HD is a progressive and fatal disease, with a clinical course of 15 years and no effective therapy. The most common cause of death is pneumonia, occurring in advanced stages.

Other diseases that affect the coding region of the gene include:

  • Spinobulbar muscular atrophy (Kennedy disease)
  • Spinocerebellar ataxias
  • Dentatorubral-pallidoluysian atrophy (Haw–River syndrome)

Other options:

Options B, C, and D: Myotonic dystrophy, Friedreich ataxia, and Fragile X syndrome are disorders caused by trinucleotide-repeat mutations in the non coding region of the gene.

questions.text: A patient with calcium oxalate monohydrate crystals in the urine is diagnosed with ethylene glycol poisoning. What is the drug of choice for treating this condition?
questions.solution:
Fomepizole is the drug of choice for the treatment of ethylene glycol poisoning.

Treatment of ethylene glycol poisoning:

  • Fomepizole (preferred) or ethanol (if fomepizole is unavailable) - inhibits the enzyme alcohol dehydrogenase
  • Sodium bicarbonate - correct systemic acidosis
  • Hemodialysis - for elevated toxic alcohol levels, severe acid-base derangements, or evidence of end-organ toxicity
  • Co-factors (folic acid, thiamine, and pyridoxine) - optimizes non-toxic metabolic pathways for the elimination of parent alcohol or its metabolites

questions.text: A patient who is on treatment for angina, presents to you with erectile dysfunction. You decide against prescribing sildenafil because the patient is being treated with _____
questions.solution:
The patient would be on nitrates for angina and thus should not be prescribed sildenafil as sildenafil causes dangerous potentiation of nitrate action resulting in severe hypotension.

The combination of the two drugs has a synergistic action on the intracellular cGMP levels that can result in uninhibited vasodilation and a precipitous fall in blood pressure. Hence, the use of sildenafil is a contraindication when on nitrates.

questions.text: A 22-year-old presented with pain and stiffness in the neck following a blow with a hockey stick. On examination, the right shoulder is drooping. Which of the following muscles is likely to be paralyzed?
questions.solution:
The drooping of the shoulder is due to the paralysis of the trapezius muscle.

The trapezius is innervated by the spinal accessory nerve (CN XI). It causes: 

  • Retraction of scapula
  • Shrugging of the shoulder
  • Overhead abduction (along with serratus anterior)

Paralysis of the trapezius causes drooping of the shoulder and slight winging of the scapula (the superior angle of the scapula becomes more prominent).

questions.text: A 26-year-old athlete underwent a LASIK procedure. His intraocular pressure was measured using this instrument. What is the name of the instrument?
questions.solution:
The above given instrument is Pascal tonometer.

This is a dynamic contour tonometer. Intraocular pressure (IOP) readings are not affected by central corneal thickness. Pascal is the tonometer of choice for post LASIK corneas.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with chest pain and breathlessness which is more on lying down and relieved on sitting upright. On examination, heart sounds are muffled. His chest X-ray is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and X-ray appearance of the money bag heart is suggestive of pericardial effusion.

Plain PA chest X-ray shows an enlarged cardiac silhouette. There is effacement of the normal cardiac borders, development of a flask or water bottle cardiac configuration, and bilateral hilar overlay which are features of pericardial effusion. It is also known as money bag or leather bottle-shaped heart.

Pericardial effusions occur when excess fluid collects in the pericardial space (a normal pericardial sac contains approximately 15-50 mL of fluid).

Investigation of choice: Echocardiography.

Signs on plain radiograph include:

  • Globular enlargement of the cardiac shadow giving a water bottle configuration.
  • Lateral CXR may show a vertical opaque line (pericardial fluid) separating a vertical lucent line directly behind the sternum (paracardial fat) anteriorly from a similar lucent vertical lucent line (epicardial fat) posteriorly; this is known as the Oreo cookie sign.

questions.text: Which of the following is a non-enveloped DNA virus?
questions.solution:
Adenovirus is a non-enveloped DNA virus. The DNA is double-stranded.

Adenovirus has a unique shape. The capsid has capsomeres arranged as an icosahedron, with rod-like projections having knobs at the tips. This gives adenovirus the appearance of a space vehicle.

They infect humans, animals, and birds, showing strict host specificity. Adenovirus infections are common worldwide, mostly in children. Many infections are asymptomatic. The virus may persist in the host for many months. They cause infections of the respiratory tract and eyes, and less often of the intestine and urinary tract.

Common syndromes associated with adenovirus infection: 
 
Syndrome Principal serotypes
Respiratory disease in children 1, 2, 5, 6
Sore throat, febrile cold, pneumonia  3, 4, 7, 14, 21 
Acute respiratory diseases in military recruits 4, 7, 21
Follicular (swimming pool) conjunctivitis 3, 7
Epidemic keratoconjunctivitis (shipyard eye) 8, 19, 37
Diarrhea 40, 41

Acute hemorrhagic cystitis (in children)

 11, 21

questions.text: During ward rounds, you come across four patients who have sudden onset chest pain and breathlessness. All of them have a modified Well's score of 4. Assuming they are under the age of 50 with stable vitals, in whom can you rule out pulmonary embolism?

choices.text: A woman with SpO2 96% on room air
A man who had a recent road traffic accident
A man with unilateral lower limb swelling

questions.solution:
You can rule out pulmonary embolism in a woman with SpO2 96% on room air using the pulmonary embolism rule-out criteria (PERC).

The PERC, as the name suggests is a tool that includes 8 clinical criteria, which can be used to rule out pulmonary embolism in patients. A modified Well's score of ≤4 is a prerequisite for the application of this criteria. The criteria include:

  • Age < 50 years
  • Heart rate < 100 beats per minute
  • SpO2 on room air ≥95%
  • No history of venous thromboembolism
  • No recent (within 4 weeks) injury or surgery requiring hospitalization
  • No hemoptysis
  • No estrogen therapy
  • No one-sided leg swelling

Patients who meet all the above criteria can be monitored off anticoagulation and needs to be assessed for alternative diagnoses as pulmonary embolism (PE) can be ruled out.

Patients with PE present with unexplained breathlessness, syncope, hypotension, and cyanosis.

Well's criteria is used as follows to assess the likelihood of developing pulmonary embolism.

Criteria along with the score is given below:

  • Signs and symptoms of deep vein thrombosis (DVT): 3
  • Alternative diagnosis is less likely: 3
  • Heart rate > 100/minute: 1.5
  • Surgery in previous 4 weeks, immobilization for more than 3 days: 1.5
  • Previous PE or DVT: 1.5
  • Hemoptysis: 1
  • Cancer: 1

According to modified Wells criteria:

  • PE likely if the score is >4
  • PE unlikely if the score is ≤4

According to Well's criteria (Three-tiered clinical probability assessment):

  • High risk >6
  • Moderate risk 2-6
  • Low risk <2

Other options:

All the other patients have features that do not fit into the PERC criteria and hence pulmonary embolism cannot be ruled out.

Related Pearl: Clinical prediction for pulmonary embolism: Well’s, Modified Well’s and Pulmonary Embolism Rule out Criteria (PERC)

Signs/symptoms Score
Clinical signs of DVT 3
Diagnosis other than pulmonary embolism is less likely 3
Heart rate >100 bpm 1.5
Immobilization for >3 days or surgery in the last 4 weeks 1.5
Past history of DVT/pulmonary embolism 1.5
Hemoptysis 1
Malignancy 1

Three-level score probability:

Well's criteria Score
Low <2
Moderate 2-6
High >6

Two-level score probability:

Modified Well's criteria Score
Pulmonary embolism unlikely ≤4
Pulmonary embolism likely >4 

 

Pulmonary embolism rule out criteria (PERC):

This is a quick OPD/casualty tool to rule out pulmonary embolism in patients with low clinical probability. It comprises eight clinical variables. If the patient meets all eight criteria, there is no need for further investigations. The variables include: 

  1. Age <50 years
  2. Heart rate <100 bpm
  3. SpO2 ≥95%
  4. No unilateral leg swelling
  5. No hemoptysis
  6. No recent trauma or surgery
  7. No history of venous thromboembolism
  8. No use of hormonal therapy.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old pregnant female patient complains of hearing loss, which is aggravated during pregnancy. Tympanometry shows As type of graph. Which of the following statements are true regarding the disease condition?
  1. The disease has an autosomal recessive mode of inheritance.
  2. Patients commonly present with bilateral sensory neural hearing loss.
  3. Fissula ante fenestrum is the most common site for the start of the lesion in a stapedial disease.
  4. Pure tone audiometry may reveal Carhart's notch.
  5. Medical treatment with sodium fluoride ear drops is generally avoided.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the tympanometry showing As type of graph are suggestive of otosclerosis. The correct statements regarding the disease include 3, 4, 5.

Otosclerosis is a primary disease of the bony labyrinth where foci of irregularly placed spongy bone replace part of the normally dense enchondral layer of the bony otic capsule.

It has an autosomal dominant (statement 1) inheritance and usually presents with bilateral progressive conductive hearing loss (statement 2). It is known to be initiated or worsened by stress and hormonal variations during pregnancy, trauma, surgery, and menopause. 

The most common type of otosclerosis is stapedial otosclerosis. Here lesion starts just in front of the oval window in an area called fissula ante fenestram (statement 3). The patients will have painless bilateral conductive hearing loss, tinnitus, and vertigo. 

An otosclerotic patient hears better in noisy than in quiet surroundings. This is because a normal person will raise his voice in noisy surroundings. This is called paracusis willisii.

On examination, the tympanic membrane may appear normal. In some patients, a reddish hue over the promontory may be visible through the tympanic membrane. This is called the Schwartze sign.

Tuning fork tests and audiometry will reveal the presence of conductive hearing loss. The bone conduction curve may show a dip, which is maximum at 2000Hz, known as Carhart’s notch (statement 4). Tympanogram will show the presence of As type of curve. As type of curve indicates that pressure is normal but compliance is reduced which is seen in otosclerosis.

Medical management with sodium fluoride has been tried to hasten the maturity of active focus and arrest further cochlear loss, but controversies exist and this treatment is not recommended generally (statement 5). Stapedectomy/stapedotomy with the placement of a prosthesis is the treatment of choice.

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

questions.text: A woman delivered a child who died a few minutes after birth. The infant was found to have blue sclera and fractures of the right humerus, ulna, and femur at birth. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of osteogenesis imperfecta type II.

The type II variant of osteogenesis imperfecta (OI) is uniformly fatal in utero or during the perinatal period. Type II OI is characterized by extraordinary bone fragility with multiple intrauterine fractures.

Osteogenesis imperfecta (brittle bone disease) is caused by deficiencies in the synthesis of type I collagen. It can be separated into four major clinical subtypes that vary widely in severity. The severity of the disease is based on the location of the mutation within the protein.

Individuals with type I OI have a normal life span, but experience childhood fractures that decrease in frequency following puberty.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy has severe excruciating pain in his right ear associated with fever. The tympanic membrane of the child appears as given below. The tympanic membrane would rupture in which of the following stages of the disease?
questions.solution:
The clinical symptoms and the appearance of the tympanic membrane are suggestive of acute otitis media. The tympanic membrane ruptures in the stage of resolution.

questions.text: You are performing the cranial nerve examination in a patient with a stroke. You noticed a loss of taste sensation in the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue. What is this sensation carried by?
questions.solution:
The taste sensation from the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue is carried by the special visceral afferent of the facial nerve via chorda tympani nerve.

The taste sensation from the hard and soft palate is also carried by the facial nerve via the greater superficial petrosal nerve to the nucleus tractus solitarius.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presented to the OPD with the following condition. what is the type of epithelium lining the ducts of the glands involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical image depicts rhinophyma or potato tumor, which is due to sebaceous glands hypertrophy. The ducts of the sebaceous glands are lined by stratified squamous keratinized epithelium.

Note: The ducts of sweat glands, salivary glands, and exocrine pancreas are lined by stratified cuboidal epithelium.

 

Related Pearl: Various Types of Epithelium, Their Location and Functions

questions.text: A 35-year-old presents with spastic paralysis of the lower limbs. Diet history reveals chronic consumption of Khesari dal before the onset of this paralysis. This condition is caused by which of the following toxic compounds?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with spastic paralysis and dietary history of consumption of Khesari dal is suggestive of lathyrism. This condition is caused by the toxic compound beta oxalyl amino alanine (BOAA).

Lathyrism is due to the consumption of Khesari dal/Lathyrus sativus. It is a paralyzing disease in humans and animals. In humans, it is referred to as neurolathyrism because it affects the nervous system and another variant is osteolathyrism causing skeletal deformities. A proper dietary history will reveal chronic consumption of this pulse in large quantities. Neurolathyrism is characterized by gradually developing spastic paralysis of the lower limbs. 

The water-soluble property of the toxin is used in removing it from the pulses, by soaking it in hot water and rejecting the soaked water. This method is called the steeping method. Parboiling can be done in large-scale operations. Vitamin C in doses of 500-1000mg can be used for the prevention and treatment of lathyrism.

Note- Aflatoxin is a metabolite produced by Aspergillus flavus and Aspergillus parasiticus. Aflatoxin toxicity presents with nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, convulsions, and signs of acute liver injury. Long-term exposure can result in growth retardation, cirrhosis, and hepatocellular carcinoma. 

Related Pearl: Food adulteration diseases

questions.text: Which IPC section deals with causing miscarriage with consent?
questions.solution:
IPC Section 312 deals with causing miscarriage with consent.

Doctor and Abortion:

IPC section

Section it deals with

312

Causing miscarriage with consent

313

Causing miscarriage without consent

314

Death of mother due to miscarriage

315

Preventing the child from being born alive or to cause it to die after birth

316

Causing the death of the quick unborn child by act amounting to culpable homicide

 

Note: Quick child is a fetus that has developed to such a stage that it moves within the womb of the mother. It shall mean an unborn child whose heart is beating, who is experiencing electronically measurable brain waves, who is discernibly moving, and who is so far developed and matured as to be capable of surviving the trauma of birth with the aid of usual medical care and facilities available in this state.

questions.text: A child has come to you for the administration of the IPV vaccine, as part of his routine immunisation schedule. Which of the following antibiotics may be found in this vaccine?
questions.solution:
IPV may contain trace amounts of streptomycin, neomycin or polymyxin B. 

MMR contain small amount of neomycin. 

Antibiotics are used during vaccine manufacture to prevent bacterial contamination of tissue culture cells.

questions.text: The weight of the head, arms and chest act as a constricting force in which of the following types of hanging?
questions.solution:
The weight of the head, arms, and chest acts as a constricting force in partial hanging.

Types of hanging:

  • Complete hanging - the weight of the entire body acts as a constricting force.
  • Partial hanging - the bodies are partially suspended, the weight of the head (5-6 kgs), arms, and chest act as a constricting force.

questions.text: Identify the fetal presentation shown in the following image :
questions.solution:
The image depicts anterior asynclitism where the anterior parietal bone is the presenting part.

The image shows the spine (dorsal part of the maternal body) and the pubic symphysis bone (ventral part of the maternal body) and it shows sagittal suture of the fetus deflected posteriorly towards the sacrum, thus making the anterior parietal bone the presenting part at the vaginal introitus.

Asynclitism refers to the position of a baby in the uterus such that the head of the baby is presenting first and is tilted to the shoulder, causing the fetal head to no longer be in line with the birth canal.

When the sagittal suture is deflected posteriorly, towards the sacral promontory the anterior parietal bone becomes the leading presenting part and is called anterior asynclitism.

When the sagittal suture is deflected anteriorly, towards the symphysis, the posterior parietal bone becomes the leading presenting part and is called posterior asynclitism. With extreme posterior asynclitism, the posterior ear may be easily palpated.

Moderate degrees of asynclitism are the rule in normal labour. However, if severe, this condition is a common reason for cephalopelvic disproportion even with an otherwise normal sized pelvis.

questions.text: What is the pathology seen in patients with Trevor's disease?
questions.solution:
Trevor's disease is characterized by the presence of intra-articular epiphyseal osteochondromas. 

In Trevor's disease, bony lesions appear on the medial or lateral aspect of the epiphysis. The lesions are localized to a single side of the body. Knee and ankle are most frequently involved.

Multiple osteochondromas are seen in a condition known as diaphyseal aclasis or multiple hereditary exostoses.

The below lateral view X-ray of the lower limb shows non-uniform bone growth, and unconnected ossification centers related to the epiphyses at the knee and ankle. This is seen in Trevor's disease.

questions.text: Which of the following organism confirms the recent fecal pollution of water?
questions.solution:
The presence of fecal streptococci is confirmatory evidence of recent fecal contamination of water.

Streptococci are highly resistant to drying and may be valuable for routine control testing after laying new mains or repairs in distribution systems or for detecting pollution by surface run-off to ground or surface waters.

Note: Streptococci, E. coli, and clostridium perfringens are biological indicators of fecal pollution of water.

Related Pearl: WHO Guidelines for Drinking Water Quality, 2017

WHO Guidelines for Drinking Water Quality, 2017

I) Physical parameters:

  Guideline values Comments
Turbidity Ideally, no visible turbidity but permissible standard is < 1.0 NTU (nephelometric turbidity units) for household drinking water. 

It describes the cloudiness of water.

  • >4 NTU – cloudiness visible to naked eye.
  • <4 NTU – measured only by instruments. 
Color Ideally, no visible color but permissible standard is <15 TCU (true color units).  >15 TCU is detectable by the naked eye. 

Taste, odor and temperature

 No health based guideline values It may be indicative of contamination and pollution. High water temperature may enhance growth of microorganisms and influence taste, odor and color.

 

II) Chemical parameters:

  Guideline values
Ammonia

No health based guideline value.

Natural levels in surface and ground water is 0.2 mg/l. Anaerobic groundwater may have up to 3 mg/l.
Aluminium up to 0.9 mg/l
Arsenic

up to 0.01 mg/l

Levels in natural water range from 1 to 2 µg/l.
Chloride

250 mg/l, as above this a detectable taste appears.

Maximum permissible level is 600 mg/l. Sodium thiosulphate can be used to dechlorinate drinking water or tap water.
Copper

up to 2 mg/l.

Excess copper in water can have gastrointestinal effects.
Fluoride

up to 1.5 mg/l. Above this, there is risk of dental and skeletal fluorosis.

Artificial fluoridation range is 0.5 to 1.0 mg/l.
Hydrogen sulphide

Taste and odor threshold is between 0.05 and 0.1 mg/litre.

A rotten egg smell of water indicates hydrogen sulphide.
Nitrates 50 mg/l as nitrate ion, to prevent methaemoglobinaemia and thyroid effects
Nitrites 3 mg/l as nitrite ion, to prevent methemoglobinemia in bottle-fed infants and general population.
pH Acceptable pH is in the range of 6.5 – 8.5.
Lead

up to 0.01 mg/l

The concentration of lead must be kept as low as possible. It is the most undesirable metal in drinking water.
Mercury

0.006 mg/l for inorganic mercury

It is nephrotoxic
Polyaromatic hydrocarbons (PAH)

Benzo(a)pyrene up to 0.0007 mg/l

They are to be kept in traces as they are carcinogenic/mutagenic
Sodium Above 200 mg/l may give an unacceptable taste.
Total Dissolved Solids (TDS)

Less than 600 mg/l is generally considered palatable.

TDS consists of inorganic salts and small amounts of organic matter dissolved in water. Water is completely unpalatable above 1200mg/l.

 

III) Biological indicators:

  • Total coliform bacteria:
    • They are the primary bacterial indicators for drinking water.
    • Total coliforms are good indicators of water disinfection because they are abundant in the human intestine and are foreign to potable water.
    • E. coli is considered the best indicator of fecal contamination of water when resources for supplementary microbiological examination are limited.
    • Guidelines state that coliforms must not be detectable in 100ml of sample water. 
    • Multiple tubes method:
      • This is a test of bacteriological surveillance of drinking water for coliforms and thereby fecal contamination.
      • This test is based on the most probable number (MPN) of coliform organisms.
      • Acid and gas production from fermentation due to coliforms are observed for in multiple tubes and a presumptive coliform count is arrived at.
      • Confirmation of E. coli can be done by testing for indole formation at 44-45 degrees Celsius or by another test called Eijkman test.
    • Faecal streptococci: Their presence in water indicates recent contamination with feces and are regarded as specific indicators of human faecal pollution.
    • Clostridium perfringens: They are spore-forming organisms that are resistant to many disinfection methods. They are used as an indicator of protozoa in water and also of remote/intermittent fecal contamination. Their spores are also indicators of the effectiveness of filtration processes.
    • Viruses like enteric viruses can also be used as indicators of the disinfection process.
    • Heterotrophic plate counts measure a wide range of heterotrophic organisms including bacteria and fungi.
    • Coliphages and Bacteroides fragilis phages are evidence of fecal contamination of water. 

IV) Radiological aspects:

  • The proposed guidelines for gross alpha activity is 0.5 Bq/litre and for gross beta activity, it is 1.0 Bq/litre of drinking water.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the casualty with severe abdominal pain. On performing emergency exploratory laparotomy, the following finding is noted. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Can be a lead point for intussusception
The most common presenting symptom is bleeding in younger children
It is a false diverticulum which extends from the anti-mesenteric side
Most common heterotopic tissue is gastric mucosa

questions.solution:
Meckel’s diverticulum is a true diverticulum, which extends from the antimesenteric side of the small bowel. The diverticula which contain all the layers of the intestine are called true diverticula. 

Meckel’s diverticulum is caused by a failure of normal regression of the vitelline duct that develops during weeks 5-7 of gestation.

The rule of 2's (Mnemonic for Meckel’s diverticulum) :

  • 2 types of heterotopic mucosa (gastric & pancreatic)
  • 2% incidence
  • located within 2 feet of the ileocecal valve
  • approximately 2 inches in length
  • Usually symptomatic by 2 years of age

The most common presentation is painless, massive, lower GI bleed in children younger than 5 years. Meckel's diverticulum can be the lead point for ileoileal or ileocolic intussusception.

A bleeding Meckel's diverticulum may be confirmed by a 99 mTc-pertechnetate isotope scan to detect ectopic gastric mucosa. 

Surgical treatment is the definitive therapy for Meckel’s diverticulum. A simple V-shaped diverticulectomy with transverse closure of the ileum is the ideal surgical approach.

The following diagram shows the various anomalies that arise as a result of the failure of normal regression of vitellointestinal duct:

questions.text: Which of the following is true about breast milk jaundice?

choices.text: Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia is seen in the infant
It is seen in the first week of life
It is due to inadequate breastfeeding

questions.solution:
Breastfeeding should be continued in infants with Breastmilk jaundice.

Breastmilk jaundice usually occurs after the first week of life. It is caused by the presence of β-glucuronidase, which deconjugates intestinal bilirubin. Therefore, it causes Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

Most neonates would not have a dangerous level of Total Serum bilirubin and don't require any treatment. Mothers should continue breastfeeding.

Breastfeeding jaundice begins in the first week of life. It occurs due to inadequate breastfeeding. Inadequate breastfeeding can be caused by Improper breastfeeding technique, breast engorgement, cracked or sore nipples, late preterm gestation, and ineffective sucking.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents with headache and weakness of the right side of the body. He has difficulty in speaking also. Angiography shows a puff of smoke appearance. Which of the following statements regarding this disease is false?

choices.text: It is an occlusive disease involving large intracranial arteries
Dawson’s fingers are the characteristic imaging finding

questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of Moyamoya disease and Dawson's fingers is not a finding in this condition. 

Dawson fingers are a radiographic feature typically seen in multiple sclerosis (MS)

The picture below demonstrates Dawson fingers.

Moyamoya disease is an occlusive disease involving large intracranial arteries. It has a bimodal age distribution and is seen in the first and fourth decades:

  • Childhood moyamoya is characterized by ischemic manifestations
  • Adult moyamoya is characterized by hemorrhagic manifestations

The first symptom is a stroke or recurrent TIA.

Treatment is by surgical bypass of extracranial carotid arteries to the dura or middle cerebral artery. This may prevent stroke and haemorrhage.

The below image shows the MR angiography findings in a patient with Moyamoya disease.

Note: As this is a chronic condition, the lenticulostriate arteries develop a rich collateral circulation around the occlusive lesion. This is seen as a 'puff of smoke' (moyamoya in Japanese) on X-ray angiography.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man was diagnosed with STEMI. He was admitted and given thrombolytic therapy. The next day he complained of palpitations and an ECG was taken. Which of the following drugs can be used to treat his condition?
questions.solution:
The above ECG shows narrow QRS complex, irregular RR intervals, and absent P waves which are suggestive of atrial fibrillation. Among the given options, amiodarone can be administered in patients having atrial fibrillation with coronary or structural heart disease.

Drugs for rhythm control in atrial fibrillation:

In patients without structural heart disease, class I agents are used. Class I agents act by blocking the Na+ channels leading to slower depolarization:

  • Flecainide 
  • Propafenone
  • Disopyramide

In patients with coronary or structural heart disease, class III agents are used. Class III agents act by blocking the K+ channels leading to slower repolarization causing increased refractory period:

  • Amiodarone
  • Dofetilide
  • Sotalol
  • Ibutilide

questions.text: Which of the following bacilli gives the appearance of Chinese letters?
questions.solution:
Corynebacterium diphtheria also known as Klebs-Loffler bacillus gives the appearance of Chinese letters.

The bacilli are usually arranged in pairs or palisades or small groups, at various angles to each other, resembling the letters V or L. This has been called the Chinese letter or cuneiform arrangement.

Albert’s stain, Neisser’s stain, and Ponder’s stain are used to demonstrate the metachromatic granules (Volutin/Babes Ernst granules) of Corynebacterium diphtheria.

Related Pearl: Common names of various bacteria

List of common names and scientific names of medically important bacteria:

questions.text: According to the berlin definition, moderate ARDS is characterized by all, except
questions.solution:
Moderate ARDS is characterized by PaO2/FiO2: 101 - 200 mmHg. PaO2/FiO2: 200 - 300 mm/Hg is classified as mild ARDS. 

Diagnostic criteria in ARDS—Berlin definition:(requires each of the following criteria to be present to diagnose ARDS)

  • Onset - Acute: Respiratory symptoms must have begun < 1 week of a known clinical insult
  • Bilateral alveolar or interstitial infiltrates: on a chest X-ray image or CT scan
  • Respiratory failure must not be fully explained by cardiac failure or fluid overload. Objective assessment e.g Echo should be done in cases of no known cause.
  • Impairment of oxygenation: The severity of hypoxemia defines the severity of ARDS.

Severity

PaO2/FiO2

(On ventilator settings that include PEEP ≥5 cm H2O)

Mild

> 200 mmHg but ≤ 300 mmHg

Moderate

 > 100 mmHg but ≤ 200 mmHg
Severe ≤ 100 mmHg

Note: American-European Consensus Conference (AECC) classification of ARDS is no longer used.

Image: Alveolar/interstitial infiltrates in ARDS patient

questions.text: Blood is collected in a grey-colored vacutainer to measure blood glucose level. Which substance is present in this vacutainer?
questions.solution:
Sodium fluoride present in the grey-colored vacutainer inhibits glycolysis. Hence, is used for the estimation of blood glucose and alcohol.

The Clinical & Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) has recommended a color sequence for multiple collections of venous and/or arterial blood samples in a single patient.

Yellow, pink, and blue → light Blue → red → green → lavender → grey

Other options:

Option A: Green vacutainers contain Heparin.

Option C: Purple vacutainers contain K2 EDTA. This helps remove the calcium by forming salts and is used to collect samples for hematological studies and cross-match samples.

Option D: Light blue vacutainers are coagulation tubes and contain sodium citrate. It is used to collect samples for coagulation tests such as prothrombin time.

Related Pearl: Anticoagulants in Vacutainers and their Uses

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with sudden severe headache and vomiting. She has a history of prolactinoma treated with cabergoline, which she stopped taking 3 months ago, despite medical advice not to. Her last neuroimaging 3 months ago had shown a pituitary mass of 5 cm. On examination, she is in unconscious and her vitals suggest she is in shock. Her family tells you that she also complained of blurred vision earlier at home. In addition to general resuscitation, what is the next step in immediate management?

choices.text: Give IV fluids only and monitor

questions.solution:
This woman, who has a history of a pituitary tumor now presents with sudden headache and shock. This is highly suggestive of pituitary apoplexy - An acute intrapituitary hemorrhagic vascular event causing damage to the pituitary gland and the surrounding structures. Since she is unconsious and also has a history of blurred vision, the treatment of choice is urgent surgical decompression. 

It occurs spontaneously, as in pre-existing adenoma or in Sheehan's syndrome. It can also occur in association with other systemic diseases like diabetes mellitus, systemic hypertension, sickle cell anemia, and acute shock.

Clinical features include are headache with signs of meningeal irritation, bilateral visual changes, ophthalmoplegia, cardiovascular collapse(shock) and, loss of consciousness. 

Investigation of choice: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)

Treatment :

  • Patients with no signs of visual disturbances or loss of consciousness - high dose glucocorticoids
  • Patients with signs of progressive visual loss, cranial nerve palsy, or loss of consciousness - urgent surgical decompression

Note: Hypopituitarism follows pituitary apoplexy.

questions.text: Which of the following is involved in inducing the migration of leukocytes to sites of injury?
questions.solution:
C5a induces the migration of leukocytes to the site of injury. It functions as an endogenous chemoattractant.

Both exogenous and endogenous substances can act as chemoattractants. The most common exogenous agents include bacterial products like peptides with N-formylmethionine terminal amino acids and certain lipids. 

Endogenous chemoattractants include several chemical mediators:

  1. Cytokines - particularly those of the chemokine family (IL-8)
  2. Complement system components - particularly C5a
  3. Arachidonic acid metabolites - mainly leukotriene B4 

Related Pearl: Various actions of Principal Mediators of Inflammation

Histamine Vasodilation, increased vascular permeability, endothelial activation
Prostaglandins Vasodilation, pain, fever
Leukotrienes Increased vascular permeability, chemotaxis, leukocyte adhesion, and activation
Cytokines (TNF, IL-1, IL-6)

Local: endothelial activation (expression of adhesion molecules).

Systemic: fever, metabolic abnormalities, hypotension (shock)
Chemokines Chemotaxis, leukocyte activation
Platelet-activating factor Vasoconstriction, Vasodilation (at low concentration), increased vascular permeability, leukocyte adhesion, chemotaxis, degranulation, oxidative burst
Complement Leukocyte chemotaxis and activation, direct target killing (membrane attack complex), vasodilation (mast cell stimulation)
Kinins Increased vascular permeability, smooth muscle contraction, vasodilation, pain

Note: Thromboxane A2 (TXA2) is a prostaglandin, which is a potent vasoconstrictor

questions.text: Which of the following statement is false regarding epigenetic modification:

choices.text: It causes the alteration of gene expression without mutation
The acetylation of histone favors active transcription
Genomic imprinting is a phenomenon involved in epigenetic gene inactivation
DNA methylation is restricted between cytosine and guanine residues connected by hydrogen bonds

questions.solution:
DNA methylation usually occurs between cytosine and guanine residues connected by phosphodiester bond (CpG) island on the same strand.

Epigenetics is defined as heritable chemical changes in gene expression that are not caused by the alteration in the gene sequence. It alters gene expression without the mutation. Epigenetic modification can cause both gene activation and inactivation. If it causes gene inactivation, it is known as Genomic imprinting.  

The epigenetic modification includes:

  • DNA methylation is usually restricted to cytosines of CpG dinucleotides, which are abundant throughout the genome. CpG islands in promoter regions are typically unmethylated, and the lack of methylation facilitates transcription.
  • Acetylation and deacetylation of lysine residues in core histones which activates and deactivates gene expression respectively. Acetylation of histone favors active transcription.
  • Methylation of histones: Histone Methylation Mostly Makes DNA Mute.

questions.text: Which of the following vitamin deficiency do not cause Hyperhomocysteinemia?
questions.solution:
Niacin deficiency does not cause hyperhomocysteinemia.

Elevated blood homocysteine is a significant risk factor for atherosclerosis, thrombosis, and hypertension. The condition is the result of deficiency of Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6), Cobalamin (B12), and folate resulting in failure to convert homocysteine to methionine thus hyperhomocysteinemia.

questions.text: Which of the following represents the correct order of amount of water absorption in the respective sites of the gastrointestinal tract?
questions.solution:
The amount of water absorbed in the intestines follows this order: Jejunum > Ileum > Colon, with the maximum water absorption taking place in the jejunum.

The intestines are presented each day with about 2000 mL of ingested fluid plus 7000 mL of secretions from the mucosa of the gastrointestinal tract and associated glands. Ninety-eight percent of this fluid is reabsorbed, with a daily fluid loss of only 200 mL in the stools.

questions.text: Which of the following is detected by TLR-2?
questions.solution:
Gram-positive bacteria are detected by Toll-like receptors 2 or TLR 2.

Toll-like receptors (TLRs) are the microbial sensors present in the macrophages and phagocytic cells that can detect a pathogen as it enters the skin.

The mechanism is the activation of signal transduction cascade and a marked inflammatory response.   

In humans, 10 TLRs have been found which have unique microbial recognition patterns. They are as follows

  • TLR 1 and 6 detect diacyl peptides 
  • TLR 2 recognized various ligands like lipoteichoic acid expressed by the gram-positive bacteria
  • TLR 3 engages double-stranded viral RNA in viral replication.
  • TLR 4 is specific for gram-negative lipopolysaccharides.
  • TLR 5 can recognize the flagellin in bacteria.
  • TLR 7 and 8 interact with single-stranded RNA in viral replication.
  • TLR 9 binds to both viral and bacterial DNA
  • TLR 10 is an orphan receptor

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy sustained an injury while falling on an outstretched hand and presented with pain and swelling over his left elbow. His X-ray image is shown below. Which among the following classification is used in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of the boy presenting with pain and swelling over his left elbow and the X-ray image is suggestive of a supracondylar fracture of the humerus. Gartland classification is used in this case.

Gartland classification

  • Type I – an undisplaced fracture
  • Type II – an angulated fracture with the posterior cortex still intact.
             IIA: a less severe injury with the distal fragment merely angulated
             IIB: a severe injury; the fragment is both angulated and malrotated
  • Type III–a completely displaced fracture(although the posterior periosteum is usually preserved, which will assist in surgical reduction)
  • Type IV – an anteriorly displaced fracture

Supracondylar fracture of the humerus is most commonly seen in children of 5-7 years. The extension type is seen in 98% of the cases while the rest are flexion type. The mechanism of injury involved is usually a fall on an outstretched hand with an elbow in full extension. 

On examination, there may be an S-shaped deformity at the elbow. If the proximal fracture fragment is sharp and has penetrated the muscles and fascia, a dimple may be seen on the skin above the elbow (dimple sign). The three-point bony relationship is maintained in supracondylar fracture.

Radiology:  

  • An undisplaced fracture may show a triangular lucency like a sail of a yacht (sail sign), also called a fat pad sign. This is due to the fat pad around the elbow being pushed forward by the hematoma.
  • Baumann’s angle is the angle between the horizontal line of the elbow and the line drawn through the lateral epiphysis and long axis of the arm. It is normally less than 5 degrees and is checked with the other arm.

The most common nerve to be injured in the extension type is the anterior interosseous nerve while the ulnar nerve is injured in the flexion type. The brachial artery is most likely involved when there is blood vessel involvement. Cubitus varus or gunstock deformity is the most common angular deformity that results from supracondylar fractures in children. It is corrected by closing wedge osteotomy.

Conservative management is attempted with closed reduction using traction and counter-traction. Successful reduction is when the long axis of the arm and forearm lie in parallel. If conservative management fails, skin or skeletal traction is employed but is not used anymore due to better modalities of treatment.

Surgery is by either closed reduction and percutaneous internal fixation with K-wires or open reduction and internal fixation with wires or plates.

questions.text: The medial fragment in a clavicle fracture is held up due to:

choices.text: Force of gravity on ipsilateral arm

questions.solution:
The medial fragment in a clavicle fracture is held up by the action of the sternocleidomastoid.

The lateral fragment in a clavicle fracture is displaced inferiorly due to gravity acting on the ipsilateral arm.

Fracture of the clavicle:

Mechanism of injury:

  • Fall on the point of the shoulder
  • Direct trauma over the clavicle due to road traffic accident
  • Fall on the outstretched hand

The fracture occurs most commonly at the junction of the middle third and outer third of the clavicle

Treatment:

  • Conservative treatment
    • Cuff and collar sling
    • Strapping and sling suspension
    • Figure of 8 bandaging
  • Operative treatment (for open fracture, injury to the neurovascular bundle, non union, floating shoulder etc)
    • Open reduction and internal fixation

questions.text: A woman presents with bluish discoloration of the skin and mucous membranes. All of the following may be responsible for the given symptoms except:
questions.solution:
Bluish discoloration of the skin and mucous membranes is suggestive of cyanosis. Cyanosis is seen when the concentration of deoxygenated or reduced hemoglobin exceeds 4 gm/dL.

Cyanosis is detectable with methemoglobin ≥1.5 gm% and/or sulfhemoglobin ≥0.5 gm%.

Central cyanosis is detectable when the oxygen saturation <85%. In dark-skinned individuals, it may be detectable at an oxygen saturation of 75%.

The types of cyanosis are:

Central cyanosis Peripheral cyanosis

Due to diminished arterial oxygen saturation/presence of abnormal hemoglobin derivative.

Due to diminished peripheral blood flow.

Mucous membranes and skin are both affected

 Mucous membranes of the oral cavity or those beneath the tongue are spared.

Decreases after O2 supplementation

 Does not decrease after O2 supplementation

questions.text: Identify the nematode in the given muscle biopsy specimen.
questions.solution:
The given skeletal muscle biopsy shows Trichinella spiralis. The given muscle biopsy image shows encysted larvae of Trichinella, which is a tissue nematode and causes trichinosis.

Trichinella spiralis is typically encountered in undercooked pork. Encysted larvae of Trichinella spiralis are present in the striated muscles of its hosts.

The optimum host is the pig. Humans are dead-end hosts for trichinella. The infective form is the encysted form in the striated muscles of pigs and other animals. 

The muscles undergo basophilic degeneration with features of myositis. Patients experience malaise, diarrhea, muscle weakness, myocarditis, and encephalitis. 

Detection of spiral larva in muscle tissue is done by performing a muscle biopsy. Deltoid, biceps, gastrocnemius, or pectoralis muscles are usually selected for biopsy. About 1 g of muscle tissue preferably near the tendon insertion is biopsied and stained with safranin. 

Bachman's intradermal test involves the injection of trichinella larval antigen intradermally. An erythematous wheal appears in positive cases within 15-20 minutes. The test remains positive for years after infection.

Treatment depends on the severity of the condition

  • Mild case - Antipyretics and analgesics 
  • Moderate cases - Albendazole or mebendazole
  • Severe cases - Glucocorticosteroids like prednisolone along with albendazole or mebendazole

Other parasites that can be demonstrated in a muscle biopsy are:

  • T. solium
  • T. cruzi (amastigote)

Other options - 

Option A: Enterobius vermicularis, also known as pinworm, lives in the cecum and appendix. Infection is by ingestion of eggs or autoinfection. Detection of eggs by NIH swabs and cellophane scotch tape method. 

Option B: Trichuris trichiura is also known as whipworm. The infective form is the embryonated egg that contains a rhabditiform larva. Patients are often asymptomatic except when the worm load is heavy where the disease manifests due to mechanical effects or allergic reactions. Fecal smears show barrel-shaped ovum with mucus plug at both ends. Eggs of Trichuris trichiura are brown in color, bile stained, and float in a saturated salt solution. 

Option D: Ascaris lumbricoides is the largest nematode infecting humans. The infective form is the embryonated egg containing rhabditiform larva. Demonstration of egg in stool or adult worm in stool or sputum is helpful in diagnosis. 

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with high fever, vomiting and one seizure which lasted for 2 minutes. She appears confused and is unable to answer questions properly. Her medical history is significant for Graves disease with medication non-compliance. Her family members also tell you that for the past few days she has been feeling feverish and had a cough. The cardiac monitor shows some arrhythmias. What is the most appropriate management for this patient, in addition to supportive care?
questions.solution:
This patient who has Graves disease and an acute infection, now presents with high fever, vomiting, one seizure and confusion. This is suggestive of thyroid storm or thyrotoxic crises. Management includes supportive measures and large doses of propylthiouracil (500–1000 mg loading dose and 250 mg every 4 h) given orally or via an NG tube and propranolol (60–80 mg PO every 4 h; or 2 mg IV every 4 h). 

Methimazole is used if propylthiouracil is not available. Although identificantion and treatment of the precipitaing factor is important, antibiotics and propranolol alone are not enough - anti-thyroid drugs should be given. 

Related Pearl: Thyroid storm / Thyrotoxic crisis:

It is an emergency caused by an acute exacerbation of hyperthyroidism. 

Precipitating factors:

  • When a thyrotoxic patient has been inadequately prepared for thyroidectomy
  • Abrupt cessation of antithyroid medications
  • Stress
    • Infection
    • Thyroid or non-thyroid surgery
    • Trauma in patients with untreated thyrotoxicosis
  • Acute iodine load
    • Amiodarone administration 
    • Exposure to iodinated contrast agents
    • Following RAI therapy

Clinical features:

  • Fever
  • Tachycardia
  • Altered mentation (delirium, psychosis, coma)
  • GI symptoms (nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea)
  • Atrial fibrillation and cardiac failure - most common causes of death

Treatment of thyroid storm:

Treatment modality Effect
IV Fluids, ice packs Rehydration and external cooling
Propylthiouracil
(DOC)

Reduces peripheral T4 to T3 conversion
Propranolol

Block adrenergic effects

Reduces peripheral T4 to T3 conversion
Corticosteroids

Inhibits the release of thyroid hormone from the gland

Reduces peripheral T4 to T3 conversion
Lugol’s iodine/ sodium ipodate Inhibits the release of thyroid hormone from the gland
Digoxin Controls the associated atrial fibrillation
Diuretics and administration of oxygen

To manage cardiac failure

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy with frequent nose bleeds is brought for a routine check-up.  He has multiple ecchymoses over his arms and legs. The physician reports a deficiency in a clotting protein. A normal platelet count, prolonged BT, normal PT, and a prolonged aPTT are seen in this patient. Which of the following is the major source of the deficient clotting protein?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of von-Willebrand disease. It is caused by a deficiency of the von-Willebrand factor. The major source of plasma von-Willebrand factor is endothelial cells. 

They are present within cytoplasmic vesicles called Weibel-Palade bodies

Normal Platelet count, Prolonged BT, Normal PT, Prolonged aPTT is seen in Von - Willebrand disease. Factor VIII is found bound to the Von-Willebrand factor(vWF)  in the blood. Deficiency of vWF results in Factor VIII deficiency and prolongation of aPTT in this disease. Prolonged BT is due to abnormal platelet mediated hemostasis.

vWF is also found in:

  • Platelet granules (Less as compared to endothelial cells)
  • Subendothelium, where it binds to collagen

questions.text: A young man who had fractured his left humerus previously now does not feel pain in his left little finger. On examination, the following deformity is observed. Which of the nerves is most likely to have been involved?
questions.solution:
The deformity shown is cubitus valgus. This, along with the patient’s history of previous humerus fracture followed by loss of sensation over the little finger, points to the involvement of the ulnar nerve.

Cubitus valgus can occur as a late complication of nonunion of fracture of the lateral condyle of the humerus. The cubitus valgus deformity leads to the stretching of the ulnar nerve, resulting in classic neuropathic symptoms, which is termed tardy ulnar nerve palsy. Paresthesia in the ulnar nerve distribution with atrophy of the intrinsic hand muscles can be seen. It can be treated with ulnar nerve transposition and cubitus valgus correction.

The ulnar nerve supplies the medial two lumbricals in the hand. The lumbricals have a combined action on metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint flexion and interphalangeal (IP) joint extension (glass holding posture). In ulnar nerve injury, since the medial lumbricals are not functional, the forearm muscles are unopposed. Hence, there is hyperextension at MCP joints and flexion at IP joints. This causes claw hand deformity. There is also numbness in the medial one-and-a-half fingers. 

Related Pearl: Dermatome of upper limb

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents with headache and weakness of the right side of the body. He has difficulty in speaking.  Angiography findings are shown below. Which among the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features and the angiography showing a puff of smoke appearance is suggestive of Moyamoya disease.

Moyamoya disease is an occlusive disease involving the large intracranial arteries.

It has a bimodal age distribution in the first and fourth decades. Childhood moyamoya disease is characterized by ischemic manifestations, whereas adult moyamoya disease is marked by hemorrhagic manifestations.

Vascular inflammation is absent. Since it is a chronic condition, the lenticulostriate arteries develop a rich collateral circulation around the occlusive lesion. This is seen as a puff of smoke (moyamoya in Japanese) on X-ray angiography.

The first symptom is a stroke or recurrent TIA.

Treatment: Surgical bypass of extracranial carotid arteries to the dura or middle cerebral artery may prevent stroke and hemorrhage.

questions.text: A young man presented to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. He reported significant left hip pain and an inability to bear weight. The affected leg is in the position as shown in the image. Which of the following nerves is most commonly injured in a case like this?

choices.text: Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve of thigh

questions.solution:
In the above image, the affected leg is in the state of flexion, abduction, and external rotation (FABER). Hence the most likely diagnosis is anterior dislocation of the hip and the most common nerve injured is femoral nerve.

According to the position assumed by the femoral head, anterior dislocation of the hip can further be classified as superior and inferior. When seen from the side:

  • If the femoral head lies anteriorly it is called as the superior (pubic) type
  • If the femoral head lies in the groin it is called as the inferior (obturator) type

Related Pearl: Anterior and posterior dislocation of the hip

  Anterior dislocation Posterior dislocation
Prevalence Less common Most common
Type of injury Deceleration injury/ Fall from height Dashboard injury
Attitude of the limb Flexion, abduction, external rotation (FABER) Flexion, adduction, internal rotation (FADIR)
Length of the limb Lengthened Shortened
Radiological findings
  • Femoral head may be seen inferior to the acetabulum
  • Femoral head appears larger than normal 
  • Lesser trochanter is prominent
  • Femoral head is displaced superiorly and laterally
  • Femoral head appears smaller than normal
  • Lesser trochanter is not visualised
Nerve injured  Femoral nerve  Sciatic nerve

Related Pearl: Fractures/dislocations and associated nerve injuries

Fracture/Dislocation Nerve injured
Fracture clavicle Brachial plexus
Anterior or inferior shoulder dislocation Axillary (circumflex humeral) nerve
Proximal humerus fracture Axillary nerve
Shaft of humerus fracture Radial nerve
Supracondylar fracture humerus  Anterior interosseous nerve > Median nerve > Radial nerve
Medial condyle of humerus  Ulnar nerve
Posterior dislocation elbow Ulnar nerve >Median nerve

Lunate dislocation  Median nerve
Wrist injury Median nerve
Posterior hip dislocation Sciatic nerve
Anterior dislocation of hip and shaft femur fracture Femoral nerve
Knee dislocation Common peroneal nerve
