questions.text: In a patient, urine flow rate is 10 mL/min; plasma inulin is 2 mg/mL; and urine inulin is 25 mg/mL. Which of the following is true assuming GFR to be normal?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, inulin clearance = GFR.

Inulin clearance is calculated by the formula:

Substituting the values given,

  • Uinulin= 25 mg/mL
  • Vinulin= 10 mL/min
  • Pinulin=2 mg/mL

Thus, Inulin clearance=GFR (normal GFR= 125 ml/min)

Inulin is a polymer of fructose, clearance of inulin can be used for measurement of GFR, because of the following reasons: 

  • Freely filtered
  • Neither reabsorbed nor secreted in the tubules
  • Nontoxic
  • Not metabolized by the body

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presented with new-onset seizures. Examination suggests raised intracranial pressure and the fundus is as given below. He had previously been diagnosed with cysts in his kidney. Which of the following intracranial tumors is the most likely cause for his symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given fundus image shows a retinal hemangioma indicated by the arrow. Retinal hemangioma in a patient with renal cysts and an intracranial tumor is suggestive of Von Hippel–Lindau disease. The associated intracranial tumor with this is Cerebellar hemangioblastoma

  • The major neurologic features of von Hippel–Lindau disease include cerebellar hemangioblastomas and retinal angiomas.
  • Cerebellar hemangioblastomas
    • Are erythropoietin-secreting tumors, which can lead to polycythemia
    • Usually present in early adult life with symptoms and signs of increased intracranial pressure
    • Typically appearing as a cystic cerebellar lesion with a vascular mural nodule on CT or MRI scan
    • Are treated with total surgical removal of the tumor, which is curative
  • Retinal angioma:
    • Small masses of thin-walled capillaries, usually located in the peripheral retina that is fed by large and tortuous arterioles and venules appearing as a fiery red vascular mass
    • Exudation in the region of the angiomas may lead to retinal detachment and visual loss
    • Retinal angiomas are treated with photocoagulation and cryo-coagulation

von Hippel–Lindau disease

  • Arises from an autosomal-dominant mutation of VHL gene on chromosome 3
  • Associations of VHL syndrome:
    • Cystic lesions of kidneys, pancreas, liver, and epididymis
    • Renal cell carcinoma (most common cause of death)
    • Pheochromocytoma
    • Cerebellar hemangioblastoma
    • Retinal angioma

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is not involved in the formation of the perineal body?
questions.solution:
The internal anal sphincter is not involved in the formation of the perineal body.

The perineal body is a fibromuscular structure present in the midline at the junction between the anal and urogenital triangle. It attaches to various muscles in the pelvis:

  • Anterior - superficial and deep transverse perinei, bulbospongiosus
  • Posterior - external anal sphincter 
  • Superior - puborectalis, pubovaginalis and the rectovaginal septum 

It is continuous with the perineal membrane and the superficial perineal fascia. In males, it continues as the perineal raphe, and in females, it is attached to the posterior commissure and the introitus. 

The following image shows the perineal body and its muscular attachments.

Related Pearl: Perineal Body

The perineal body is not a structure but an aggregation of fibromuscular tissue located in the midline at the junction between the anal and urogenital triangles, just ventral to the anal sphincter.

Ten muscles of the perineum converge and interlace in the perineal body.

Category Muscles
Two unpaired
  • Fibres of longitudinal muscle coat of anal canal
  • Fibres from External anal sphincter
Four Paired
  • Bulbospongiosus
  • Superficial transverse perenei
  • Deep transverse perenei
  • Levator ani

Note: In females, sphincter urethrovaginalis is also attached here.

questions.text: A nursing assistant posted in the obstetric care unit was asked to plot a partograph to monitor the progress of labour. Where should she start marking the cervical dilatation?
questions.solution:
In a partograph, the first marking of cervical dilatation should be made on the left of the alert line. In a normal partograph, the plotting remains on the left of the alert line.

Related Pearl: Partograph

Partograph types:

WHO Modified Partograph (2000)

  • No latent phase
  • Vaginal examination: This should be done no less than every 4 hours to assess cervical dilatation, descent of the fetal head, and moulding of skull bones. More frequent examination is only undertaken if indicated.
  • Charting starts at 4 cm of cervical dilation.
  • Colour of liquor mentioned as C-clear, B-blood stained, M-meconium stained.
  • Moulding mentioned:
    • bones are separated and sutures can be easily felt - (0)
    • bones touching (1+)
    • bones overlapping but can be reduced(2+)
    • bones severely overlapping and irreducible ( 3+).
  • Alert line reflects the average rate of cervical dilation of the slowest quintile of term primigravidas, if dilation slows or ceases, the partograph plot will cross the alert line.
  • Alert line: at 4 cm dilation and expected dilation of 1 cm/hour.
  • Action line is 2–4 hours after the alert line, which prompts interventions to accelerate labor or perform cesarean delivery.
  • Higher rates of perinatal mortality are associated with delays of 4 hours or more after the alert line.
  • Contractions measured for a span of 10 min (duration noted) and measured every 30 min (1 square = half hour).
  • Pulse: record every 30 minutes and mark with a dot (•).
  • Blood pressure: record every 4 hours and mark with arrows, unless the patient has a hypertensive disorder or pre-eclampsia, in which case record every 30 minutes.
  • Temperature: record every 4 hours.

WHO Composite Partograph: It is same as modified except for it has latent phase and charting done at 3 cm.

WHO Simplified Partograph: WHO further modified the partograph for use by skilled attendants in health centers. This simplified partograph is colour coded.

  • The area to the left of the alert line in the cervicograph is coloured green, representing normal progress.
  • The area to the right of the action line is coloured red, indicating dangerously slow progress in labour.
  • The area in between the alert and action line is coloured amber, indicating the need for greater vigilance.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man was found dead in his apartment. No medical records were found in his place. An autopsy image of his liver is given below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of death?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the nutmeg appearance of the liver, which is seen in heart failure. Congestive hepatopathy, also known as nutmeg liver or chronic passive congestion of the liver, is liver dysfunction due to venous congestion. It usually occurs due to congestive heart failure.

Pathogenesis:

  • It is seen in patients with chronic cardiac lesions, especially those affecting the right heart, which causes the blood to be drained back into the inferior vena cava and then into the hepatic veins.
  • This transmission of right ventricular pressure directly into the hepatic veins causes passive congestion around the central veins leading to enlargement of the liver (congestive hepatomegaly).

Gross appearance:

  • In chronic passive hepatic congestion due to heart failure, the centrilobular regions are grossly red-brown due to congestion and slightly depressed due to cell death and are accentuated against the surrounding zones of the uncongested tan liver.
  • The appearance is called a nutmeg liver pattern due to its close resemblance with the cut surface of the nutmeg seed.

Microscopic appearance:

Microscopic examination reveals centrilobular hemorrhage, hemosiderin-laden macrophages, necrosis, and variable degrees of hepatocyte dropout.

questions.text: A elderly male patient complains of chest pain at rest. He previously experienced it on exertion. ECG shows ST depression, with no elevation of cardiac biomarkers, what is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is unstable angina based on the clinical features given. Unstable angina is a subtype of acute coronary syndrome (ACS).

ACS includes:

1. Non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome (NSTE-ACS)

  • Unstable angina
  • Non-ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI)

2. ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI)

The former, which includes unstable angina arises due to an imbalance in the myocardial oxygen supply-demand ratio. They present with characteristic features such as chest pain at rest, of recent onset, and lasting for more than ten minutes. It usually lasts longer or is more severe than previous episodes. (crescendo pattern). The pain is usually retrosternal and might radiate to the left arm, shoulder, or jaw. 

ECG may show new ST-segment depression in one-third of the patients. It can be transient or may last for several days in NSTEMI. In unstable angina, there is no elevation of cardiac biomarkers, namely cardiac troponin I or cardiac troponin T. In other words, there is no evidence of myocyte necrosis.

Stable angina is marked by ischemic episodes which present as chest pain, precipitated by exertion and relieved with rest. 

Other options:

Option A: Non-ST elevation myocardial infarction, a component of ACS, presents with similar symptoms. In contrast to unstable angina, there are elevated levels of cardiac biomarkers.

Option B: ST-elevation myocardial infarction, occurs due to occlusion of a coronary artery by thrombus. Usually, these vessels are already affected by atherosclerosis. The chest pain may last for more than 30 minutes, associated with marked diaphoresis. The ECG initially shows ST-segment elevation, and usually develops Q waves later on. There is an elevation of cardiac biomarkers. 

Option C: Left heart failure, which arises due to pulmonary edema, presents with shortness of breath. Brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) and N-terminal pro-BNP are biomarkers that are usually elevated. There are no specific ECG changes. Any abnormality can rather point to the underlying cardiac condition.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with persistent soreness of the nipple of the right breast. A crusted red, eczematous rash is present on the areola of the right breast. Histopathology shows malignant cells scattered individually throughout the squamous epithelium. All of the following are true about this disease except _________

choices.text: A palpable mass is never seen
Prognosis depends on the features of the underlying carcinoma
It presents as a unilateral erythematous eruption

questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of Paget's disease of the nipple. A palpable mass is seen in about half the patients with Paget disease of the nipple.

Paget's disease of the nipple is a rare manifestation of breast cancer that presents as a unilateral erythematous eruption with a scale crust, which could be mistaken for eczema. Histology shows malignant cells (Paget cells), with abundant pale cytoplasm and pleomorphic nuclei, scattered individually throughout the squamous epithelium.

Paget cells do not breach the basement membrane, they rather extend via the lactiferous sinuses into the nipple skin.The underlying carcinomas are usually poorly differentiated, ER-negative, and overexpress HER2. The prognosis of Paget's disease depends on the features of the underlying carcinoma.

The histology of Paget's disease of the nipple is shown in the image below.

Note: Paget cells may resemble the cells of superficial spreading melanoma, but they are periodic acid Schiff (PAS) positive - Diastase resistant (i.e. stain is present after diastase predigestion), unlike melanoma cells.

Lateral point: Paget disease of the bone is a disorder of locally increased but disordered and structurally unsound bone mass.

Paget disease of the nipple is not same as Paget disease of the bone.

questions.text: A patient presents with fatigue and a petechial rash for the past 4 weeks. Complete hemogram shows: Hb - 8 g/dL, platelet count  - 70,000/mm3, WBC - 5000/mm3. Bone marrow aspiration reveals mild hypercellularity with 3% blasts, dysplastic erythroid and megakaryocytic cells, and 10 % ringed sideroblasts(RS). What type of myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) does this patient have?

choices.text: MDS - RS with single lineage dysplasia

questions.solution:
MDS with multilineage dysplasia is seen in this patient. As both erythroid and megakaryocyte lineages are affected, it is a multilineage dysplasia.

Myelodysplastic syndromes are a group of hematogenous disorders that are characterized by cytopenia due to bone marrow failure and a high risk of transformation into acute myeloid leukemia(AML). Multilineage hematogenous abnormalities are seen as anemia, thrombocytopenia, and neutropenia. Dysmorphic and hypercellular bone marrow are reflective of ineffective hematopoiesis. 

  • WHO classification of Myelodysplastic syndromes:
Name Ringed sideroblasts Myeloblasts Karyotype

MDS with single lineage dysplasia (MDS-SLD)

<15% (<5%)a

BM <5%, PB <1%, no Auer rods

Any
MDS with multilineage dysplasia (MDS-MLD) <15% (<5%)a

BM <5%, PB <1%, no Auer rods

Any
MDS with ringed sideroblasts (MDS-RS)      

MDS-RS with single lineage dysplasia (MDS-RS-SLD)

 >15% (>5%)a

BM <5%, PB <1%, no Auer rods

 Any

MDS-RS with multilineage dysplasia (MDS-RS-MLD)

 >15% (>5%)a

BM <5%, PB <1%, no Auer rods

 Any

MDS with isolated del(5q)

None or any

BM <5%, PB <1%, no Auer rods

del(5q) alone or with 1 additional abnormality except -7 or del (7q)

MDS with excess blasts (MDS-EB)

      
MDS-EB-1 None or any

BM 5–9% or PB 2–4%, no Auer rods

MDS-EB-2 None or any  BM 10–19% or PB 5–19% or Auer rods Any

MDS, unclassifiable (MDS-U)

  • with 1% blasts
  • with single lineage dysplasia and pancytopenia
  • defining cytogenic abnormality

 

  • None or any
  • None or any
  • 15% 

 

  •  BM <5%, PB=1%, no Auer rods
  • BM <5%, PB=1%, no Auer rods
  • BM <5%, PB=1%, no Auer rods
  • Any
  • Any
  • MDS-defining abnormality
Refractory cytopenia of childhood  None  BM <5%, PB <2%  Any
       

Related Pearl: Bone Marrow Changes in Myelodysplastic Syndrome (MDS)

The myelodysplastic syndrome can lead to dysplasia of the erythroid series, myeloid series, and megakaryocytes.

Dysplasia of erythroid series:

  • Megaloblastoid maturation - Abnormally large erythroid cells
  • Nuclear budding abnormalities - Nucleus with abnormal shape
  • Ring sideroblasts - Erythroblasts with stainable iron in the cytoplasm 

 

Dysplasia of myeloid series:

  • Neutrophils with a decreased number of secondary granules
  • Pseudo-Pelger-Hüet cells- neutrophils with only two nuclear lobes

 

Dysplasia of the megakaryocytes:

  • Megakaryocyte with single nuclear lobe
  • Pawn ball megakaryocytes- cells with multiple separate nuclei

If only one lineage is affected, then it is called single lineage dysplasia. If multiple lineages are affected, then it is called multilineage dysplasia. If the percentage of ring sideroblasts is more than 15% it is called MDS with ring sideroblasts (MDS-RS).

questions.text: Which of the following is an intraepidermal disease?
questions.solution:
Pemphigus foliaceus is an intraepidermal vesiculobullous disorder.

Pemphigus foliaceus is a chronic blistering disease characterized by flaccid bullae with exfoliation mainly over the seborrhoeic area and with mucosal sparing. It is less severe than pemphigus vulgaris with antibodies against desmoglein-1

The skin lesion in this condition is a form of a subcorneal blister, where the stratum corneum forms the roof of the bulla. The bullae are superficial and mainly present as areas of erythema and crusting.

The lesions are commonly observed on the scalp, face, chest, and back and observation of acantholysis on Tzank smear. They represent superficial erosions at sites of blister rupture. There is no involvement of the mucosal epithelium in pemphigus foliaceus.

The histologic examination shows acantholysis in the upper epidermis and the stratum corneum will be separated from the underlying epidermis. On examination, it gives a positive Nikolsky sign. Dapsone and hydroxychloroquine can be used in treatment.

The following image shows lesions over the chest in pemphigus foliaceus. 

Related Pearl: Classification of Vesiculobullous Disorders

According to Pathology

  • Immunobullous disorders/ Primary blistering disease: occur due to autoimmunity

Intraepidermal

Subepidermal

Pemphigus vulgaris

Bullous pemphigoid

Pemphigus foliaceous

 Dermatitis herpetiformis

Pemphigus vegetans

 Epidermolysis bullous acquisita
 Pemphigus erythematosus  
  • Mechanobullous disorders: Due to defect in the structure of epidermis
    • Epidermolysis bullosa
    • Bullous ichthyosiform erythroderma
  • Other disorders
    • Infections - VZV, HSV, Bullous impetigo, SSSS
    • Metabolic - Porphyria, Diabetes, Hemodialysis
    • Drug eruptions - Fixed drug eruption, Steven Johnson Syndrome, Erythema Multiforme

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with chronic constipation was prescribed a stimulant purgative after she failed to respond to laxatives. Which of the following drugs is likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
Prucalopride is a stimulant purgative drug that acts as 5HT4 receptor agonist. It facilitates cholinergic neurotransmission and is approved for use in women with chronic constipation in whom laxatives fail to provide adequate relief.

Classification of Laxatives

  • Bulk-forming 
    • Dietary fibre: Bran, Psyllium/Ispaghula, Methylcellulose (option B)
  • Stool softener: Docusates (DOSS), Liquid paraffin (option D)
  • Stimulant purgatives
    • Diphenylmethanes: Phenolphthalein, Bisacodyl, Sodium picosulphate
    • Anthraquinones: Senna, Cascara sagrada
    • 5-HT4 agonist: Prucalopride
  • Osmotic purgatives
    • Magnesium salts: sulphate, hydroxide (option A)
    • Sodium salts: sulphate, phosphate 
    • Sod. pot. tartrate
    • Lactulose

questions.text: The direct oral factor Xa inhibitor is ______.
questions.solution:
Apixaban, a novel oral anticoagulant (NOAC) is a factor Xa inhibitor that is used in the treatment of VTE (Venous Thrombo Embolism)/DVT and in its prophylaxis after major orthopedic surgery.

Direct factor Xa inhibitors:

  • Rivaroxaban
  • Apixaban
  • Edoxaban
  • Betrixaban

Parenteral direct thrombin inhibitors:

  • Bivalirudin
  • Argatroban
  • Desirud

 Oral direct thrombin inhibitor—Dabigatran is the only oral direct thrombin inhibitor available for clinical use.

Related Pearl: Classification of Anticoagulants

Classification of anticoagulants
1) Vitamin K antagonist Warfarin
2) Direct thrombin inhibitors (DTI)   

Parenteral: Monovalent DTI- Argatroban

Bivalent DTI- Lepirudin, Desirudin, Bivalirudin

Oral: Dabigatran 
3) Indirect thrombin inhibitors 

Unfractionated heparin

Low molecular weight heparins: Enoxaparin, Dalteparin, Tinzaparin, Nadroparin
4) Indirect factor Xa inhibitors Fondaparinux
5) Oral Direct factor Xa inhibitors Rivaroxaban,Apixaban, Edoxaban,Betrixaban

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman is found to have raised serum alkaline phosphatase. Urinary examination reveals increased excretion of hydroxyproline in urine. X-ray taken in the past shows flame-shaped lesions extending along the shaft of the femur. The radiograph of the skull is given below. She has developed swelling, tenderness, and pain in her thigh for the past 2 weeks. If these symptoms and signs occur due to an underlying neoplasm, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis from the given clinical scenario is osteosarcoma secondary to an underlying Paget's disease.

Points in favour 

  • Increase in serum alkaline phosphatase indicates an increase in bone formation
  • Increased excretion of hydroxyproline in urine indicates increased bone resorption.
  • The radiograph shows ‘Cotton wool skull’ 

These points favour a diagnosis of Paget's disease

Malignant transformation to osteosarcoma should always be suspected if a previously diseased bone becomes more painful, swollen and tender in Paget's disease. Occasionally it presents as the first evidence of Paget’s disease. The prognosis is extremely grave.

questions.text: A 45-year-old chronic alcoholic with liver disease came to the hospital with complaints of distension of the abdomen. On per abdominal examination, shifting dullness was positive. Which of the following is the diuretic of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical feature and the positive shifting dullness indicate ascites, probably due to liver cirrhosis in alcoholic liver disease. The diuretic of choice in a patient with cirrhotic ascites is spironolactone.

Spironolactone is a competitive inhibitor of the mineralocorticoid receptor in the late distal tubule and collecting duct of the kidneys. It causes a decrease in sodium reabsorption and potassium excretion in the distal tubule. As a result, spironolactone promotes sodium diuresis but maintains body potassium levels. Spironolactone is particularly helpful in edematous states caused or exacerbated by hyperaldosteronism, such as in cirrhotic ascites.

Furosemide may be added, particularly in patients of ascites who have peripheral edema and are nonresponsive to spironolactone.

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with Charcot's triad?
questions.solution:
Hypotension is not a component of Charcot's triad.

Charcot's triad has all the classical presentation of cholangitis. It includes:

  • Fever
  • Right upper quadrant pain
  • Jaundice

Reynold's pentad is seen in severe cholangitis. It includes:

  • Charcot's triad
  • Hypotension
  • Altered mental status

Related Pearl: Charcot and Reynold's Triad

Charcot's triad - in acute cholangitis

  • Right upper quadrant pain
  • Fever with chills
  • Jaundice

Reynold's pentad - in acute suppurative cholangitis

  • Charcot’s triad + Altered mental status + Hypotension

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presented with diffuse thyroid swelling for the past 6 months. She says that it has increased in size over the last 1 month. Investigations reveal elevated TSH levels. Histopathological examination is done, as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture and image showing Hurthle cells are suggestive of Hashimoto's thyroiditis. 

In this condition, the following microscopic features are seen:

  • Intense lymphocytic infiltrate containing small lymphocytes, plasma cells, and well developed germinal centers
  • Atrophied thyroid follicles 
  • The epithelial cells lining the follicles contain eosinophilic granular cytoplasm (oncocytes)
    • This is called oncocytic metaplasia
    • These cells are called Hurthle cells
    • Ultrastructurally, these cells have numerous mitochondria

Hashimoto's thyroiditis is an autoimmune disease, characterized by the gradual destruction of the thyroid gland leading to thyroid failure. It is commonly seen in women between 45 to 65 years of age. It is caused by the presence of circulating autoantibodies against thyroglobulin and thyroid peroxidase.

Morphologically, there is a diffuse enlargement of the thyroid gland, with an intact capsule. It is well demarcated from the adjacent structures.

Note: Oncocytes can arise in various tissues and are referred to as follows: 

  • Hurthle cells/ Ashkenazy cells - thyroid gland
  • Oxyphilic cells - parotid gland
  • Apocrine metaplasia - breast

questions.text: Which of the following conditions has the following laparoscopic finding?
questions.solution:
The findings seen in the given laparoscopic image are powder burn spots over the peritoneum. This is seen in endometriosis.

  • Typically, there are small black dots, the so called "powder burns"/"gunshot appearance" seen on the uterosacral ligaments and pouch of Douglas.
  • Fibrosis and scarring in the peritoneum surrounding the implants is also a typical finding which is known as "Allen Masters syndrome".
  • Other subtle appearances are: red flame shaped areas, red polypoid areas, yellow brown patches, white peritoneal areas, circular peritoneal defects or subovarian adhesions.
  • These lesions are thought to be more active than the “powder burn” areas.

Other pathology in Endometriosis:

  • Peritoneal cavity: contains yellowish brown fluid which has prostaglandin repsonsible for the pain of endometriosis.
  • Ovary: "Chocolate cyst" (True cyst with columnar epithelium lining)

questions.text: Substrate level phosphorylation occurs in which of the following steps of the TCA cycle?

choices.text: Alpha keto glutarate to succinyl CoA

questions.solution:
Substrate level phosphorylation occurs when succinyl CoA gets converted to succinate in the TCA cycle.

Succinyl-CoA is converted to succinate by the enzyme succinate thiokinase or also called succinyl-CoA synthetase.

GTP formation takes place in this step, and hence this is the one and only example of substrate-level phosphorylation in the TCA cycle.

The GTP so formed is used for the decarboxylation of oxaloacetate to phosphoenolpyruvate catalysed by PEPCK in gluconeogenesis.

Related Pearl: Steps involved in TCA cycle

Step 1

Acetyl CoA + Oxaloacetate → Citrate

     (2C  + 4C  =   6C)

Enzyme: Citrate Synthase

Irreversible, Exothermic reaction
Step 2

Citrate → Cis –aconitate  → Isocitrate 

( 6C    →          6C →             6C)

Enzyme:   Aconitase

Cofactor:   Fe2+

The Reaction occurs in 2 steps:         

1st step:  Dehydration      

2nd step:  Rehydration

Inhibited by: Fluoroacetate (Non- Competitive)
Step 3

Isocitrate →[Oxalosuccinate]→α- Keto glutarate

        (6C) →         [6C]         →         (5C)

Enzyme:  Isocitrate Dehydrogenase

Cofactor:   Mn2+ or Mg2+

Reaction:  Oxidative  Decarboxylation

Intermediate:   Oxalosuccinate [ Unstable]

Release:    1 NADH and CO2
Step 4

α- Keto glutarate → Succcinyl Co A 

       (5C             →         4C)

Enzyme: α- Ketoglutarate Dehydrogenase(Multienzyme complex)

Reaction:  Oxidative Decarboxylation

Inhibited by: Arsenite  (Non – Competitive)

Physiologically unidirectional step.

Release: 1 NADH and CO2
Step 5

Succinyl- CoA  → Succinate

      ( 4C          →         4C )

Enzyme:  Succinate Thiokinase

Cofactor: Mg2+

Release:  1 ATP / GTP

Substrate level phosphorylation
Step 6

Succinate  →   Fumarate

( 4C          →         4C )

Enzyme:  Succinate Dehydrogenase (Part of 2nd complex ETC)

Cofactor:  FAD and Fe-S protein 

The only enzyme of TCA cycle attached to the inner mitochondrial membrane.

Inhibited by: Malonate ( competitive)

Release: FADH2
Step 7

Fumarate  →   Malate

( 4C         →     4C )

Enzyme:  Fumarate Hydratase

Reaction: Hydration
Step 8

Malate  →  Oxaloacetate  

( 4C     →        4C )

Enzyme:  Malate Dehydrogenase

Release:  1 NADH

Oxaloacetate is regenerated.

questions.text: A young man presents to the ER with complaints of sudden onset nausea, vomiting, and four episodes of passing loose stools. He gives a history of having food from a nearby restaurant three hours ago. Which of the following organisms is most likely implicated here?
questions.solution:
Based on the given clinical history, the patient is most likely suffering from gastroenteritis caused by Staphylococcus aureus. 

Staphylococcus causes nausea, vomiting, and diarrhoea 2-6 hrs after the consumption of contaminated food. Other organisms causing food poisoning within the same time period of 2-6 hrs are the emetic strains of Bacillus cereus.

Gastroeneteritis is caused by enterotoxin produced by S. aureus. It is a preformed toxin that is relatively heat stable while most of the other exotoxins are heat-labile. It stimulates the vagus nerve and vomiting centre of the brain and also stimulates intestinal peristaltic activity. Eight antigenic types of enterotoxin are currently known of which is Type  A toxin is responsible for most cases.

Related Pearl: Food Poisoning

Organism Symptoms Common food source

Bacillus cereus Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea Fried rice
8–16 hrs incubation period  
Clostridium perfringes Abdominal cramps, diarrhea Beef, poultry, legume, gravies
Bacillus cereus Abdominal cramps, diarrhea Meat, vegetables, dried beans, cereals
>16 hrs incubation period  
Vibrio cholerae Watery diarrhea Shellfish, water
Salmonella species Inflammatory diarrhea Beef, poultry, eggs

Enterohemorrhagic E. coli Bloody diarrhea Raw milk, raw vegetables, apple juice
Campylobacter jejuni Inflammatory diarrhea Poultry, raw milk
Shigella species Dysentery Potato, egg salad, lettuce
Vibrio parahaemolyticus Dysentery Molluscs, crustaceans

questions.text: A 22-year-old patient presented with hematuria, pedal edema, and hypertension. He also gives a history of episodes of hemoptysis in the past. His renal biopsy showed crescent formation and a linear pattern of staining on immunofluorescence. Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is this?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the renal biopsy findings suggest Goodpasture syndrome/anti-glomerular basement membrane (GBM) disease. It is a type II hypersensitivity reaction.

Type II hypersensitivity is characterized by an antigen-antibody reaction on the cell surface or in the extracellular matrix, leading to the destruction of the cells and consequent inflammation. The antibody against a specific antigen can lead to cellular destruction by either opsonization and phagocytosis or by complement activation. 

In Goodpasture syndrome, antibodies directed against the GBM also cross-react with the basement membrane of the lung's alveoli. This causes the characteristic clinical picture of pulmonary hemorrhage associated with renal failure. The antibodies are targetted against a peptide in the non-collagenous portion of the α3 chain of collagen type IV. In the kidney, anti-GBM antibodies lead to rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis, characterized by the formation of crescents. On immunofluorescence, deposition of IgG and C3 is seen in a linear pattern along the GBM. 

Related Pearl: Types of Type II Antibody-Mediated Hypersentivity

There are 3 mechanisms involved in type 2 hypersensitivity reactions- 

  1. Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction- antibodies react with antigens present on cell surfaces or in the extracellular matrix cause disease by destroying these cells, triggering inflammation, or interfering with normal functions
    1. Myasthenia gravis (against acetylcholine receptor)
    2. Graves’ disease (against TSH receptor)
    3. Pemphigus Vulgaris (against epidermal cadherin)
    4. Pernicious anemia (against intrinsic factor)
    5. Insulin resistant diabetes (against insulin receptor
  2. Antibody-mediated opsonization and phagocytosis -antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement and Recruiting Phagocytes
    1. Transfusion reactions
    2. Erythroblastosis fetalis
    3. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
    4. Autoimmune thrombocytopenic purpura
  3. Complement and Fc receptor-mediated inflammation- antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement
    1. Goodpasture syndrome
    2. Vasculitis due to ANCA
    3. Acute rheumatic fever
    4. Vascular rejection in organ graft

questions.text: In Guillain-Barre syndrome of Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (AIDP) variant, the complement deposition occurs at _______
questions.solution:
In AIDP, complement deposits along the outer surface of the Schwann cell.

Activation of complement initiates a characteristic vesicular disintegration of the myelin sheath and also leads to recruitment of activated macrophages, which participate in damage to myelin and axons.

In AMAN the complement along with IgG is deposited at the nodes of Ranvier of large motor axons.

  • AMAN-Acute motor axonal neuropathy 
  • AMSAN-Acute motor sensory axonal neuropathy

questions.text: Which of the following types of leprosy would have the following finding as its most prominent histologic feature?
questions.solution:
The finding marked with red arrows in the given image is Grenz zone and it is prominently seen in the case of lepromatous leprosy.

The Grenz zone is a narrow area of the papillary dermis uninvolved by the underlying pathology. The Grenz zone is most prominent in lepromatous leprosy as there are scarce granulomas to fill this space. It may also be seen in the borderline spectrum, but is not necessarily characteristic.

Dermal tuberculoid granulomas, consisting of groups of epithelioid cells with giant cells, are found in tuberculoid leprosy. The granulomas are elongated and generally run parallel to the surface, following neurovascular bundles. The granulomas extend up to the epidermis, thereby obscuring the Grenz zone.

Grenz zone is also seen in Granuloma faciale and B cell lymphomas.

questions.text: A young American is planning an international trip to India. He asks his family doctor about the yellow fever vaccination for his infant. From what age is the yellow fever vaccination certificate mandatory?
questions.solution:
The yellow fever vaccination certificate is mandatory for infants ≥9 months.

A yellow fever vaccination certificate is mandatory for travellers coming from endemic areas like America and African countries to India. A live attenuated, 17D strain vaccine is administered subcutaneously to the populations at risk. 

The vaccination must be given at an officially designated centre, and the certificate must be validated with the official stamp of the Indian Ministry of Health. Its validity begins after 10 days from the date of vaccination. It is valid only if it is met with the standards of the model prescribed under international health regulations.

The validity was for 10 years before, but now it is extended to lifelong after the introduction of the amendment in the World Health Assembly. If there is no certificate available, the traveller is advised to quarantine for 6 days starting from the day they left the infected area. 

Yellow fever is a zoonotic disease caused by an Arbovirus called Flavivirus fibricus. It is transmitted to man through the Aedes mosquito. The incubation period is 6 days. Clinical features are similar to hemorrhagic fevers which include jaundice, epistaxis, and melena with severe hepatic and renal involvement. 

India is a yellow fever receptive area. It is called so because we do not have yellow fever in India but conditions will allow its development if it is introduced. The virus reaches India through travellers from the infected areas and from mosquitoes that arrive through ships and aircraft from infected areas.

questions.text: A 49-year-old female presented with pain in neck, fever, malaise and firm enlargement of both lobes of the thyroid after a few days following viral fever. On investigation, thyroid antibodies were normal and serum T4 was slightly raised. The probable diagnosis is __________.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of history of viral infection, pain in the neck, and bilateral enlargement of the thyroid lobes suggests a diagnosis of granulomatous thyroiditis (subacute/de Quervain’s thyroiditis).

Granulomatous thyroiditis may follow a viral infection. In a typical subacute presentation, there is pain in the neck, fever, malaise, as well as firm and irregular enlargement of one or both lobes of the thyroid.

There may be raised inflammatory markers, absent thyroid antibodies, serum T4 may be high normal or slightly raised and I123 uptake of the gland is low.

The specific treatment for acute case with severe pain is to give prednisone 10-20 mg daily for 7 days and to gradually taper over the next month. If thyroid failure is prominent, treatment with thyroxine may be required until function recovers.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the hospital with dysphagia, stridor, and cough. On examination,a bulge is seen in the posterior pharyngeal wall on one side of the midline.The patient keeps his head extended and the neck is stiff. Likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of retropharyngeal abcess.

Acute retropharyngeal abscess is commonly seen in children below 3 years. It is the result of suppuration of retropharyngeal lymph nodes secondary to infection in the adenoids, nasopharynx, posterior nasal sinuses or nasal cavity. In adults, it may result from penetrating injury of posterior pharyngeal wall or cervical esophagus.

Dysphagia and difficulty in breathing are prominent symptoms as the abscess obstructs the air and food passages. Stridor and croupy cough may be present. Torticollis develops- the neck becomes stiff and the head is kept extended. Bulge in posterior pharyngeal wall on Xray. Usually seen on one side of the midline.

Chronic retropharyngeal abscess is tubercular in nature and is the result of

  • Caries of cervical spine
  • Tuberculous infection of retropharyngeal lymph nodes secondary to tuberculosis of deep cervical nodes.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of Gorlin syndrome?
questions.solution:
Squamous cell carcinoma is not a feature of Gorlin syndrome 

Gorlin syndrome/Basal cell naevus syndrome:

  • Mutation in PTCH gene
  • Autosomal dominant

Components:

  • Basal cell carcinomas
  • Medulloblastoma
  • Bifid ribs
  • Odontogenic keratocysts
  • Scoliosis
  • Hypertelorism

questions.text: A 40-year-old man was admitted to the hospital with difficulty in breathing. He had puffiness around the eyes, pitting edema of the lower limbs, and ascites. His 24-hour urine protein shows a protein level of 4 g/24h. CT chest shows a saddle embolus. What is the cause of this patient's CT findings?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of a diagnosis of nephrotic syndrome complicated by pulmonary embolism. Thrombo-embolic complications in nephrotic syndrome are due to the loss of endogenous anticoagulants such as antithrombin III in the urine.

Nephrotic syndrome is a condition that occurs due to damage in the glomerular capillary walls thereby leading to increased capillary permeability to plasma proteins.

The manifestations and the mechanisms of nephrotic syndrome are:

  • Massive proteinuria (>3.5 grams) as a result of leakage in the barrier formed by glomerular basement membrane, endothelium, and visceral epithelial cells.
  • Hypoalbuminemia (albumin <3g/dL) occurs as a consequence of proteinuria. Also, increased catabolism of the kidney contributes to hypoalbuminemia. 
  • Generalized edema is seen. The edema is soft and pitting seen in periorbital and dependent portions of the body. It occurs as a result of decreased intravascular colloid osmotic pressure and other factors like sodium and water retention lead to edema. 
  • Hyperlipidemia occurs following the increased synthesis of lipoproteins, lipid particles, and decreased catabolism of lipids.
  • Lipiduria is due to leakage of lipids through the glomerular capillary wall.

Increased susceptibility to infections is another complication. It is due to the loss of immunoglobulins in the urine.

The CT image below depicts a large pulmonary embolism at the pulmonary artery bifurcation (saddle embolism).

Some glomerular diseases may progress from one pattern to another or may present with considerable overlap between them, as a nephritic–nephrotic syndrome; features of nephrotic syndrome can concurrently occur with any form of nephritic syndrome but are most commonly seen with diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (seen in systemic lupus erythematosus) and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: Which of the following fibres reach the Purkinje cell directly?
questions.solution:
The fibres of inferior olivary nucleus (climbing fibres) reach the purkinje cell directly.

Note: 

The input from the Purkinje cells to the deep nuclei is inhibitory.

However, the deep nuclei output is always excitatory.

Related Pearl: Cerebellar Circuitry

Cerebellar circuitry includes:

Afferents- Climbing and mossy fibers

  • Climbing fibers -
    • Origin - contralateral inferior olivary nucleus in the medulla oblongata
    • Terminates on - Purkinje cell
  • Mossy fibers -
    • Origin - multiple sources in the spinal cord and brainstem
    • Terminates on - Granule cell

Intrinsic components

  • Granule cell backward inhibition - done by Golgi cells- prevent transmission from mossy fibers to the granule cells
  • Purkinje cells forward inhibition- done by stellate and basket cells

Efferents -

  • The output from the cerebellar cortex - from Purkinje cells inhibitory output to the deep cerebellar nuclei
  • The output from the cerebellum - from deep cerebellar nuclei
    • Globose, emboliform, and dentate - via superior cerebellar peduncle
    • Fastigial - via inferior cerebellar peduncle

questions.text: The image below depicts the structure of the HIV virus. Which of the following genes determines the core and shell of the viral structure?
questions.solution:
The given image is the structure of the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) and the gag gene determines the core and shell of the HIV virus.

It is expressed as a precursor protein, p55. This precursor protein is cleaved into three proteins, p15, p18 and p24, which make up the viral core and shell. The major core antigen is p24 which can be detected in serum during the early stages of HIV infection before antibodies appear.

HIV has structural and non-structural genes: 

Structural genes are the genes coding for structural proteins. They are

  • Gag gene: Codes for core and shell protein p55, which is cleaved to p15, p18 and p24  
  • Env gene: Codes for envelope glycoprotein gp160 which is cleaved to gp120 and gp41
  • Pol gene: Codes for the enzymes polymerase, reverse transcriptase, protease and endonuclease

Non-structural and regulatory genes:

  • tat: Trans-activating gene
  • nef: Negative factor gene
  • rev: Regulator of virus gene
  • vif: Viral infectivity factor gene
  • vpu: (only in HIV-1) and vpx (only in HIV-2)
  • vpr: Stimulates only the promoter region of the virus
  • LTR: Long terminal repeat sequences

questions.text: The biopsy of a resected inguinal mass from a patient shows marked fibrotic changes with prominent Leydig cells and hypoplastic Sertoli cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given histopathological features are strongly suggestive of cryptorchidism.

Cryptorchidism is histopathologically characterized by the following: 

  1. Testicular atrophy: thickening of the basement membrane, arrested germ cell development, marked hyalinization
  2. Tubules showing Sertoli cells but no spermatogenesis
  3. Increase in the interstitial Leydig cells. 

Cryptorchidism is the failure of the descent of the intra-abdominal testes into the scrotal sac.  It is the most common congenital abnormality of the genitourinary tract. The testes can arrest anywhere during descent, and the most common site is the inguinal region.

Phases of testicular descent:

  • Transabdominal phase: Testes come to lie in the lower abdomen or pelvis. This phase of descent is regulated by Mullerian-inhibiting substances.
  • Inguinoscrotal phase: Testes descend along the inguinal canal and reach the scrotal sac. This phase of the descent is regulated by androgen-induced calcitonin gene-related peptide from the genitofemoral nerve.

The exact pathogenesis remains unknown, however, deficiency in gonadotropins and Mullerian-inhibiting substance (MIS) and increased expression of estradiol in the placenta are thought to play a role. It is associated with testicular atrophy and dysfunction, which result in sterility. Cryptorchid testes carry a 3–5-fold higher risk for testicular cancer (usually seminoma).

questions.text: An idea intrudes the patient’s consciousness continuously leading to repetitive and purposeful behavior or acts carried out to reduce the intense distress. This act is known as _______
questions.solution:
The obsession will lead to compulsion – which is a repetitive and purposeful behavior or act carried out to reduce the intense distress. Obsession is an idea that continuously intrudes the patient's consciousness.

The characteristics of obsession are:

  • one's own thoughts.
  • ego-alien (ego-dystonic).
  • patients try to resist against it but it leads to further anxiety and distress.
  • the thought is very well known by the patient to be irrational and absurd.

 

Note:

Ego-alien/Ego-dystonic: unwanted and unaccepatable to one's own personality, causing distress.

Ego-syntonic: acceptable to one's own personality. Personality traits are usually ego-syntonic.

questions.text: A 1-year-old baby is brought to the emergency room with bluish discoloration of the skin and rapid breathing. His mother reveals a history of congenital heart disease in the baby and adds that this episode was provoked by an incessant cry. Which of the following is least likely to be used for managing this child?
questions.solution:
The least likely drug to be used for managing this child is intravenous nitroglycerin. The given scenario is suggestive of a paroxysmal hypercyanotic attack/ cyanotic spell. The administration of intravenous nitroglycerin is of no use and can worsen the condition, as it decreases peripheral resistance.

Paroxysmal hypercyanotic spells may also be referred to as tet spells/ blue spells/ hypoxic spells. Though commonly associated with Tetralogy of Fallot, they can be associated with other forms of pulmonary stenosis with ventricular septal defect as well. Precipitating factors include crying, defecation, feeding, wakening from sleep, dehydration, fever, tachycardia, tachypnea, and events provoking agitation.

They are characterized by:

  • Period of uncontrolled crying/ panic/ irritability
  • Rapid and deep breathing
  • Increased cyanosis
  • Limpness and lethargy
  • Reduced murmur intensity (signifying substantial blood flow reduction across the right ventricular outflow tract)

Management options for this child include the following:

  • Calm the child and minimize the stimuli
  • Place in the knee-chest position
  • Administer oxygen
  • Subcutaneous morphine (not in excess of 0.2mg/kg)
  • IV sodium bicarbonate - for correction of the ongoing metabolic acidosis
  • IV phenylephrine - as it increases the systemic vascular resistance
  • IV propranolol - as it reduces the pulmonary infundibular spasms in TOF
  • If the spell is resistant to all the above-said measures, then intubation and sedation of the child are required to break the spell

Related Pearl: Classification of congenital heart disease

Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA)

Coarctation of aorta

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the condition shown below:

choices.text: It is included in major degree of placenta previa
Smoking is a risk factor for development
MRI is the gold standard for diagnosis
It is a Type 2 placenta previa

questions.solution:
The given image depicts a partial/incomplete placenta previa which is Type 3 placenta previa.

Placenta previa is characterized by abnormal implantation of the placenta over the lower uterine segment.

Clinical classification of Placenta previa:

  • Minor degree (Type - I and II anterior)
  • Major degree (Type - II posterior, III and IV)

Risk Factors for Placenta Previa:

  • Prior Cesarean Delivery(Most important risk factor): Drastically increasing frequency with increasing number of cesarean deliveries
  • Previous history of placenta previa
  • Multifetal gestation: Due to larger placental area
  • Maternal age: Increasing frequency with increasing maternal age
  • Multiparity: Increasing frequency with increasing parity
  • Cigarette Smoking: Increased frequency in women who smoke (2x)
  • Elevated Prenatal Screening MSAFP Levels: Unexplained abnormally elevated prenatal screening levels of maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP) are at increased risk for previa.

The gold standard investigation would be an MRI. The sagittal images of the MRI best demonstrate the relationship of the placenta to the internal cervical os, although it is not required in most instances.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presented with a painless swelling in front of the ear as given below. On examination, his left earlobe was lifted and the curtain sign was positive. What is the mainstay treatment of this condition where only the superficial lobe is involved?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of parotid pleomorphic adenoma and the mainstay treatment in this condition is superficial parotidectomy. 

Pleomorphic adenomas are benign mixed neoplasms presenting as a painless and slow-growing swelling that lifts the ear lobe. This swelling cannot be moved above the zygomatic bone and is known as the curtain sign. 

Sometimes it may undergo malignant transformation. The malignant form is known as carcinoma ex pleomorphic adenoma. Signs of malignant transformation include:

  • A rapid increase in size
  • Pain and ulceration
  • Facial nerve involvement (LMN)
  • Lymph node involvement
  • Restricted jaw movements

Surgical intervention is done via parotidectomy. If only the superficial lobe is involved superficial parotidectomy (removal of the superficial lobe) is done. 

If both lobes are involved, total conservative parotidectomy (both lobes are removed but the facial nerve is preserved) or total radical parotidectomy (both lobes and facial nerve are removed - malignant cases) can be done. 

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: The PAGE DNA electrophoresis of the affected cell shows a step-ladder pattern. Moreover, Annexin V is positive. Which of the following molecules promote the occurrence of the type of cell death being described?
questions.solution:
A step-ladder pattern in DNA electrophoresis and positive Annexin V suggests apoptosis as the type of cell death. BAX is an pro-apoptotic factor.

The figure below represents a step ladder pattern seen in the case of apoptosis. This pattern is produced by the cleavage of genomic DNA by key apoptotic proteases-caspases. A DNA ladder is produced by the cleavage of genomic DNA between nucleosomes to generate fragments with lengths corresponding to multiple integers (approximately 180 base pairs). Annexin V is a marker for this process.

Apoptosis is defined as the programmed cell death characterized by activation of intrinsic enzymes that degrade the cells' genomic DNA, nuclear and cytoplasmic proteins.

Genes involved in the regulation of apoptosis:

  • BCL2, BCL-XL, MCL-1 are anti-apoptotic genes that keep the outer mitochondrial membrane-impermeable to death-inducing proteins. Thereby they prevent the leakage of cytochrome c and other death-inducing proteins into the cytosol.
  • BAX and BAK are pro-apoptotic factors that insert into the mitochondrial membrane and create channels that allow proteins from the inner mitochondrial membrane to leak out into the cytoplasm.
  • Initiators of apoptosis include BAD, BIM, BID, Puma, and Noxa. Their activity is upregulated and activated by sensors of cellular stress and damage.

other death lnducing proteins into
cytosol.

Stress Sensors BAD,
BIM,
BID,
Puma, Noxa		 Act as sensors of cellular stress and damage and regulate the balance
between the other two groups

questions.text: The rate of postmortem cooling is higher in which among the following situations?

choices.text: An adult body kept in a dry environment
A body with excess fat kept in a closed room
A fully clothed body kept under a blanket
A body kept in a well ventilated humid environment

questions.solution:
The rate of post mortem cooling is higher in a body kept in a well ventilated humid environment. 

Moist air is a better conductor of heat than dry air, therefore postmortem cooling is more rapid in a humid environment than dry environment. A body kept in a well ventillated room will cool more rapidly than one kept in a closed room.

Rate of cooling is slow when the body is clothed as clothes are bad conductors of heat. 

Fat is a bad conductor of heat. Fat bodies cool slowly and lean bodies cool rapidly.

Factors increasing the rate of postmortem cooling:

  • Increased difference in the temperature between body and the atmosphere
  • Large body surface area
  • Children and old aged people
  • Higher humidity and rapid air velocity
  • Body immersed in running water

Rate of cooling is decreased in:

  • Excess fat
  • Edema
  • Body covered with clothing
  • Bodies in small, ill-ventilated room

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms is predominantly responsible for an increase in the fasting plasma glucose level of patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus?
questions.solution:
In type 2 diabetes mellitus increased fasting blood sugar is predominantly due to increased hepatic gluconeogenesis.

In the postprandial period, there is a rise in peripheral blood glucose levels. Due to insulin resistance in type 2 diabetes mellitus, there is reduced peripheral uptake of glucose by insulin-sensitive tissues like the liver and skeletal muscles. This results in reduced glucose utilization by skeletal muscles as well as reduced glycogenesis in the liver and skeletal muscles. This results in increased postprandial plasma glucose levels.
Increased hepatic glucose output predominantly accounts for increased FPG levels, whereas decreased peripheral glucose utilization results in postprandial hyperglycemia.

questions.text: Which of the following is an allosteric activator of acetyl CoA carboxylase?
questions.solution:
Citrate is an allosteric activator of acetyl-CoA carboxylase.

Acetyl-CoA carboxylase is the rate-limiting enzyme in de novo fatty acid synthesis. Citrate promotes the conversion of acetyl CoA carboxylase from an inactive dimer to an active polymeric form. Its concentration increases in the well-fed state. Insulin also activates the enzyme by dephosphorylating it.

Glucagon and epinephrine promote inactivation of acetyl-CoA-carboxylase by phosphorylation of the enzyme. Long-chain acyl-CoA molecules such as palmitoyl CoA also promotes inactivation of the enzyme.

Examples of allosteric modifiers
Enzyme Allosteric inhibitor Allosteric activator
1. ALA synthase Heme -
2. Aspartate transcarbamoylase CTP ATP
3. HMG CoA reductase Cholesterol -
4.Phosphofructokinase Citrate, ATP AMP, F2,6P
5. Acetyl CoA carboxylase Acyl CoA Citrate
6. Citrate synthase ATP -
7. Carbamoyl phosphate synthase-I - NAG
8. Carbamoyl phosphate synthase-II - ATP

questions.text: In which of the following cases, vaginal birth after cesarean section (VBAC) can be considered?
questions.solution:
VBAC can be considered in case of a previous lower segment cesarean scar.

In cases where the previous cesarean section is done for some nonrecurrent indication and the uterine scar is sound, a vaginal delivery can be performed. 

Selection criteria for VBAC:

  1. One or two previous lower-segment transverse scars.
  2. Nonrecurring indication for prior cesarean section
  3. Pelvis adequate for the fetus
  4. Continuous monitoring of labor.
  5. Informed consent of the woman
  6. Sufficient personnel and equipment

Risk factors for VBAC:

  1. Classical or inverted T incision in prior cesarean
  2. Prior uterine rupture.
  3. Pelvis contracted or suspected CPD.
  4. Obstetrical contraindications such as placenta previa, malpresentation, or preeclampsia
  5. Transfundal surgery.
  6. Inadequate facilities

questions.text: The director of a hospital wishes to make improvements. Among the different management methods in health programs, he decides to use a quantitative method. Which of the following should he select?
questions.solution:
The decision-making method is a quantitative method used in the management of health programs. Hence, he should select it.

Other Options:

Option A: Division of responsibility comes under personnel management, which is a behavioral science-based method.

Options C and D are also behavioral science-based methods.

Management Methods in Health Programmes:

Network analysis- Includes Programme Evaluation and Review Technique(PERT) and Critical Path Method(CPM)

Planning–Programming–Budgeting System (PPBS)

Work sampling

Decision making

questions.text: A 29-year-old man presented with complaints of blood in his urine.  Urine analysis was positive for proteins and red cell casts.  A renal biopsy was done as shown below. Immunofluorescence microscopy revealed granular deposits of C3 on either side of the glomerular basement membrane but was negative for IgG,  C1q, and C4. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, immunofluorescence findings, and the image showing proliferating mesangial cells and capillary endothelial cells are suggestive of membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis type 2 (MPGN type 2) or dense-deposit disease. 

The following image shows bright deposits scattered along capillary walls and in the mesangium by immunofluorescence microscopy with antibodies to C3.

This condition belongs to a group of disorders called C3 glomerulopathies and primarily affects children and young adults. It is associated with a dysregulation in the alternative complement pathway. It is clinically and morphologically similar to MPGN type 1 but pathogenetically distinct from it.

In this condition, a circulating autoantibody called C3 nephritic factor is present, which stabilizes the C3 convertase enzyme. The stabilized C3 convertase enhances C3 activation and consumption causing hypocomplementemia. Patients will have consistently decreased serum C3 levels, but normal C1 and C4 levels.

The prognosis is poor, with about half of these patients progressing to end-stage renal disease (ESRD).

questions.text: A road traffic accident patient with an injury to the neck was brought to the emergency department. She had decreased sensations over the deltoid and lateral aspect of arm. The nerve root injured in this patient is _________.
questions.solution:

C2 injury leads to decreased sensation over the back of the scalp

C3 injury leads to decreased sensation over the anterior aspect of the neck

C4 injury leads to decreased sensation over the lateral aspect of the neck and inferiorly over clavicles down to the rib space

questions.text: An old woman underwent a cataract surgery one year back. Now she is complaining of blurring of vision in that operated eye for the past one month. It was gradual in onset and not associated with pain, redness, or watering. However, her vision was clear post-surgery one year back. What is the most common cause of the deterioration of the vision?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture is typical of posterior capsular opacification, which is a late complication of cataract surgery.

Posterior capsular opacification also called "after" or "secondary" cataract is the opacity that follows the extracapsular extraction of the lens. In this surgery, the posterior capsule and part of the anterior capsule are left in situ. In many cases these remnants are fine, forming a thin membrane, which is difficult to see. In other cases, especially when the cataract was not mature, some soft, clear cortex sticks to the capsule.

The rate of posterior capsule opacification following extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE) and phacoemulsification varies with the age of the patient, the surgeon, the surgical technique, the type of intraocular lens used, and the duration after surgery.

Related Pearl: Complications of cataract surgery

Early postoperative complications

Occurs within the first few days to 4 weeks.

  • Endophthalmitis
  • Retained lens matter
  • Corneal edema
  • Wound leak and dehiscence
  • Toxic anterior segment syndrome

Late postoperative complications

Occurs within months to years.

  • Posterior capsule opacification (most common)
  • Cystoid macular edema
  • Secondary glaucoma
  • Retinal detachment
  • Intraocular lens malpositions:
    • Windshield wiper syndrome— intraocular lens haptic rubs on the endothelium
    • Sunset syndrome—inferior subluxation
    • Sunrise syndrome—superior subluxation
    • Complete dislocation of the intraocular lens.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman with SLE has been on treatment for the past 2 years and had no problems. However, now she presents with fever, arthralgia and reappearance of malar rash. Urine analysis shows proteinuria which was not present at her last visit 1 month ago. She says she has been under a lot of stress at work. The rheumatologist suspects an acute flare of SLE. Which of the following laboratory findings indicate flare-up of SLE?
questions.solution:
Increased anti DS DNA titre and decreased complement level is an indicator of flare up of SLE.

questions.text: An 18-year-old patient, who appears as female phenotypically presents with complaints of amenorrhoea.  On further examination, the patient has poorly developed breasts and normal-looking female external genitalia. Ultrasound of the pelvis shows a normally developed vagina, uterus, and fallopian tubes but, the presence of ovaries could not be ensured. The karyotype of the patient was found to be 46 XY. Which of the following statements is true about the condition?

choices.text: Pregnancy is possible in these patients
This syndrome is female pseudohermaphrodite type
It is impossible to induce menstruation in these patients
Hormone replacement therapy has no role in treating them

questions.solution:
The possible diagnosis from the given symptoms and signs is 46 XY gonadal dysgenesis, Swyer syndrome. Pregnancy is possible in these patients. As they have a normal uterus, pregnancy is possible through in vitro fertilization using a donor egg.

As there is gonadal dysgenesis in these patients with 46 XY karyotype, who are actually determined to be males, the following features are seen

  • Normal development of female internal genitalia, as the poorly developed gonads, cannot produce the Anti-Mullerian Hormone(AMH).
  • Absent or poorly developed secondary sexual characters, as the default gonads, cannot produce the sex hormones.

Points to be considered while treating these patients:

  • Cyclical estrogen and progesterone can induce menstruation
  • As they have a normal uterus, pregnancy is possible through in vitro fertilization using a donor egg.
  • Tumours can develop in the streak gonads and hence they have to be removed prophylactically
  • Hormonal replacement therapy also has a role in maintaining the bone health of these patients
  • Genetic counselling has to be offered to the affected individuals and their family members.

Swyer syndrome is a type of male pseudohermaphrodite.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient was admitted to the hospital for pneumonia and quinupristin was prescribed. The antibacterial property is due to _______.

choices.text: Binding to 50s subunit of ribosomes and inhibiting protein synthesis
Binding to 30s subunit of ribosomes and inhibiting protein synthesis

questions.solution:
The antibacterial property of quinupristin is due to binding to 50s subunit of ribosomes and inhibiting protein synthesis.

Quinupristin and dalfopristin are streptogramins, which are semisynthetic derivatives of naturally occurring agents produced by Streptomyces pristinaespiralis

  • Quinupristin is streptogramin B molecule whereas dalfopristin is streptogramin A molecule.
  • Quinupristin binds to the 50s subunit of ribosomes and acts similar to macrolides by interfering in translocation and inhibiting protein synthesis.
  • Dalfopristin binds to the nearby site in 50s subunit of the ribosome and causes conformational changes that increase the activity of quinupristin. This synergic activity can have bactericidal action in certain susceptible bacteria.

questions.text: If the prevalence of trachoma follicles among 1-9 year old children is 4% in a population. What is the WHO strategy to control trachoma in that population?

choices.text: Trichiasis and entropion correction surgery, Antibiotics, Facial hygiene, Environmental cleanliness

questions.solution:
Facial hygiene and Environmental sanitation is the WHO strategy used to control trachoma in a population with prevalence of trachoma follicles <5% among 1-9-year-old children.

Related Pearl: WHO Programme to Control Trachoma: SAFE Strategy

  • S—Surgery: Trichiasis and entropion correction surgery → 3° prevention.
  • A—Antibiotics: Oral azithromycin, topical 1% tetracycline, topical 1% azithromycin → 2° prevention
  • F—Facial hygiene → 1° prevention.
  • E—Environmental cleanliness → primordial prevention

The strategy depends on the prevalence of trachoma follicle in children (aged 1–9 yrs)

  • >10% → Mass antibiotic treatment at the community level and FE measures
  • 5 to 10% → Targeted antibiotic treatment (affected families) and FE measures
  • < 5% → FE measures

questions.text:
Match the following type of fractures with their associated mechanism of force.
1. Transverse fracture  a. Compression
2. Oblique fracture b. Twisting
3. Butterfly fragment c. Tension
4. Spiral fracture d. Bending
questions.solution:
The correct match is:

Type of fracture Mechanism of force
Transverse fracture  Tension
Oblique fracture Compression
Butterfly fragment Bending
Spiral fracture Twisting


Most fractures occur due to a combination of forces, but the dominant mechanism of force is revealed by the type of fracture. 

Based on the continuity of the periosteum, fractures can be complete or incomplete. 

In complete fractures, the bone is split into two or more fragments and continuity of periosteum is disrupted. It can be:

  • Impacted fracture - The fracture fragments are jammed together and the fracture line is not visible
  • Comminuted fracture - There is a fracture of more than two fragments
  • Segmental fracture - A separated fragment is seen in the middle
  • Avulsion fracture - Breaking of a piece of bone attached to a strong muscle. e.g. olecranon and patella fracture

In incomplete fractures, the bone is incompletely split and the periosteum remains in continuity. They include:

  • Greenstick fractures: The outer cortex breaks and the inner cortex bends causing the bone to buckle like the snapping of a green twig. It is seen in the pediatric population. 
  • Compression fractures: Cancellous bone crumple due to force. This is typically seen in vertebral bodies, calcaneum, and the tibial plateau.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient is newly diagnosed to have plaque psoriasis, with no associated features of psoriatic arthritis. The dermatologist has graded the disease to be moderate type, based on the Psoriasis area severity index (PASI). Which of the following can be instituted as first-line therapy to manage his condition?
questions.solution:
Phototherapy with narrowband UV-B is the recommended first-line therapy in this patient, as he has moderate psoriasis without arthritis.

Psoriasis Area Severity Index (PASI) is the grading of erythema, scaling and induration in different regions of the body and gives a combined score ranging from 0 to 72.

Related Pearl: Treatment Ladder for Psoriasis

Treatment Ladder for Psoriasis

I. In Mild Psoriasis Without Arthritis

First line

  • Coal tar
  • Dithranol
  • Potent topical steroid
  • Vitamin D analogue

Second line

  • Local NB-UVB or PUVA
  • Excimer laser

II. In Moderate or Severe Psoriasis Without Arthritis

First line

  • NB-UVB or PUVA

Second line

  • Acitretin
  • Apremilast
  • Ciclosporin
  • Fumaric acid esters (where available)
  • Methotrexate

Third line

  • Adalimumab
  • Etanercept
  • Infliximab
  • Secukinumab
  • Ustekinumab

III. In Moderate or Severe Psoriasis with Psoriatic Arthritis

First line

  • Apremilast
  • Methotrexate

Second line

  • Adalimumab
  • Etanercept
  • Infliximab
  • Ustekinumab

Third line

  • Combination therapy

questions.text: A patient on long-term voriconazole needs to have periodic check-ups to detect which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Skin cancer surveillance is recommended for patients taking voriconazole. Photosensitivity and rash is a common side effect of the drug. However, voriconazole can cause cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma and melanoma and hence surveilance is recommended. Other important side effects are hepatotoxicity and visual disturbances. 

Note: Voriconazole is a an azole antifungal, which acts by inhibiting ergosterol synthesis for the fungal cell membrane. Azoles are fungistatic, not fungicidal.

questions.text: A 23-year-old G2P1 lady with a previous history of cesarean section was found to have placenta accreta on ultrasonography. Imperfect development of which layer leads to this condition?
questions.solution:
Imperfect development of the Nitabuch layer, which is marked as 1 in the given image, leads to placenta accreta.

The other structures marked in the image are: 2 and 4 are cytotrophoblast and 3 is inner syncytiotrophoblast. 

Placenta accreta is a condition in which the placenta is directly attached to the myometrium either partially or completely without any intervening decidua. This abnormal attachment to myometrium is due to the partial or total absence of the decidua basalis and imperfect development of the Nitabuch layer.

The definitive placenta consists of the chorionic plate on the fetal aspect and a basal plate on the maternal aspect with the intervillous space between them. The structures in each of these parts are as follows: 

Morbidly adherent placenta (MAP) occurs when the placenta fails to detach from the uterine wall and these include: 

  • Placenta accreta - villi are attached to the myometrium
  • Placenta increta - villi invade the myometrium
  • Placenta percreta - villi penetrate through the myometrium and to or through the serosa

The image given below shows different types of morbidly adherent placenta.

Risk factors for MAP include prior cesarean delivery, placenta previa, prior uterine surgeries like hysterotomy, prior curettage, and endometrial ablation.

Ultrasound imaging, color doppler, and MRI have all been helpful in the diagnosis of MAP during pregnancy.

Management:

  • Partial placenta accreta - placental tissue is removed and bleeding areas are oversewed.
  • Total placenta accreta - 
    • Parous women - hysterectomy is done 
    • If the patient desires to have a child - the umbilical cord is cut close to its base so that the placenta left behind gets autolyzed
  • If MAP invades the bladder, hysterectomy and partial cystectomy are required.

questions.text: Which of the following is a long-acting beta 2 agonist?
questions.solution:
Formoterol is a long-acting beta 2 agonist (LABA).

Long-acting β2-selective agonists (LABA) have a 12-hour duration of action. These drugs have a high lipid solubility and hence dissolve in the smooth muscle cell membrane in high concentrations. Due to their lack of anti-inflammatory action, they are always used in combination with inhalational corticosteroids and are not effective as monotherapy.

β2 receptor agonists are used in the treatment of asthma and COPD. They relax bronchial smooth muscle and decrease airway resistance by acting on the pulmonary receptors. They also reduce the release of leukotrienes and histamine from mast cells in lung tissue, increase mucociliary function, decrease microvascular permeability, and inhibit phospholipase A2. 

Beta 2 agonists are classified based on their duration of action into short-acting, long-acting and very long-acting beta 2 agonists.

Short-acting beta 2 agonists (SABA) are:

  • Salbutamol
  • Terbutaline 
  • Pirbuterol
  • Metaproterenol

Long-acting beta 2 agonists (LABA) are:

  • Salmeterol
  • Formoterol

Very long-acting beta 2 agonists (V-LABA) are:

  • Indacaterol
  • Olodaterol
  • Vilanterol

questions.text: A 46-year-old male presents with six months of persistent cough and coughing up food remnants shortly after consumption. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy and barium swallow showed a proximal esophageal diverticulum. During surgery, it was noticed that the diverticulum arises from the posterior upper esophagus below the cricopharyngeus. What is the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Based on this patient's clinical findings, the patient has a Laimer's diverticulum.

Laimer's diverticulum occurs posteriorly below cricopharyngeus and above the longitudinal muscle layer of the esophagus. It arises within the Laimer's triangle. 

Related Pearl: Pharyngo-esophageal diverticula

Posteriorly below cricopharyngeus and above longitudinal muscle layer of the esophagus
Killian– Jamieson Diverticulum Killian–Jamieson area

questions.text: Stimulation of which of the following structures causes a decrease in RR interval?
questions.solution:
The Right Stellate ganglion stimulation causes decrease in the R-R interval in the ECG as it increases heart rate.

Related Pearl: Effect of the Autonomic Nervous System on Heart

Inhibits SA node

Decreases the heart rate

Left vagus

Inhibits AV node

Slow AV conduction

Right Stellate ganglion

Stimulates SA node

Increases the heart rate

Shortened AV conduction time

questions.text: An experienced pathologist confirmed the biopsy specimen taken from the tumor to have pleomorphic changes. What does pleomorphism refer to?

choices.text: Variation in cell size and shape
Replacement of one type of cell by other

questions.solution:
Pleomorphism refers to a variation in the size and shape of the cells.

Other morphological features of malignancy:

  • Anaplasia refers to a lack of differentiation.

  • Increased N:C ratio: The nuclei are disproportionately large for the cell. In normal cells, the nuclear-cytoplasmic ratio is 1:4, whereas it becomes 1:1 in malignant cells.

  • Hyperchromasia: Coarsely clumped and darkly stained chromatin within irregular nuclei.

  • Increased mitosis: Atypical, bizarre mitotic figures, sometimes with tripolar, quadripolar, or multipolar spindles

  • Loss of polarity: Sheets or large masses of tumor cells grow in an anarchic, disorganized fashion.

The term anaplasia means to form backward implying a reversal of differentiation to a more primitive level.

questions.text: Which among the following organisms show stately motility?
questions.solution:
Clostridium shows stately motility.

Clostridia have peritrichate flagella and motility is slow, described as stately. Of the Clostridium species, Clostridium perfringens and Clostridium tetani type VI are non-motile.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man sustained a roller crush injury of his left arm up to mid-humerus and was brought to the casualty. The duty orthopedician uses the MESS score to decide about limb salvage. The score does not include which of the following?
questions.solution:
Neurogenic injury is not included in the Mangled Extremity Severity Score (MESS).

The Mangled Extremity Severity Score (MESS) is useful in deciding about limb salvage.

The components of the Mangled Extremity Severity score are:

  • The energy that caused the injury, skeletal and soft tissue injury
  • Limb ischemia
  • Shock
  • Age of the patient.

Related Pearl: Mangled Extremity Severity Score
