MESS score of < 7 is usually associated with salvageable limb.

MESS score of ≥ 7 is usually associated with the requirement of limb amputation.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is diagnosed with Duchenne muscular dystrophy. Genetic analysis showed dystrophin mutation in the promoter region. What could be the most likely effect of this mutation?

choices.text: Tailing of dystrophin mRNA is defective
Capping of dystrophin mRNA is defective
Termination of dystrophin transcription is defective
Initiation of dystrophin transcription is defective

questions.solution:
The initiation of dystrophin transcription is defective.

The fidelity and frequency of transcription is controlled by proteins bound to certain DNA sequences termed as promoters, and it is the base-specific association of RNA Polymerase with promoters that ensures accurate initiation of transcription. The promoter recognition-utilization process is the target for regulation in both bacteria and humans.

questions.text: Which of the following is evaluated as a part of the first-trimester aneuploidy screening test for Down syndrome?
questions.solution:
Pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A) is evaluated as a part of the combined first-trimester aneuploidy screening test.

First-trimester Aneuploidy Screening at 11-14 weeks of gestation includes:

  • β-HCG
  • Pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A)
  • Nuchal translucency scan  

Fetal trisomy 21 causing Down syndrome has higher levels of hCG and lower PAPP-A. With trisomy 18 and trisomy 13, levels of both hCG and PAPP-A are lower.

Second-trimester aneuploidy screening at 15-21 weeks includes

  • β-HCG        
  • Maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP)         
  • Unconjugated estriol        
  • Inhibin A

questions.text: Which of the following structures pass through the opening marked in the diagram below?
questions.solution:
The anterior interosseous artery passes through the opening in the interosseous membrane.

The anterior interosseous artery passes distally along the anterior aspect of the interosseous membrane and supplies muscles of the deep compartment of the forearm, radius, and ulna.

Perforating the interosseous membrane in the distal forearm, the anterior interosseous artery terminates by joining the posterior interosseous artery.

The image given below shows anterior interosseous artery.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man complains of colicky abdominal pains and frequent bowel movements. Diarrhea associated with tenesmus and heme-positive stool is seen. Colonic epithelium shows the following findings on biopsy. What is the most likely cause of this disease?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features and biopsy is suggestive of amoebiasis caused by Entamoeba histolytica. 

The biopsy shows flask-shaped ulcers typical of amoebiasis.

In amoebiasis, amoeba attach themselves to the colonic epithelium, induces apoptosis, invade crypts, and burrow laterally into the lamina propria. This recruits neutrophils and causes tissue damage, resulting in flask-shaped ulcers with a narrow neck and broad base.

Clinical manifestations:

  • Amebic Colitis
    • Colicky abdominal pains and frequent bowel movements.
    • Diarrhea associated with tenesmus and heme-positive stool.
    • Trophozoites invade the intestinal mucosa, produce flask-shaped ulcers.
  • Amebic Liver Abscess
    • Fever is the hallmark of amebic liver abscess
    • It is associated with abdominal pain, abdominal distention, and enlargement and tenderness of the liver.
    • Changes at the base of the right lung, such as elevation of the diaphragm and atelectasis or effusion, may also occur.
    • The most common finding is a single abscess in the right hepatic lobe, detected on ultrasonography,computed tomography, or magnetic resonance imaging.

questions.text: What is the equilibrium potential for sodium-ion calculated by using the Nernst equation for a spinal motor neuron?
questions.solution:
The equilibrium potential for Na+ is +60mV.

For Na+ both electrical and the concentration gradient is directed inward. So, one would expect the cell to gain Na+. But the intracellular concentration of Na+remains constant because:

  • The activity of Na+- K+ ATPase pumps out 3 Na+ in exchange for 2 K+ 
  • Selective permeability of the membrane.

 K+ +1  -90

-1

-70

+2

+130

Mg2+

+2

+9

questions.text:
The stool culture of a patient with suspected food poisoning produced hemolytic colonies on blood agar. The isolated organism gave a positive indole test and a positive MUG test. You observe the following colonies on eosin methylene blue agar. Identify the organism.

MUG - 4-methylumbelliferyl-β-glucuronide
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a patient with suspected food poisoning with stool culture growing hemolytic colony on blood agar with a positive indole test and MUG test with a iridescent green colony growth on eosin methylene blue agar is characteristic of Escherichia coli. 

E. coli produces the enzyme β-glucuronidase which is tested using the MUG test. In it, the substrate MUG (4-methylumbelliferyl-β-glucuronide) is reduced by the enzyme to produce a fluorescent color which indicates a positive MUG test.

questions.text: The transvaginal ultrasound of a pregnant woman is given below. What are the cutoff values of the parameters marked A and B for a diagnosis of cervical incompetence?
questions.solution: In the given image, the parameter marked A is funnelling of the internal os and the parameter marked B is cervical length. Funnelling of internal os and cervical length <25 mm are diagnostic of cervical incompetence on transvaginal ultrasound.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male sustained a fracture of the neck of femur and he was planned for replacement surgery. Identify the prosthesis in the given image:
questions.solution:
The given image shows the Austin-Moore prosthesis. The Austin-Moore prosthesis is used for hemiarthroplasty in the neck of femur fracture in elderly individuals. 

The Austin-Moore prosthesis has a head, neck, and stem. The stem has a hole to which the hook of the extractor can be attached. It helps in removing the prosthesis. There are two fenestrations in the stem which are for bone growth and fixing the prosthesis. It can be used without cement since its usage makes the removal difficult. 

The below image shows Austin Moore's prosthesis.

Other options:

Option A: Thompson prosthesis is used in hemiarthroplasty to replace the head of the femur. It is specially indicated in cases where the neck of the femur is absorbed. It can be used with or without cement.

The below image shows the radiograph image of Thompson's prosthesis.

Option C: Charnley's prosthesis is a total hip prosthesis used to replace the acetabulum and the head of the femur. it contains a polyethylene acetabulum cup and a steel head with a diameter of 22 mm. The radiograph image is shown below.

Option D: Muller's prosthesis is also a total hip prosthesis but the size of the head differs (32 mm) and the stem is available in different thicknesses.

questions.text: Regarding the swimming pool sanitation, how much percent of water needs to be replaced every day with freshwater?
questions.solution:
About 15% of the water should be replaced with fresh water every day.

The reason for water replacement is to remove solutes consisting of ammonia, albuminoid, organic, and nitrates derived from the bathers. These solutes have the capacity to reduce the bactericidal activity of chlorine.

Swimming pool sanitation:

  • Bacteriological quality of water has to be close to the drinking standards.
  • Recommended area of minimum of 2.2 m2 per person.
  • The filtering should be continuous such that all the water is re-filtered in less than 6 hours
  • Rapid sand filters must be used.
  • The free residual chlorine level has to be 1 mg/litre (1 ppm)
  • The pH of the water must be 7.4 - 7.8

questions.text: In the syndromic management of sexually transmitted infections, the grey kit consists of __________
questions.solution:
In the syndromic management of sexually transmitted infections, the grey kit consists of T.Azithromycin and T.Cefixime

The color coded packs are as follows:

  • Kit 1– Grey, for urethra discharge, anorectal discharge, and cervicitis.
  • Kit 2– Green, for vaginitis
  • Kit 3– White, for genital ulcers
  • Kit 4– Blue, for genital ulcers.
  • Kit 5– Red, for genital ulcers.
  • Kit 6– Yellow, for lower abdominal pain
  • Kit 7– Black, for inguinal bubo

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in Nothnagel's syndrome?

choices.text: Ipsilateral occulomotor nerve palsy and contralateral cerebellar ataxia
Ipsilateral occulomotor nerve palsy and contralateral tremor, chorea and athetosis
Ipsilateral occulomotor nerve palsy with contralateral ataxia, tremor, chorea and athetosis
Ipsilateral occulomotor nerve palsy and contralateral hemiparesis

questions.solution:
In Nothnagel’s syndrome, injury to the superior cerebellar peduncle causes ipsilateral oculomotor palsy and contralateral cerebellar ataxia.

Injury to the structures surrounding fascicles of the oculomotor nerve descending through the midbrain results in the following syndromes

  • In Benedikt’s syndrome, injury to the red nucleus results in ipsilateral oculomotor palsy and contralateral tremor, chorea, and athetosis.
  • Claude’s syndrome incorporates features of both of these syndromes, by injury to both the red nucleus and the superior cerebellar peduncle.
  • Weber’s syndrome, injury to the cerebral peduncle causes ipsilateral oculomotor palsy with contralateral hemiparesis.

 

Related Pearl: Medullary syndromes and Weber syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following parameters would you use to check the efficiency of the surveillance system for malaria under the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme?
questions.solution:
The Annual Blood Examination Rate (ABER) is used to check the efficiency of the surveillance system for malaria. It takes into account the number of slides examined for the population under surveillance.

World Malaria Day is conducted on April 25 every year.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man came to the OPD with blurred vision. His fundus examination was done. The fundus appearance is as shown in the image given below. This appearance is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The fundus image shows a Bayoneting sign in the optic disc, which is seen in the advanced stages of glaucoma.

In glaucoma, due to the loss of neuroretinal rim tissue, nasal shifting of retinal vessels occurs, giving the vessels the appearance of being broken off at the margin. This leads to sharp angulation of vessels at the margin of the excavated cup, known as the bayoneting sign.

Glaucomatous changes in the optic disc:

Early glaucomatous changes

  • Slit defects of the retinal nerve fiber layer
  • Splinter hemorrhages on disc margin
  • Large cup: 0.7 or more
  • Asymmetry of the cups: A difference equal to or more than 0.2 between two eyes is significant
  • Vertical oval cup

Advanced glaucomatous changes

  • Marked cupping (Beanpot cupping)
  • Thinning of neuroretinal rim
  • Bayoneting sign
  • Laminar dot sign

questions.text: Which of the following is a bioterrorism category C agent?
questions.solution:
Hantavirus is a Bioterrorism category C agent.

Hanta and Nipah viruses are emerging pathogens that could be engineered for mass dissemination in the future because of availability, ease of production, dissemination, the potential for high morbidity and mortality rates, and major health impact.

questions.text: A man presented with slurred speech and festinating shuffling gait. He tells that a course of levodopa was advised by his previous doctor but didn't show any effect. Which of the following mineral toxicity/ deficiency causes such features?
questions.solution:
Manganese toxicity can cause secondary parkinsonism with features similar to atypical parkinsonism.

Secondary parkinsonism is characterized by Parkinson-like disease caused by agents/factors that cause basal ganglia dysfunction. These factors include drugs (tetrabenazine, metoclopramide, neuroleptics, flunarizine), stroke, tumor, infection, or toxins. Clinical features will be based on the region of the basal ganglia that has been damaged.

Toxins such as carbon monoxide or manganese produce damage to the globus pallidus, and hence present with features resembling atypical parkinsonism such as:

  • Early speech and gait impairment
  • Repeated early falls
  • Absence of rest tremor
  • No motor asymmetry
  • Poor or no response to levodopa
  • Aggressive clinical course
  • Symptoms of severe early autonomic involvement

Manganese deficiency on the other hand can result in poor growth, bone demineralization, ataxia, convulsions, and abnormalities in carbohydrate and lipid metabolism.

Other options

Option A: Selenium deficiency causes Keshan disease (cardiomyopathy in endemic regions of China); Excess selenium intake leads to selenosis (with hair loss, brittle nails, garlic breath odor, myopathy, and neurologic symptoms).

Option B: Zinc toxicity leads to nausea, vomiting, headache, fever, and hypersalivation. Zinc deficiency causes dwarfism, hypogonadism, hypopigmented hair, hypogeusia, and impaired immunity.

Option D: Hypomagnesemia is characterized by neurologic symptoms like tremors, muscle weakness, ataxia, delirium, and psychosis. Hypermagnesemia causes lethargy, weakness, hypotonia, weak tendon reflexes, and coma.

questions.text: A patient was incidentally found to have essential fructosuria. Which of the following enzymes is deficient in this condition?
questions.solution:
Essential fructosuria is due to the deficiency of the enzyme hepatic fructokinase. It is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.

This defective degradation does not cause any clinical symptoms. Fructose is either excreted unchanged in the urine or metabolized to fructose-6-phosphate by alternate pathways in the body, most commonly by hexokinase in adipose tissue and muscle.

No treatment is indicated for essential fructosuria.

The flowchart given below depicts fructose metabolism.

questions.text: On giving a patient insulin, which of the following is expected to occur first?

choices.text: Increased transport of K+ into adipocytes

questions.solution:
Increased transport of K+ into adipocytes will occur first on giving an injection of insulin. 

Based on time on onset, actions of insulin are classified as:

Rapid (seconds): Increased permeability, leading to:

  • Increased transport of glucose, amino acids, and K+ into insulin sensitive cells

Intermediate (minutes): Changes in activity levels of intracellular enzymes, leading to:

  • Stimulation of protein synthesis
  • Inhibition of protein degradation
  • Activation of glycolytic enzymes and glycogen synthase
  • Inhibition of phosphorylase and gluconeogenic enzymes

Delayed (hours to days): Changed rates of transcription of DNA, leading to: 

  • Increase in mRNAs for lipogenic and other enzymes

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with anorexia nervosa. All of the following lab findings can be associated except :
questions.solution:
Hypocholestrolemia is not seen in anorexia nervosa.

Anorexia Nervosa is a syndrome characterized by significant self-induced starvation, a morbid fear of weight gain, and the presence of medical signs and symptoms of starvation.

Investigations in anorexia nervosa:

  • Complete blood count: Leukopenia with a relative lymphocytosis
  • Serum electrolyte: Hypokalemic alkalosis (purging)
  • Fasting serum glucose: Often low (emaciated phase)
  • Serum salivary amylase: Often elevated (if the patient is vomiting)
  • ECG: ST-segment and T-wave changes (secondary to electrolyte disturbances)
  • Hypotension and bradycardia
  • High serum cholesterol level
  • Endocrine changes (caused by the underweight):
    • Amenorrhea
    • Hypothyroidism
    • Hypersecretion of corticotrophin-releasing hormone

questions.text: While undergoing contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) of the abdomen, a patient develops urticaria, dizziness, bronchospasm, and hypotension 10 minutes after the administration of the iodinated radiocontrast dye. This is the first time that the patient is undergoing a CECT and an anaphylactoid reaction was suspected. Which of the following statements is false about this condition?

choices.text: It involves degranulation of mast cells.
It can occur on first exposure
It is most commonly caused by NSAIDs.

questions.solution:
The clinical features of urticaria, dizziness, bronchospasm, and hypotension a short while after administration of the iodinated radiocontrast dye on first exposure are suggestive of an idiosyncratic anaphylactoid reaction. Anaphylactoid reactions are not IgE mediated.

These reactions are caused by direct degranulation of the mast cells or basophils, which causes the release of mediators. Unlike the classic anaphylaxis, which occurs on re-exposure to the allergen, the anaphylactoid reaction can occur even on the first exposure.

The most common agents that can cause an anaphylactoid reaction include NSAIDs and radiocontrast media.

Non-IgE-mediated mast cell activation in response to certain drugs can not be clinically distinguished from classical IgE-mediated hypersensitivity reactions (anaphylaxis). However, non-IgE mediated reactions can occur with the first known exposure. This is because mast cells do not need sensitization by IgE.

Note: The term 'anaphylactoid reaction' is no longer recommended by the World Allergy Organization (WAO), and has been replaced by 'non-immunologic anaphylaxis.'

In 2014, WAO has introduced two new terms:

  • Immunologic anaphylaxis: It includes anaphylactic reactions mediated by IgE, IgG (in animals), and immune complex/complement-mediated reactions.
  • Non-immunologic anaphylaxis: It includes reactions caused by agents which cause massive degranulation of mast cells or basophils in the absence of immunoglobulin.

 

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Hypersensitivity Reactions

Type

Immune Mechanisms

Histopathological lesions

Immediate
 hypersensitivity
(type I)

  • Anaphylaxis
  • Allergies
  • Bronchial asthma
  • Atopic dermatitis

Production of IgE antibody →immediate release of vasoactive amines from mast cells

Vascular dilatation, edema, smooth muscle contraction, mucus production, tissue injury, inflammation

Antibody-mediated hypersensitivity
(type II)

  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
  • Goodpasture syndrome

(type IV)

  • Contact dermatitis

questions.text: Which of the following is mainly a responsibility of the health worker male?
questions.solution:
Malaria surveillance is mainly a responsibility of the health worker male, whereas health worker female is also responsible for DOTS activities and ASHA workers are also involved in immunization and spreading awareness about contraception.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids is a component of pantothenic acid?
questions.solution:
The amino acid present in pantothenic acid is beta-alanine.

Pantothenic acid (vitamin B5) is an essential nutrient that plays a crucial role in metabolism. It is a key component of coenzyme A (CoA), which is involved in numerous biochemical reactions, particularly in transferring acyl groups.

Functions of Pantothenic Acid in the Body:

  • Facilitates fatty acid oxidation and synthesis.
  • Involved in the formation of succinyl-CoA and acetyl-CoA, essential intermediates in the Krebs cycle.
  • Precursor to HMG-CoA, which is crucial for cholesterol synthesis.
  • CoA participates in acetylation, which modifies proteins, neurotransmitters, and drugs.

The intestinal gut flora synthesizes vitamin B5, so deficiency is rare. Grierson-Gopalan's burning foot syndrome is a rare disorder caused by pantothenic acid deficiency. Its clinical features include burning pain and paresthesia in the lower extremities, staggering gait due to impaired coordination, and sleep disturbance.

Other Options:

Option A: Phenylalanine is an essential amino acid involved in dopamine and melanin synthesis.

Option B: Tryptophan is a precursor for serotonin, melatonin, and niacin (Vitamin B3).

Option D: Arginine is involved in the urea cycle and nitric oxide (NO) synthesis.

questions.text: A senior resident working in an intensive care unit has assembled the following equipment to perform a procedure. Which of the following procedures he would be performing?
questions.solution:
From the materials which have been gathered by the senior resident, it can be inferred that he would be performing a central venous catheterization.

The image below shows the equipment for performing a central venous catheterization.

The instruments are numbered as follows:

  1. A syringe with a local anesthetic
  2. Scalpel in case venous cutdown is needed
  3. Introducer needle on the syringe with saline to detect backflow of blood upon vein penetration
  4. Guidewire
  5. Tissue dilator
  6. An indwelling catheter
  7. Additional fasteners, and corresponding surgical thread

The catheter can be inserted into any of the following veins - Right and internal jugular veins, subclavian vein, external jugular veins, and femoral vein.

Indications of central venous catheterization include

  • Central venous pressure monitoring
  • Pulmonary artery catheterization and monitoring
  • Transvenous cardiac pacing
  • Temporary hemodialysis
  • Drug administration (concentrating vasoactive drugs, hyperalimentation, chemotherapy, agents irritating peripheral veins, prolonged antibiotic therapy)
  • Rapid infusion of fluids
  • Aspiration of air emboli
  • Inadequate peripheral venous access
  • Sampling site for repeated blood testing

Complications of central vein catheterization are

  • Arterial puncture - This is the most common mechanical complication. 
  • Cardiac tamponade - This is the most important life-threatening complication. It occurs as a result of puncture of intrapericardial superior vena cava, right atrium, or right ventricle.
  • Pneumothorax - This is more common in subclavian vein catheterization as a result of injury to the underlying pleura.
  • Chylothorax - This can occur particularly in left subclavian vein catheterization. But it is not the most common.
  • Injury to the associated nerves - like brachial plexus, stellate ganglion, phrenic nerve, or vocal cords.
  • Thromboembolism - This can lead to venous thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. It is more common with femoral veins.
  • Infections - most common late complication.

The image below shows central venous catheterization

Image showing pigtail catheter with locking string, obturator, and the puncture needle is given below.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman who is a chronic smoker had recurrent retroareolar infections and abscesses. The condition she is suffering from is________.
questions.solution:
Zuska’s disease, also called recurrent periductal mastitis, is a condition of recurrent retro areolar infections and abscesses. Smoking has been implicated as a risk factor for this condition. Managed symptomatically by antibiotics coupled with incision and drainage as necessary.

Other options: 

Option A: Tietze’s Syndrome is a benign inflammation of one or more costal cartilages.

Option B: Mondor’s disease is thrombophlebitis of the superficial veins of the breast and anterior chest wall.

Option D: Paget's disease of the nipple is a superficial manifestation of underlying breast carcinoma. It presents as an eczema-like condition of the nipple

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes are found to be deficient in Hyperammonemia Type 2 and 1 respectively?

choices.text: Ornithine Transcarbamoylase and Carbamoyl Phosphate Synthetase 2
Carbamoyl Phosphate Synthetase 2 and Ornithine Transcarbamoylase
Ornithine Transcarbamoylase and Carbamoyl Phosphate Synthetase 1
Carbamoyl Phosphate Synthetase 1 and Ornithine Transcarbamoylase

questions.solution:
Ornithine Transcarbamoylase and Carbamoyl Phosphate Synthetase 1 are found to be deficient in Hyperammonemia Type 2 and 1 respectively.

  • Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I is the rate-limiting enzyme of the urea cycle. It utilises CO2, ammonia, and 2ATPs to form carbamoyl phosphate. Deficiency in CPS1 results in hyperammonemia type 1.
  • All urea cycle disorders are autosomal recessive except hyperammonemia type 2 which is X-linked recessive.

Note : 

CPS II combines CO2 + Glutamine + ATP to form carbamoyl phosphate which is used in the biosynthetic pathway for pyrimidine nucleotides.

Related Pearl: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man presents with painless generalized lymphadenopathy and weakness. The biopsy findings of H&E staining and immunohistochemistry for BCL2 are given in the images below. The results of immunophenotyping of the cells are as follows: CD19+, CD20+, CD10+, and CD5-. What is the translocation seen in this disease?

H&E: Hematoxyline and eosin
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of follicular lymphoma. The majority of follicular lymphomas have the characteristic t(14;18) translocation.

Follicular lymphoma presents in middle age with no sex predilection. The most common presenting symptom is painless generalized lymphadenopathy. A lymph node biopsy is adequate for the diagnosis of follicular lymphoma. Immunophenotyping of the cells showing CD19, CD20, CD10, BCL2 positive, and CD5 negative is suggestive that the cells originate from the germinal center.

This chromosomal rearrangement results in the overexpression of BCL2 protein, which is an inhibitor of apoptosis that contributes to cell survival.

On histopathology, the lymph nodes exhibit a nodular or nodular and diffuse growth pattern. Two cell types are predominantly present in varying proportions: 

  • Centrocytes (small cleaved cells) - small cells with a cleaved nucleus and scant cytoplasm
  • Centroblasts - large cells with open nuclear chromatin, several nucleoli, and modest amounts of cytoplasm

In most cases, there is a majority of centrocytes.

Other options:

Option B: t(9;22) results in Philadelphia chromosome, which causes chronic myeloid leukemia.

Option C: t(8;14) is seen in Burkitt lymphoma.

Option D: t(11,14) is seen in mantle cell lymphoma.

questions.text: Which of the following methods is used to demonstrate the oxygen requirements of the bacterium?
questions.solution:
The culture method used to demonstrate the oxygen requirements of a bacterium is stab culture. It is also used for demonstrating other properties like gelatin liquefaction. 

The image below shows stab culture. It is prepared by puncturing a suitable medium with a long, straight, charged wire. The oxygen-requiring bacteria will grow on the surface, and the bacteria that do not require oxygen will grow at the bottom.

Other methods used in bacterial culture:

  • Lawn culture/carpet culture: It is used for bacteriophage typing and antibiotic sensitivity testing. It is prepared by flooding the surface of the plate with a liquid culture.
  • Streak culture: It is routinely used for the isolation of bacteria in pure culture from clinical specimens. It is prepared by picking the specimen using platinum loops or straight wires and transferring it onto a well-dried plate. The inoculum is then distributed thinly over the plate by streaking it with the loop in a series of parallel lines, in different segments of the plate.
  • Pour plate culture: It gives an estimate of viable bacterial count in a suspension. It is prepared by adding appropriate dilutions of the inoculum (of 1 ml) to the molten (40-45°C) agar, which is mixed and poured into sterile petri dishes. After incubation, colonies are seen to be distributed throughout the depth of the medium. 
  • Liquid culture: These are preferred for inocula containing antibiotics and other inhibitory substances. It is prepared by inoculating liquid cultures in tubes, bottles, or flasks by touching with a charged loop, pipettes or syringe. 

Related Pearl: Organisms and selective Culture Media

questions.text: An elderly diabetic female patient presented with a black, foul-smelling discharge from the nose. On examination, blackish necrotic mass filling the nasal cavity and eroding the septum and hard palate. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis.

Mucormycosis is an opportunistic infection caused principally by species of Rhizopus, Mucor, and Lichtheimia. The most prevalent species is Rhizopus Oryza.  It commonly occurs in patients with diabetes mellitus and immunocompromised individuals.

Rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis is the most common form of mucormycosis.

The presenting features are facial pain, numbness, loosening of teeth, conjunctival swelling, congestion, and blurry vision. When the disease spreads to the orbit, proptosis can be present. It can later spread to the frontal lobe of the brain and cavernous sinus. 

The local tissue destruction with blackish nasal discharge is typically seen in invasive mucormycosis. The blackish discoloration is due to direct fungal invasion causing arterial and venous thrombosis leading to gangrene.

A definitive diagnosis is done with a biopsy and histopathologic examination. It is the most sensitive and specific method. It reveals aseptate fungi with thick-walled, ribbon-like, hyphae branching at right angles. 

Among the imaging techniques used for diagnosis, MRI is more sensitive to detecting orbital and nervous involvement than CT. Contrast-enhanced MRI is the imaging technique of choice. 1,3 beta D- glucan assay, which is helpful for the identification of most fungi, cannot be used for the diagnosis of mucormycosis.

Management is by amphotericin B and surgical debridement of the affected tissues. The underlying cause and risk factors should also be addressed.

Other options:

Option A: Invasive aspergillosis leads to the formation of black or greyish membrane in the nasal mucosa. The maxillary sinus may contain a fungus ball containing semisolid cheesy-white or blackish material.

Option C: Foreign body nose presents with foul-smelling unilateral discharge.

Option D: Rhinosporidiosis is a granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi. It presents as nasal discharge, epistaxis, and nasal obstruction by a polypoidal mass.

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady who was a victim of rape was brought by the lady constable to the gynecologist for examination. The doctor examined the victim and obtained a sample in and around the vagina. Which among the following statements is false regarding this situation?

choices.text: Seminal stains can be detected by ultraviolet light
Acid phosphatase test can be used to detect seminal stain
Absence of spermatozoa in the sample collected excludes rape
Vaginal and cervical cells can be identified from the penis of the accused using papanicolaou's stain

questions.solution:
Absence of spermatozoa in the sample obtained does not exclude rape.

The seminal fluid may have been removed by washing, or discharges or there may not have been an emission, or it may have been aspermic, or ejaculation occured outside.

Other options:

  • Seminal stains can be detected by ultraviolet light
  • An acid phosphatase test is used to identify seminal stains: The prostatic secretion contains acid phosphatase. Semen recovered from the vagina retains acid phosphatase concentrations upto 36 hours after it's deposition. It is expressed in Bodansky units. Acid phosphatase test is conclusive in case the absence of demonstrable sperms or Aspermia. The absolute proof of semen is finding at least one unbroken spermatozoon or electrophoretic LDH isoenzyme detection of sperms.
  • The suspect's penis is washed with saline and the material is stained with papanicolao's stain. Vaginal and cervical cells and barrbody identification suggest recent intercourse.

Related Pearl: Tests to detect seminal and blood stains

Tests for seminal stains

  • Barberio's test
  • Florence test
  • Acid phosphatase test
  • Creatine phosphokinase test
  • Immunological test to detect Prostate Specific Antigen

Tests for blood stains  

  • Benzidine test
  • Phenophthalein (Kastle Meyer) test
  • Takayama hemochromogen crystal test
  • Teichmann’s hemin crystal test
  • Spectroscopic test

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the given graph?

choices.text: Inhibitor binds to the active site
Inhibitor does not change the shape of the active site
Increase in substrate concentration reduces the inhibition
Vmax decreases and Kmax is unchanged

questions.solution:
The given graph shows competitive inhibition in which the value of Vmax remains constant and the Km value increases.

When the active site or catalytic site of an enzyme is occupied by a substance other than the substrate of that enzyme, this type of inhibition is known as Competitive inhibition. eg: succinate dehydrogenase reaction is inhibited by malonate. The inhibitor binds to the active site. The inhibitor does not change the shape of the active site. Competitive Inhibition is reversible.

 

Lineweaver Burk Plot for other enzyme inhibition,

Related Pearl: Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Reversible inhibitors are of two types:

  • Competitive inhibitors
  • Non-Competitive inhibitors

Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Competitive inhibitors

Non-Competitive inhibitors

Succinate dehydrogenase is inhibited by Malonate

Pyruvate kinase is inhibited by alanine

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically similar & have same shape

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically not similar & have different shape

Inhibitor binds to active site

Inhibitor binds away from active site, i.e., at allosteric site

Inhibitor does not change the shape of the active site

Inhibitor changes the shape of the active site

Increase in substrate concentration reduces the inhibition

Increase in substrate concentration does not affect the inhibition

Vmax remains constant

Vmax decreases

Km Increases

Km remains constant

questions.text: A woman is admitted to the antenatal ward at 35 weeks. Her BP is 170/110 mmHg and her urine dipstick is 3+. She developed a generalized seizure attack during the examination.  What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Give a 4 g bolus of MgSO4 by slow IV injection
Give a 40 mg bolus IV injection of labetalol

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is that of a patient with eclampsia, where the first step of treatment is the management of the airway and prevent aspiration.

The immediate measures in the medical management of eclampsia include the following steps:

  • Call for extra help (Communication)
  • To put the patient in a left lateral recumbent position
  • Maintain oral airway
  • O2 inhalation – non-rebreather mask; 10 L/minute
  • Commence IV lines; 1 or 2 wide bore cannulas
  • Catheterize the patient with a foley's catheter and an urometer
  • To monitor O2 saturation; pulse oximeter (SPO2 >95%)
  • Control of seizures: MgSO4 (IV/IM regimens)
  • To monitor vitals; fetal status and magnesium toxicity
  • Control of hypertension: Labetalol, Hydralazine
  • Fluids: Crystalloids (saline) or colloids (albumin/blood) <125 mL/h
  • Oropharyngeal suction
  • Diuretics administration for pulmonary edema, if present

MgSO4 regimens:

Regimen Loading Dose Maintenance Dose
Intramuscular (Pritchard) 4 g (20% solution) IV over 3-5 minute
followed by 10 g (5O%), deep IM
(5 g in each buttock)		 5 g (5O%) IM 4 hourly in the alternate buttock
Intravenous (Zuspan or Sibai) 4g IV slow over 15-20 minute 1-2 g/h IV infusion

 

Delivery of the fetus resolves eclampsia. In most cases, labor sets in with antepartum eclampsia. If labor does not start and the seizures are controlled, a mature baby is vaginally delivered by induction of labor. If the baby is premature, steroids are given(<34 weeks) and delivery is conducted with an NICU setup.

If the seizures are not controlled for 6-8 hours, delivery is conducted by induction of labor and by shortening the duration of the second stage of labor. In case of obstetric contraindications for a vaginal delivery, a cesarean section should be done to deliver the fetus.

questions.text: Which of the following is closely related to Mediterranean lymphoma?
questions.solution:
Alpha Heavy Chain Disease (Seligman's Disease) is closely related to a malignancy known as Mediterranean lymphoma, a disease that affects young persons in parts of the world where intestinal parasites are common.

This is the most common of the heavy chain diseases. The disease is characterized by an infiltration of the lamina propria of the small intestine with lymphoplasmacytoid cells that secrete truncated alpha chains.

Demonstration of the alpha heavy chain is difficult because the alpha chains tend to polymerize and appear as a smear instead of a sharp peak on electrophoretic profiles. Despite the polymerization, hyperviscosity is not a common problem in alpha heavy chain disease.

questions.text: A physician is looking for an NSAID which could be prescribed as once-daily dosing. Which of the following drugs fulfil his preferences?
questions.solution:
Piroxicam is the NSAID having the longest plasma half-life. 

Piroxicam is absorbed completely and undergoes enterohepatic circulation. Due to long half-life of about 50 hours, a single daily administration of the drug is sufficient for the therapeutic response.

Piroxicam is approved for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis and osteoarthritis.

questions.text: A patient with 1.5D myopia undergoes streak retinoscopy. The patient is seated one meter from the light source and is asked to fixate on a distant object as the retinoscopy is performed. With respect to the movement of the plane mirror in the retinoscope, the red reflex in the eye exhibits:
questions.solution:
In a patient with myopia of 1.5D, the red reflex will exhibit movement against the plane mirror.

When a plane mirror retinoscope is used at a distance of 1 meter, based upon the movement of the red reflex, the results can be interpreted as:

  • No movement of red reflex: myopia of 1D
  • Movement of red reflex with the plane mirror retinoscope: Emmetropia, hypermetropia, or myopia < 1D
  • Movement of red reflex against the plane mirror retinoscope: Myopia >1D
  • Oblique movement is seen in astigmatism.

questions.text: Which subunit of Nerve Growth Factor has Trypsin like activity?
questions.solution:
Alpha subunit of Nerve Growth Factor has Trypsin like activity.

 Nerve Growth Factor is the first neurotrophin identified. It is a protein growth factor that is needed for the growth and maintenance of sympathetic neurons and some sensory neurons.

It is made up of two α, two β, and two γ subunits.

Subunit Function
α Trypsin like activity
β Nerve growth-promoting activity
γ Serine proteases

The structure of the β subunit of NGF resembles that of insulin.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient had complaints of post-coital bleeding with leucorrhoea. An initial visual inspection with acetic acid showed an abnormal finding, which, when followed by a colposcopic guided biopsy of the cervix,  had the malignant cells occupying the lower 50% to 75% of the epithelial thickness. She wishes for conservative treatment, as she has not completed her family. Which of the following might be offered considering the future pregnancy?

choices.text: Needle excision of the transformation zone

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the histologic finding are suggestive of high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL/CIN II) of the cervix. An ideal procedure to be performed in this patient, anticipating the future pregnancy would be laser ablation.

This is because ablative techniques do not result in future pregnancy complications.

Techniques involving the excision of abnormal tissue such as

  • Large Loop Excision of the Transformation Zone (LLETZ)
  • Loop Electrosurgical Excision Procedure (LEEP)
  • Needle Excision of the Transformation Zone (NETZ)
  • Cold knife conization
  • Laser conization

result in the stenosis of the cervix, abortion, and premature labour. Hence avoid in female patients who desire for childbirth in the near future

Related Pearl: Management of CIN

questions.text:
In order to reach the demographic goal of NRR=1, the couple protection rate should exceed?

NRR: Net reproduction rate
questions.solution:
In order to reach the demographic goal of NRR=1, the couple protection rate (CPR) should exceed 60%. This coincides with every couple having 2 children.

Related Pearl: Pearl index and couple protection rate:

Pearl Index is defined as the number of contraceptive failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).

  • In this formula, the total accidental pregnancies that are used as the numerator must include every known conception, irrespective of its outcome.
  • In the denominator, total months of exposure is obtained by deducting, 10 months for full-term deliveries and 4 months for abortion, from the total period under review.

Couple Protection Rate:

  • It is an indicator of couple protection practice in the community.
  • It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.
  • Attaining a 60% CPR would mean restricting all third or higher-order births.

Related Pearl: Fertility Indicators

Crude birth rate

  • It is the simplest measure of fertility although its usage is unsatisfactory
  • India, as per SRS bulletin 2018, had a birth rate of 20.0 per 1000 population

General Fertility Rate

  • It is a better indicator of fertility than crude birth rate
  • The demerit of this indicator is that not all women in the denominator are exposed to childbirth

Age-specific fertility rates is a more precise measure of fertility and is also a sensitive indicator of family planning achievement.

Total Fertility Rate

  • It is the sum of all age-specific fertility rates multiplied by 5
  • This measure gives the approximate magnitude of completed family size

Gross Reproductive Rate is the average number of girls that would be born to a woman if she experiences the current fertility pattern throughout her reproductive span, assuming no mortality.

Net Reproduction Rate

  • It is a demographic indicator
  • NRR of 1 is equivalent to approximately the 2 child norm
  • If the NRR is less than 1, then the reproductive performance of the population is said to be inadequate

questions.text: A 32 year old lady is undergoing evaluation for polycystic ovary syndrome. Her sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG) is low. The decrease in sex hormone-binding globulin will have the maximum effect on which of the following hormones?
questions.solution:
The decrease in sex hormone-binding globulin will have the maximum effect on testosterone.

Around 98% of the circulating testosterone is bound to plasma proteins such as sex hormone-binding globulin (65%) and albumin. So, the decrease in sex-hormone-binding globulin (SHBG) or gonadal steroid-binding globulin (GBG) will have the maximum effect on testosterone levels by increasing the levels of its free form.

Therefore patients with polycystic ovary syndrome will show features of hyperandrogenism (due to elevated free testosterone).

questions.text: Which of the following is a false statement about the given device?

choices.text: While inflation, the cuff pressure should not exceed 60 cm of H2O
It is a second generation supra glottic airway device
It has an advantage of simple insertion and positioning
It has an integral bite block

questions.solution:
i-gel is a cuffless anatomically reshaped sealer.

It is a second-generation supraglottic airway device that has been designed to create a non-inflatable, anatomical seal of the pharyngeal, laryngeal, and perilaryngeal structures whilst avoiding compression trauma.

It has an advantage that it can be inserted and positioned in a simpler manner.

questions.text: Defect in the metabolism of which of the following is associated with increased cardiovascular risk?
questions.solution:
Defect in the metabolism of sulfur-containing amino acids (homocysteine) due to the deficiency of cystathionine-β-synthase leads to homocystinuria and increases cardiovascular risk.

Homocysteine is highly cytotoxic and elevated levels within the bloodstream are believed to damage the endothelial lining of arterial vessels, leading to intravascular coagulation.

Related Pearl: Homocystinuria

The concept for treatment:

  • Since homocysteine is produced from methionine, decreased dietary intake of methionine decreases the formation of homocysteine.
  • As the end product of this cycle is cysteine, increased dietary intake of cysteine will decrease the conversion of methionine to homocysteine through negative feedback.

questions.text: 'The secondary ossification center that appears first, fuses last'. Which of the following bones violates this law?
questions.solution:
The fibula violates the law of ossification which states that the secondary ossification center that appears first is the last to fuse.

The secondary ossification center at the lower end of the fibula appears before the ossification center of the upper end and fuses before the upper end.

Ossification centers are of two types:

  1. Primary centers appear before birth, usually during late embryonic or early fetal life (seventh week to the fourth month). They form the diaphysis.
  2. Secondary centers usually appear after birth. They form the epiphysis.

questions.text: Individuals with Duffy negative RBCs are resistant to:
questions.solution:
People with Duffy negative RBCs are resistant to P.vivax.

Resistance to P.falciparum is seen in:

  • Individuals with sickle cell trait 
  • Neonates, as fetal hemoglobin suppresses the development of P. falciparum

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to OPD with a history of the lump in the left breast. On clinical examination, the size of the lump in the left breast is 9×10 cm with no discharge and no axillary lymphadenopathy.  The histopathology of the biopsy of the lump is shown in the image. Which of the following is not true about this condition?

choices.text: Axillary dissection is done in malignant type
They present as large, sometimes massive with bosselated surface
They remain mobile on the chest wall

questions.solution:
The histopathology of the biopsy of the lump shows increased stromal cellularity, overgrowth, and typical leaflike architecture which is suggestive of phyllodes tumor. Axillary dissection is not done if malignant transformation occurs because the lymphatic spread is rare.

Phyllodes tumors usually occur in women over the age of 40 years but can appear in younger women.Phyllodes tumor is mostly benign even though it is also called as cystosarcoma phyllodes or as serocystic disease of Brodie. They are usually mobile over the chest wall despite their large size. Histologically, there is a wide variation with some of low malignant potential and others having a higher mitotic index.

Treatment of phyllodes tumor:

  • Benign type- Enucleation or wide local excision
  • Massive tumors, recurrent tumors and malignant type- Mastectomy

questions.text: A patient presents to the ophthalmology OPD with a sudden, severe diminution of vision in his right eye. Relative afferent pupillary defect is present. What is the probable diagnosis in this patient with the fundoscopic findings shown below?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in this patient is ischaemic central retinal vein occlusion.

The clinical vignette of a patient developing sudden, severe painless diminution of vision, with relative afferent pupillary defect and funduscopy of the eye showing massive retinal haemorrhages giving a splashed tomato appearance, are all suggestive of ischaemic central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO).

Other features of ischaemic CRVO on fundoscopy include numerous cotton wool spots - usually more than 6 to 10, disc showing oedema and hyperaemia, and the macular area is full of haemorrhages and is severely oedematous.

In later stages, the fundus shows marked sheathing around veins, with collaterals and neovascularization seen around and at the disc or periphery respectively.
Macula shows marked pigmentary changes and chronic cystoid oedema.

The complications include Rubeosis iridis, i.e. neovascularisation of iris and neovascular glaucoma occurs within 3 months and this is also called "90 days glaucoma".

Vitreous haemorrhage and proliferative retinopathy may also occur in a few cases. Treatment usually involves treating the underlying cause and complications.

Other options:
Option A: Non-ischaemic CRVO, also called venous stasis retinopathy, is characterised by sudden onset mild to moderate blurring of vision. Relative afferent pupillary defect is either absent or if present, mild. Pathognomonic features of ischaemic CRVO differentiating it from non-ischaemic CRVO are the presence of relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), visual field defects and reduced amplitude of b-wave on electroretinogram

Option C: Branched retinal vein occlusion is characterised by a sudden painless onset of blurred vision if the macula is involved, whereas peripheral occlusion is asymptomatic. Iris neovascularization and neovascular glaucoma are both less common in BRVO than in CRVO. On fundoscopy, dilatation and tortuosity of the affected venous segment is observed, with flame-shaped and dot/blot haemorrhages in the retinal area. Cotton wool spots and retinal edema may also be present.

Option D: Central retinal artery occlusion is characterised by sudden profound loss of vision, that is painless and visual acuity is severely reduced. Relative afferent pupillary defect is profound, giving rise to an amaurotic pupil and fundoscopy shows the presence of a cherry red spot at the region of the foveola. The peripapillary retina appears swollen and opaque.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with fatigue. Laboratory investigations are suggestive of haemolytic anaemia. Which of the following is an example of an extracorpuscular cause?
questions.solution:
Atypical haemolytic uremic syndrome (or familial HUS) is a cause of extracorpuscualar haemolytic anemia. 

Note:

  • Intracorpuscular defects are almost always hereditary. The only exception is PNH, because the defect is due to an acquired somatic mutation leading to deficiency of membrane protective factors CD59 and CD55. This makes the RBC extremely sensitive to complement activation through both pathways and causes intravascular hemolysis. 
  • Extracorpuscular defects are almost always acquired. The only exception is familial hemolytic uremic syndrome (atypical HUS): It is an inherited abnormality with excessive complement activation leading to bouts of production of membrane attack complex destroying normal RBCs leading to the triad of HUS.

Related Pearl: Classification of Hemolytic Anemias

Hemolytic anemias can be classified in 2 ways:

1. Based on the type of defect:

Type  Intracorpuscular Defects Extracorpuscular Factors
Hereditary

Hemoglobinopathies

Enzymopathies

Membrane-cytoskeletal defects

 Familial (atypical) hemolytic uremic syndrome
Acquired Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH)

Mechanical destruction (microangiopathic)

Toxic agents

Drugs

Infectious

Autoimmune

2. Based on the sites of hemolysis:

Intravascular hemolysis:

  • Mechanical injury
    • Trauma caused by cardiac valves 
    • Microangiopathic hemolytic anaemias (hemolytic uremic syndrome, disseminated intravascular coagulation, thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura) 
    • Repetitive physical trauma
  • Complement fixation (antibody-mediated destruction)
    • Hemolytic disease of the newborn- ABO incompatibility
    • Transfusion reaction  
    • Drug-induced 
  • Infections of red blood cells 
    • Malaria
    • Babesiosis
  • Exogenous toxic factors - clostridial sepsis

Extravascular hemolysis:

  • Hereditary spherocytosis
  • Thalassemia
  • Sickle cell anemia
  • Hemolytic disease of the newborn- Rh incompatibility

Both intravascular and extravascular hemolysis:

  • G6PD deficiency
  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia

questions.text: The image given below depicts the lifecycle of ________
questions.solution:
The given lifecycle is that of Paragonimus westermani.

Paragonimus westermani (lung fluke - trematode) infection is acquired by consuming freshwater crab/ crayfish containing metacercariae. It causes pulmonary symptoms similar to pulmonary tuberculosis (coughing and hemoptysis).

  • Definitive host: Men, cats, tigers, leopards, foxes, dogs, pigs, beavers, and domestic animals.
  • First intermediate host: Freshwater snail.
  • Second intermediate host: Freshwater crab or crayfish.

The adult worms live in the respiratory tract of the definitive host in cystic spaces surrounded by a fibrous capsule formed by the host tissues. Unembryonated eggs escape into the bronchi and are coughed up and voided in sputum or swallowed and passed in feces.

Praziquantel (25 mg/kg TDS for 1–2 days) is the drug of choice.

Other options:

Option B: Ascaris lumbricoides is an intestinal nematode that causes ascariasis. Infection occurs through food or water contaminated with nightsoil or human feces having eggs of Ascaris that contain the infective rhabditiform larva. 

Man is the only natural host. There is no intermediate host.

Adult worms can be occasionally detected in the stool or sputum of the patient. A definitive diagnosis is made by demonstration of eggs in feces. Fertilized eggs are always bile stained. 

Effective and safe drugs for the treatment of ascariasis are Pyrantel pamoate 11 mg/kg once, Albendazole 400 mg once, Mebendazole 100 mg twice daily for 3 days, Ivermectin 150-200 mcg/kg once.

The image below shows the life cycle of Ascaris lumbricoides: 

Option C: Fasciola hepatica is a liver fluke (trematode) that resides in the liver and the lumen of the biliary passages and causes fascioliasis. It mainly affects sheep and other domestic animals. Infection in sheep and man is acquired by ingestion of metacercariae encysted on aquatic vegetation.

  • Definitive host: Sheep, goat, cattle, and man.
  • Intermediate host: Snails of the genus Lymnaea and Succinea. Encystment occurs on aquatic plants, which act as the second intermediate host.

Oral triclabendazole (10 mg/kg once) is the treatment of choice.

Life cycle of Fasciola hepatica:

Option D: Brugia malayi is a nematode that also causes filariasis in man. The intermediate hosts of Brugia are vectors of the genera Mansonia, Anopheles, and Aedes. In India, the main vectors are Mansonia annulifera and Mansonia uniformis.

Diethylcarbamazine is found to reduce the microfilarial count.

Life cycle of Brugia malayi:

questions.text: Which of the following patients most likely has ulcerative colitis?

choices.text: A 60 year old male with  colonoscopy showing a continuous lesion of the rectum and distal colon and collar button ulcers
A 45 year old smoker with colonoscopy showing two skip lesions in terminal ileum and caecum and cobblestone appearance
A 23 year old female with pain, diarrhoea and constipation and normal findings on colonoscopy
A 56 year old female with endoscopy showing multiple ulcers in the duodenum and jejunum

questions.solution:
Of the given patients, the 60 year old male with colonoscopy showing a continuous lesion of the rectum and distal colon with collar button ulcers most likely has ulcerative colitis. Ulcerative colitis is characterized by a continuous lesion, starting at the rectum. 

Other options:

Option B: This patient probably has Crohn's disease, characterized by multiple skip lesions involving any part of the GIT. 

Option C: This patient most likely has irritable bowel syndrome.

Option D: This patient may have Zollinger-Ellsion syndrome, characterised by overproduction of gastrin from a tumor and multiple ulcers in atypical areas. 

Related Pearl: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD)

Renal Calculi- MC in CD

questions.text: A 60-year-old female presented with acute loss of vision and metamorphopsia. There is a history of the positive scotoma. Fundal changes are given below. What will be the fundus fluorescein angiography finding?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the fundal image depicting focal fundal detachment are suggestive of central serous retinopathy. An enlarging inkblot pattern or smoke stack pattern is seen in FFA.

Central serous retinopathy refers to the spontaneous serous detachment of the neurosensory retina in the macular region. Recent studies implicate an abnormal choroidal circulation as the cause of CSR. 

Clinical features:

  • Retinal detachment - Sudden painless loss of vision
  • Relative positive scotoma
  • Micropsia
  • Metamorphopsia

Investigations:

  • Ophthalmoscopy - circular ring reflex present and foveal reflex absent
  • FFA - enlarging inkblot pattern or smoke stack pattern

Spontaneous resolution is seen in most cases and hence observation is enough. Steroids are contraindicated. The disease is usually self-limiting but may recur.

The image depicts fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA), showing an enlarging ink-blot pattern/enlarging dot sign, which is seen in central serous retinopathy (CSR).

Other options:

Option B- Petaloid appearance is seen in cystoid macular edema

Option C- Stars in the sky appearance is suggestive of drusen

Option D- Dual circulation is a pathognomonic feature of choroidal melanoma

questions.text: What is the size of IV cannula shown below?
questions.solution:
The size of IV cannula in the given image is 26G.

Related Pearl: Color Coding of Intravenous Cannulae
