questions.text: Breath sounds are decreased in all of the following except ________
questions.solution:
Tubular Breath sounds are heard over the region of consolidation in lobar pneumonia.

The following findings are seen in a consolidation:

  • Dull Percussion note
  • Tubular Breath sounds
  • Increased Vocal resonance
  • No Mediastinal shift
  • Added sounds- Midline Dull  Indux fine crackles or Redux coarse crackles

Note: Other options have decreased or absent breath sounds.

questions.text: A first-year medical student focuses on the histological section of the liver during his practical exam as shown in the below image. Which of the following structure is not seen by the student in the area marked by a circle?
questions.solution:
The area marked by a circle represents the Portal Canal. Hepatic vein does not form the part of this canal.

Portal canals are present at the angular intervals at the periphery of each hepatic lobule. They are filled with connective tissue and form a connective tissue network across the entire liver substance.

Each ‘canal’ consists of

  • A branch of the portal vein
  • A branch of the hepatic artery
  • An interlobular bile duct.

These three structures collectively form a portal triad.

questions.text: Which of the following antibodies is associated with vasculitis seen in patients with Kawasaki disease?
questions.solution:
Antibodies to endothelial cells are associated with vasculitis in Kawasaki disease.

Option A: Immune complex deposition is characteristic of vasculitis due to systemic immunologic disorders such as SLE. 

Option B: ANCA-associated vasculitis is seen in microscopic polyangiitis, Churg–Strauss syndrome, and granulomatosis with polyangiitis.

Option D: Autoreactive T cells are seen in giant cell arteritis.

Reports have been described in children with a multisystem inflammatory condition (MIS-C) linked to COVID-19 infection with some features similar to Kawasaki disease and toxic shock syndrome. Although shock is rarely associated with Kawasaki disease, many children with the inflammatory syndrome related to COVID show signs of shock.

questions.text: A sister donated one of her kidneys to her brother. What would be the effect on her cardiac output?
questions.solution:
Surgical removal of kidney leads to decrease in cardiac output.

Amputation of a limb or surgical removal of organs like kidney removes a parallel circuit thus increasing total peripheral vascular resistance. As the resistance increases, afterload increases hence decreasing stroke volume. 
CO= HR × SV, therefore decrease in stroke volume leads to decrease in cardiac output.

questions.text: Which of the following patients will you classify as stage II (A) according to Ann Arbor staging for Non-Hodgkin lymphoma?

choices.text: A 32 year old female who has lymph nodes in the cervical and axillary regions without symptoms
A 32 year old female who has lymph nodes in the inguinal region and axilla without symptoms
A 32 year old female who has night sweats and lymph nodes in the inguinal region and axilla
A 32 year old female who has night sweats and lymph nodes in the cervical region and axilla

questions.solution:
A 32 year old female who has lymph nodes in the cervical and axillary regions without symptoms will be classified as II (A). Involvement of lymph nodes on the same side of diaphragm without fever/night sweats/unexplained weight loss >10% is stage II (A) of Ann-Arbor staging.

Other Options:

Option B: A 32 year old female who has lymph nodes in the inguinal region and axilla without symptoms will be classified as stage III (A). 

Option C: A 32 year old female who has night sweats and lymph nodes in the inguinal region and axilla will be classified as stage III (B).

Option D: A 32 year old female who has night sweats and lymph nodes in the cervical region and axilla will be classified as stage II (B). 

Related Pearl: Ann Arbor Staging for Hodgkin and NonHodgkin Lymphoma

Stage Distribution of disease
I

Involvement of a single lymph node region (I)

or 

a single extra lymphatic organ or site (IE)
II

Involvement of two or more lymph node regions on the same side of the diaphragm alone (II)

or

localised involvement of an extra lymphatic organ or site (IIE)
III

Involvement of lymph node regions on both sides of the diaphragm without (III) or with (IIIE) localised involvement of an extra lymphatic organ or site
IV

Diffuse involvement of one or more extra lymphatic organs or sites with or without lymphatic involvement 

All stages are further divided on the basis of the absence (A) or presence (B) of fever, night sweats and/or unexplained weight loss >10% of body weight.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male came with complaints of weakness of his right arm. After a few days, he developed weakness in his right leg, which eventually progressed to involve the left leg and then the left arm. Which condition is associated with such a pattern of weakness?
questions.solution:
This pattern is typically called "Around the clock pattern of weakness" and is seen in Foramen magnum syndrome.

Around the clock pattern of weakness is described as a sequential weakness of the ipsilateral shoulder and arm followed by weakness of the ipsilateral leg, then the contralateral leg, and finally the contralateral arm.

This is due to compressive lesions in the foramen magnum disrupting the pyramidal tract fibres. The pattern of the weakness may begin in any of the limbs. 

There is typically suboccipital pain spreading to the neck and shoulders in foramen magnum syndrome.

questions.text: During your OBG rotations, one of the senior residents asks you to induce labor in a primigravida admitted at 40 weeks of gestation. Identify the following device that you will use for the same.
questions.solution:
This is an image of a cervidil vaginal insert. It is used for cervical ripening and improves the Bishop's score.

It contains 10 mg of dinoprostone designed to release at a rate of approximately 0.3 mg/hr over 10-hours.

questions.text: In which stage of the demographic cycle is India in currently?
questions.solution:
Currently, India is in stage 3 i.e. Late expanding stage of the demographic cycle.

Demographic gift or demographic dividend is seen in stage 3 of the demographic cycle. It is a phenomenon that India is currently experiencing, in which there is a higher number of economically productive population (young adults and middle-aged adults) due to a higher birth rate in previous demographic phase (phase 2).

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

Stages of the demographic cycle include:

  • Stage 1 - High stationary 
    • High birth rates and high death rates render the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 2 - Early expanding 
    • The death rate declines and the birth rate remains unchanged
    • The demographic gap starts increasing and becomes maximum
  • Stage 3 - Late expanding
    • Death rate declines further and birth rate falls
    • India is in this stage, currently
    • The demographic gap starts declining
  • Stage 4 - Low stationary 
    • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 5 - Declining 
    • The population begins to decline as the birth rate is lower than the death rate
    • The demographic gap is negative

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with generalized edema. Urine analysis showed protein 3+ and fat bodies. Which of the following would you expect to see in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of nephrotic syndrome. This leads to a decrease in serum albumin which is an unmeasured anion.

Albumin at physiological pH is the major contributor to the unmeasured anions of the body. Unmeasured anions consume bicarbonate in the body and reduce its levels. This leads to an increase in the anion gap. Therefore, when these unmeasured anions are reduced the anion gap also reduces due to decreased consumption of the bicarbonate.

Nephrotic syndrome causes hypoalbuminemia and thus patients have a reduced anion gap. A fall in serum albumin by 1 g/dL from the normal value (4.5 g/dL) decreases the anion gap by 2.5 mEq/L.

Decreased anion gap (<6 mEq/L) is seen in:

  • Increase in unmeasured cations
  • An addition of abnormal cations to the blood, such as:
    • Lithium (lithium intoxication)
    • Cationic immunoglobulins (plasma cell dyscrasias)
  • Reduction in the plasma anion albumin concentration (nephrotic syndrome, liver disease, or malabsorption)
  • Bromide intoxication
  • Hyperviscosity and severe hyperlipidemia, which can lead to an underestimation of sodium and chloride concentrations.

Related Pearl: Causes of Metabolic Acidosis

High Anion-Gap Metabolic Acidosis (MUDPILES) Normal Anion-Gap Metabolic Acidosis (FUSED CAR)
Methanol Fistula pancreatic
Uremia (Renal failure - Acute or Chronic) Ureterosigmoidostomy
Diabetic ketoacidosis Small bowel fistula
Paraldehyde Extra chloride (Hyperalimentation)
Iron tablets, INH Diarrhea
Lactic acidosis Carbonic anhydrase inhibitor (acetazolamide)
Ethylene glycol Addison's disease
Salicylates Renal tubular acidosis

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman in the first trimester of pregnancy presents to your clinic with hair loss. She gives a history of typhoid fever 3 months ago. What is the pattern of hair loss seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The pattern of hair loss in this clinical scenario is telogen effluvium. It is an acute-onset scalp hair loss that occurs 2–3 months after a triggering event such as high fever, surgical trauma, sudden starvation, or hemorrhage.

It refers to an increase in the shedding of telogen club hairs due to premature termination of the anagen (proliferative) phase of the hair cycle following a period of stress.

Chronic diffuse telogen hair loss refers to telogen hair shedding persisting > 6 months. Causes of chronic diffuse telogen hair loss are:

  • Thyroid disorders (Both hyper- and hypo­thyroidism)
  • Severe iron deficiency anemia, acroder­matitis enteropathica, and malnutrition.

Telogen gravidarum refers to telogen hair loss seen 2–3 months after childbirth. The circulating placental estrogen during pregnancy prolongs anagen phase. After delivery, the estrogen withdrawal pushes all the hair simultaneously into catagen and then telogen phase.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child weighing 13 kg brought with the complaints of vomiting and diarrhoea with dehydration for 2 days which was corrected with IV fluids. Now, the child looks hydrated but has poor feeding. How much fluid should the child receive?
questions.solution:
This child should recieve fluid at the rate of 46ml/hr.

Hourly Maintenance Water Rate:

  • For body weight 0 - 10 kg : 4 ml/kg/hr
  • For body weight 11 - 20 kg : 40 ml/hr(for first 10 kg) + 2 ml/kg/hr for each Kg beyond 10 Kg
  • For Body weight  >20 kg : 60 ml/hr(for first 20 kg) + 1 ml/kg/hr for each Kg beyond 20 Kg

So, for this child it is 40 ml/hr(for first 10 kg) + (2*3 ml/hr) = 46 ml/hr With total maintenance fluid per day being 1,150 ml.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman delivers a male baby at 28 weeks of gestation. The preterm neonate was diagnosed with respiratory distress syndrome. Which of the following ions are present in the compound that is deficient in this condition?
questions.solution:
Preterm babies develop respiratory distress syndrome or hyaline membrane disease due to surfactant deficiency. The calcium ions are present in the pulmonary surfactant.

Surfactant is a complex mixture of several phospholipids, proteins, and ions. The most important components are:

  • Phospholipid dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine,
  • Surfactant apoproteins,
  • Calcium ions.

The surfactants reduce the surface tension in the alveoli. It increases lung compliance, which reduces the work of expanding the lungs during inspiration.

questions.text: To which of the following patients would you give 2 doses of rabies vaccine alone on day 0 and day 3?

choices.text: A 45 yr old unimmunized veterinarian who got a laceration by dog bite
A 23 yr old vaccinated woman who fed a stray dog which did not bite her
A 10 yr old vaccinated boy whose dog nibbled his toe but there was no bleeding
A 56 yr old unimmunized man whose dog licked his hand over intact skin

questions.solution:
This boy is a category II patient and treatment for him warrants wound management and rabies vaccine on days 0 and 3 (since the time of immunization is not mentioned).

Other options:

Options B and D: Are category I and do not require rabies prophylaxis.

Option A: Is category III and requires wound care, rabies immunoglobulin, and rabies vaccine.

Related Pearl: Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins schedules

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India:

WHO category II or III exposures should receive post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) immediately.

One intradermal (ID) dose is 0.1 mL of vaccine and one intramuscular (IM) dose is an entire vial of vaccine, irrespective of the vial size.

Should a vaccine dose be delayed for any reason, the PEP schedule should be resumed (not restarted).

Rabies Immunoglobulin(RIG): 

  • Passive immunization
  • Single-dose; after initiation of PEP and not beyond 7 days after the first dose of vaccine
  • Max dose: hRIG - 20IU/kg , eRIG - 40IU/kg body weight
  • Vaccines should never be withheld regardless of the availability of RIG.
  • Alternatives for RIG- WHO recommends monoclonal antibodies (mAb) as a 'cocktail' containing at least two antibodies against the rabies virus.

Administration of RIG:

  • RIG should be administered into or around the wound site or sites.
  • The remaining RIG, if any, should be injected IM at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration.
  • RIG may be diluted to a volume sufficient for all wounds to be effectively and safely infiltrated.

Prioritization of RIG allocation (numbered according to priority order):

  1. Multiple bites
  2. Deep wounds
  3. Bites to head, neck, and hands
  4. Patients with severe immunodeficiency
  5. Confirmed/probable rabies in biting animal
  6. Bites, scratches, and exposure of mucous membranes caused by a bat

Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP)

PrEP is considered in the following conditions:

  • High-risk groups- laboratory staff, wildlife wardens, veterinarians, animal handlers, and travelers to endemic regions.
  • Remote, rabies-endemic areas where access to PEP is difficult
  • Areas where dog bite incidence is >5% per year
  • Areas where vampire bat rabies is known to be present.

Pre-exposure rabies vaccination consists of 3 intramuscular (IM) or 3 intradermal (ID) doses. These are given on days 0, 7 and 21 or 28.

  • Adults - the vaccine should always be administered in the deltoid area of the arm
  • Young children (under 1 year of age)- Administration into the anterolateral area of the thigh is recommended.
  • Rabies vaccine should never be administered in the gluteal area. Administration in this manner will result in lower neutralizing antibody titers.

For exposed or re-exposed patients who can document previous completion of PEP or PrEP the following guidelines would be applicable:

  • Proper wound management should be done.
  • There is no need for the administration of RIG.
  • One site ID or IM vaccine administration on days 0 and 3.

Only adequate wound washing would be required in case of re-exposure where the animal bite victim has documented proof of complete PEP within the last three months.

The following cases are treated as fresh cases and given full PEP:

  • Those who have previously received full post-exposure treatment with neural tissue vaccines (NTV) or vaccines of unproven potency
  • Those who cannot document complete PEP or PrEP treatment

questions.text: All of the following are radiolucent renal stone except?
questions.solution:
Oxalate stone is not a radiolucent renal stone. It is a radiopaque renal stone.

Other options:

Options A,B,and C:  Indinavir stone, uric acid stone ,and xanthine stone are radiolucent  renal stone.

Related Pearl: Radiolucent Renal Stones

Radiolucent Renal Stones

Mnemonic: X UTI

  • Xanthine
  • Uric Acid (most common)

Drug induced renal stones

  • Triamterene
  • Indinavir

questions.text: Which of the following is a double-stranded RNA virus?
questions.solution:
Reovirus is the double-stranded RNA virus.

Parvovirus has single-stranded DNA. All DNA viruses are double-stranded, except parvovirus (the only single-stranded DNA virus)

All RNA viruses have only one copy of single-stranded  RNA except:

  • Reovirus - the only double-stranded RNA virus
  • Retrovirus - possess 2 copies of single-stranded RNA

questions.text: Identify the correct statement with respect to the Bosniak classification of a renal cyst?

choices.text: All Category I requires surgical treatment
Category III do not have risk of malignancy
Category IV includes malignant cystic masses
It is based on USG and intravenous pyelogram findings

questions.solution:
Category IV Bosniak classification of a renal cyst includes malignant cystic masses.

Bosniak classification is based on CT criteria but can also be applied to MRI imaging. 

It includes:

Category I: It is a simple benign cyst, without any septations, calcification and solid component.

Category II: The cyst consists of one or more thin (<1 mm) septation and fine calcification. A subcategory, class IIF includes large (>3 cm) hyperdense cysts or hyperdense cysts that are totally intrarenal. Class II lesions are benign.

Category III: These are complicated cysts having thickened septa with nodular areas of calcification or solid non-enhancing areas.

Category IV: Malignant cystic masses- These are malignant lesions with solid enhancing nodules.

Category I and II cysts do not require treatment and do not require follow-up imaging.

The category III lesions should be surgically explored or biopsied. <50% will turn out to be malignant.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of herpetic keratitis?
questions.solution:
Corneal guttata are seen in corneal dystrophy.

Peripheral guttata are seen in old age—Hassall–Henle bodies. Central guttata, on the other hand, are found in Fuch's endothelial dystrophy.

Related Pearl: Ocular lesions of Herpes Simplex

Primary herpes:

  • Cornea
    • Fine epithelial punctate keratitis
    • Coarse epithelial punctate keratitis
    • Dendritic ulcer
  • Conjunctiva: acute follicular conjunctivitis
  • Skin lesions

Recurrent herpes:

  • Active epithelial keratitis
    • Punctate epithelial keratitis
    • Dendritic ulcer
    • Geographical ulcer
  • Stromal keratitis
  • Disciform keratitis
  • Diffuse stromal necrotic keratitis
  • Trophic keratitis (meta-herpetic)
  • Herpetic iridocyclitis

questions.text: One of the effector mechanisms in cell-mediated immunity involves identifying and lysing target cells whose membrane surface antigens are bound by specific antibodies.NK cells are one of the effector cells capable of this process. What other cells are capable of this process?
questions.solution:
Neutrophils and Eosinophils are capable of the effector mechanism described along with NK cells.


The effector mechanism being described refers to Antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC). Antibody dependent cellular cytotoxicity is seen with NK cells. However, it is also seen in macrophages,neutrophils and eosinophil killing certain parasitic worms like helminths via IgE antibodies.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient had 6 attacks of migraine in the last month and was treated for the same. She is not able to tolerate the pain during attacks and came to the hospital asking for medication that can prevent these attacks in the future. Which of the following drugs can be used in this patient?
questions.solution:
Topiramate can be used in this patient to prevent migraine attacks.

In patients with ≥4 attacks of migraine in a month, prophylactic medications can be used. The various FDA-approved drugs include propranolol, timolol, rimegepant, sodium valproate, topiramate, eptinezumab, erenumab, fremanezumab, and galcanezumab.

Drugs used for prophylaxis of migraine:

  • Beta blockers: Propranolol, metoprolol, timolol, atenolol
  • Antidepressants: Amitriptyline, nortriptyline, imipramine
  • Anticonvulsants: Valproate, topiramate
  • Serotonin antagonist: Methysergide
  • Angiotensin II receptor blocker: Candesartan
  • Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor: Lisinopril
  • Calcium channel blockers: Flunarizine

Other modalities of preventive treatment:

  • Onabotulinum toxin type A is used in the prevention of chronic migraine
  • Neuromodulation: A single-pulse transcranial magnetic stimulation (sTMS) is delivered with a hand-held device (FDA approved) that creates a fluctuating magnetic field which triggers an electric current that modifies cortical excitability.

No role in prophylaxis :

  • Calcium channel blockers: Verapamil, nimodipine, diltiazem. 
  • α2 adrenergic agonist: Clonidine. 
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors: Fluoxetine.

Related Pearl: Simplified diagnostic criteria for migraine

Repeated attacks of headache lasting 4-72 h in patients with a normal physical examination with no other reasonable cause for the headache, and

At least 2 of the following features:

  • Unilateral pain
  • Throbbing pain
  • Aggravation by movement
  • Moderate or severe intensity

Plus at least 1 of the following features:

  • Nausea/vomiting
  • Photophobia and phonophobia

questions.text: What does the number 4 in the given diagram related to hypertension denote?

choices.text: Diagnosed hypertensive subjects not on treatment

questions.solution:
The above diagram depicts the rule of halves, which is observed in hypertension, and "number 4" denotes undiagnosed patients.

The rule of halves depicts that only about half of the hypertensive subjects in the general population of most developed countries were aware of the condition and only half of those aware are being treated and only half of those being treated are considered to be adequately treated. 

The numbers in the diagram denote the following:

  1. Whole community
  2. Normotensive subjects
  3. Hypertensive subjects
  4. Undiagnosed hypertension
  5. Diagnosed hypertension
  6. Diagnosed but untreated
  7. Diagnosed and treated
  8. Inadequately treated
  9. Adequately treated

questions.text: A 48-year-old female patient presented with excessive, painless bleeding per vaginum for the past 8 days. This episode was preceded by two months of amenorrhea. The ultrasound revealed thickened endometrium, with thin slender polypi projecting into the uterine cavity, and associated myometrial hyperplasia. Which of the following statements is false regarding the condition?

choices.text: Endometrial sampling is mandatory in evaluating the disease
The ovaries associated with this condition may have a cyst
Endometrial histology shows the presence of cork screw glands
This type of AUB is not related to parity

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of metropathia haemorrhagica, and the corkscrew glands are not seen in this condition.

The endometrium shows characteristic cystic glandular hyperplasia, which appears as a swiss cheese pattern. The second feature is the absence of secretory endometrium i.e absence of corkscrew glands (as the bleeding is anovulatory, there is no progesterone and hence no secretory changes in the endometrium).

Metropathia haemorrhagica, is a specialized form of anovulatory abnormal uterine bleeding, is seen in women aged 40 to 45 years.

Typical symptoms are continuous painless vaginal bleeding at the onset of menses or preceded by a 6-8 week period of amenorrhoea. Occasionally the woman gives a history of menorrhagia prior to this.

The uterus is slightly bulky, uniformly enlarged and the uterine wall shows a mild degree of myohyperplasia, measuring up to 2.5 cm. The endometrium is thick, polypoidal, and thin slender polyps project into the uterine cavity. Corpus luteum is absent and one or both ovaries may contain a cyst, not larger than 5 cm.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old patient comes to the hospital due to frequent episodes of abdominal pain and black tarry stools. He has been using Ibuprofen for the last 20 years due to back pain. The following findings are seen in his peripheral smear. Which of the following is likely to be been seen in this patient?

TIBC - Total iron-binding capacity

choices.text: TIBC increased, Ferritin decreased, Transferrin saturation increased
TIBC increased, Soluble transferrin receptor decreased, Ferritin increased
TIBC increased, Transferrin saturation decreased, Ferritin decreased
TIBC increased, Transferrin saturation decreased, Ferritin increased

questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of iron-deficiency anemia. In iron-deficiency anemia, TIBC is increased, transferrin saturation is decreased, and ferritin is decreased.

Prolonged NSAID use is a common cause of upper gastrointestinal bleeding as seen in this patient, where it presents as anemia and blood loss. Chronic GI blood loss is one of the most common causes of iron-deficiency anemia.

Iron deficiency is the most common nutritional disorder in the world. IDA results from dietary deficiency, impaired absorption, increased requirement, and, chronic blood loss. The cause of IDA in an older man or post-menopausal woman is always gastrointestinal cancer until proven otherwise.

Clinical presentation may include fatigue, pallor, dyspnea, cheilosis (fissures at the corners of the mouth), and koilonychia (spooning of the fingernails).

The image given below shows koilonychia:

 

Diagnosis is mainly by laboratory studies. The typical findings are low hemoglobin level and low hematocrit. Serum levels of iron and ferritin are low while the total iron binding capacity is increased. These changes lead to a decrease in transferrin saturation. Decreased stores of iron inhibit hepcidin synthesis and, hence, hepcidin is low.

Peripheral smear in IDA shows:

  • Microcytic hypochromic red blood cells with an enlarged zone of central one-third pallor
  • Poikilocytes: pencil-shaped RBCs and, target cells

The image below shows a peripheral blood smear with microcytic hypochromic cells:

 

Bone marrow shows a mild to moderate raise in erythroid progenitors. The absence of iron stains in macrophages is a significant finding.

Red cell distribution width (RDW) is a quantitative measure of variation in cell size that is calculated from MCV (mean corpuscular volume). Normal RDW is 11-14%. A high RDW denotes anisocytosis, suggestive of iron deficiency.

IDA is treated by giving oral, parenteral, and packed cell transfusions depending on the severity of anemia.

For oral iron replacement therapy,

  • Up to 200 mg of elemental iron is given.
  • According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat initiative, adult women need to take 60 mg of elemental iron + 500 mcg of folic acid tablets once a week.

For parenteral iron therapy, the amount of iron needed by an individual is calculated by the formula:

Body weight (kg) x 2.3 x (15 - patient's hemoglobin, g/dL) + 500 or 1000 mg (for stores).

Related Pearl: Differential Diagnosis of Microcytic Anaemia

Investigation Iron- Deficiency Anemia Alpha or beta thalassemia Anemia of Chronic Disease
Serum Iron <60 µg/dL Normal/Increased Decreased
Serum Ferritin <20 µg/L Normal/Increased Increased
TIBC Increased Normal Decreased
Transferrin saturation <15% Normal Normal/Decreased
MCV Decreased  Decreased Normal/Decreased
RBC count Decreased Normal/Increased Normal/Increased

TIBC: Total iron-binding capacity

questions.text: What is splenunculi?

choices.text: Ruptured spleen and its content on the peritoneum

questions.solution:
Splenunculi are single or multiple accessory spleens. Most commonly they are found near the hilum of the spleen.

Other options:

Option A- Rupture of the spleen and distribution of its tissue on the peritoneum is termed splenosis.

Option C- Hamartoma are rare splenic mass of varing size.

Option D- Splenic cysts are rare and are of two types based on the presence or absence of lining epithelium true cyst and pseudocyst respectively.

questions.text: Which among the following organisms is most commonly implicated in infective endocarditis involving the tricuspid valve in injection drug users?
questions.solution:
Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of infective endocarditis involving tricuspid valve (right side) in injection drug users.

questions.text: A previously untreated HIV-positive patient is diagnosed with tuberculosis and treatment is initiated for both the diseases. Two weeks into treatment, he suddenly complains of high fever, severe malaise and worsening cough. What is the likely explanation?

choices.text: Bacterial endotoxin release due to death of TB bacilli

questions.solution:
Concurrent treatment with anti-retroviral therapy is the most likely explanation in this case resulting in Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome (IRIS). Its characteristics are:

  • Temporary paradoxical exacerbation of symptoms (lymphadenopathy, fever or worsening of pulmonary infiltrations, pleural effusion) and radiographic manifestations of TB after starting ART. This occurs as a result of immune reconstitution due to simultaneous administration of ART and ATT. 
  • It is seen weeks to months following the initiation of combination antiretroviral therapy (cART).
  • It is most common in previously untreated patients starting therapy with a CD4+ T cell count <50/μL who experience a sudden drop in viral load.
  • The earlier ART is started and the lower the baseline CD4+ T-cell count, the greater the risk of IRIS.
  • In severe cases, the use of immunosuppressive drugs such as glucocorticoids may be required to blunt the inflammatory component of IRIS while specific antimicrobial therapy takes effect.

Note: Hypersensitivity to isoniazid is extremely rare and the presentation includes maculopapular rash.

questions.text: A polytrauma patient with the given x-ray finding is being taken up for damage control surgery. Which of the following inhalational agents should be avoided in her?
questions.solution:
The image shows a pneumothorax. The inhalational agent to be avoided is nitrous oxide.

Nitrous oxide has the potential to expand air-containing cavities, as it can diffuse into and accumulate in them. Hence it should be avoided in patients with pneumothorax.

Related Pearl: Unique features of Nitrous oxide

Concentration-effect

  • The blood gas partition coefficient of N2O is 35 times higher than O2 and N2, hence its rapid uptake diminishes its volume and concentrates the remaining anesthetics in the alveolus.

Second-gas effect

  • Concentration-effect of one gas over another is known as the second gas effect
  • Increase in the partial pressure of the 2nd gas (Oxygen and volatile agents) due to the rapid uptake of N2O during induction.

Diffusion hypoxia (Finks effect)

  • Rapid elimination of N2O during recovery causes a reduction in the partial pressure of oxygen leading to hypoxia
  • Avoided by using 100% oxygen for 10 minutes during recovery from anesthesia.

Nitrous oxide in gas-filled spaces

  • It diffuses into air-containing cavities more rapidly than air (principally nitrogen) can be absorbed by the bloodstream
  • If the walls surrounding the cavity are rigid, pressure rises instead of volume.

Hence N2O is contraindicated in:

  • Venous or arterial air embolism
  • Acute intestinal obstruction
  • Pneumocephalus, pneumothorax
  • Pulmonary air cysts
  • Intraocular air bubbles
  • Tympanic membrane grafting.

questions.text: The ‘en bloc' removal of organs is a feature of which of the following autopsy techniques?
questions.solution:
The 'en bloc' removal of organs is done in the Ghon technique. In this procedure, the cervical, thoracic, abdominal, and urogenital organs are removed as organ blocks.

The 'en masse' removal of organs is done in the Letulle technique. It is the removal of the cervical, thoracic, abdominal, and pelvic organs as a single organ mass. The mass is then dissected into organ blocks.

Related Pearl: Autopsy Techniques

  • Virchow's technique: Organs are removed one by one from the body to be examined. Here the cranial cavity is opened first, then the spinal cord, followed by thoracic, cervical, and abdominal organs in that order.
  • Ghon's technique: Here the organs are removed 'en bloc'. The thoracic, cervical, pelvic, and abdominal organs are removed as organ blocks.
  • Rokitansky's technique: This is characterized by 'in situ' dissection in part combined with en bloc removal like Ghon's technique. The dissection begins at the neck and slowly works its way down the body and the organ is removed as a bloc. A cut is first made at the larynx to separate the esophagus from the pharynx. The larynx and trachea are pulled downward and using a scalpel, the chest organs are cut. The diaphragm is cut to expose the abdominal organs. Other organs like the bladder and rectum are separated from the body by using a scalpel to cut the pelvic ligaments.
  • Letulle's technique: Thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed 'en masse' meaning as one big organ block. It allows the body to be made available for examination in less than 30 minutes as the process of removing the organs is much quicker.

Related Pearl: Autopsy: Types Of Incision

Type of incision Procedure Indication Advantage
I-Shaped Incision Extends from symphysis menti to symphysis pubis, taking a curve towards the left around the umbilicus. It is used routinely in practice It is simple and convenient.
Y-Shaped Incision Commences at the acromial process on the shoulder on either side of the chest, runs downwards and anteriorly beneath the breasts as to meet at the xiphisternum and then run downwards as in the "I"-shaped incision   Preferred in females It prevents cutting of the chest skin in the midline.
Modified Y-Shaped Incision Commences at the angle of mandible on either side, brought forwards, downwards to meet at the suprasternal notch . It is then run downwards as a midline incision up to the pubic symphysis. Preferred when a detailed study of neck structures required, e.g. asphyxial death due to neck compression.  It has better exposure and allows the study of neck structures. 
Elongated X-shaped Incision Used to dissect out subcutaneous structures in the back to identify and evaluate the extent of blunt injuries.  Should be practiced in cases of custodial death.  Helpful in the reconstruction of events prior to death.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is brought to OPD with complaints of upper respiratory tract infections, fever, sandpaper rash over her trunk and extremities. On oral examination, the following image was seen. What is the most probable etiological agent?
questions.solution:
Scarlet fever is the most probable diagnosis. The etiological agent is beta-hemolytic streptococci.

Upper respiratory infection with sandpaper rash and the strawberry tongue is suggestive of scarlet fever. Pyrogenic exotoxin (erythrogenic exotoxin) produced by Group A Streptococcus is responsible for scarlet fever. The above image shows the strawberry appearance of the tongue. The tongue is usually coated, and the papillae are swollen, giving the tongue a strawberry appearance.

 

Other options:

HHV 6 causes exanthema subitum, also called the 6th disease, is an acute febrile illness with maculopapular eruptions.

Erythema infectiosum is caused by parvovirus B19. Clinical features include fever and rash over the face which has a typical slapped cheek appearance. Affected children are afebrile or have a mild fever and do not appear ill.
